TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, is overseas on government business. He will return on 9 December. During his absence the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Senator Faulkner, will take questions relating to the defence portfolio and will also represent the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I also inform the Senate that the Minister for Trade, Senator Cook, is overseas on government business. He will return on 17 December. During his absence I will take questions relating to the trade portfolio. Questions relating to the portfolio of primary industries and energy should be addressed to the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson.
—by leave—I want to again protest this practice. Every week it seems that some ministers are not bothering to turn up for question time.
—Don't look at me.

—Senator Collins is one of the better ones. In the last sitting week, Senator Cook was at a conference in Melbourne. This week we all know where he is, although the minister did not seem to want to mention it. We all know that both Senator Ray and Senator Cook are in Malaysia. Our relations with Malaysia could have been helped in other ways, rather than by sending ministers there after the event. But that is by the way.

PARA.TAB: The important issue is on what basis the government can, at its whim, decide ministers are going to go off on various conferences or for other reasons not attend question time. We have always accepted that, in relation to CHOGMs, or meetings of the forum in the Pacific, or longstanding, regular commitments in exceptional circumstances, it is legitimate. But this government is now going far beyond the normal, legitimate, accepted practice of the past. We at least ought to be given the courtesy of reasons as to why this is going to occur.

Mr Deputy President, you might have picked up that Senator Cook is not going to come back until after the Senate has risen. Apparently, he will not be here for the whole fortnight. Why is it necessary for the minister to be away from the parliament for the whole fortnight—a junior minister at that? It might well be that Senator Gareth Evans feels that he can pick up the trade portfolio again, but that is not a legitimate justification either.

What can we do other than protest? There are all sorts of things that we can do to make the government's life more difficult but that we avoid. However, if this abuse of the process of the parliament is going to continue, we will have to look at our options. I presume it is a purposeful decision of the Prime Minister, and we know his attitude—

TALK.START.PARA: —Fred used to turn it on with much more conviction.

—No, our ministers used to attend. Our ministers accepted a responsibility to attend the parliament and to answer questions. Mr Keating has a different attitude to the parliament. He does not see the responsibility to the parliament in the way that it was traditionally seen. It is just another example of his general attitude to the process, which he sees as more of a nuisance than as part of constructive democracy. On some occasion, can we get some general guidelines as to the basis upon which the government is going to decide which ministers will attend when—which conferences are of such note that ministers need not attend before the parliament? This is now getting to the ridiculous stage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In the present circumstances I hesitate to use the expression `feigned indignation', but nonetheless there is ample evidence of that in the contribution that Senator Hill just made. Obviously, the circumstances which take both these ministers out of the country at the moment are such as to fully justify their absence from this chamber.

PARA.TAB: These are not discretionary bilateral visits. It may have escaped Senator Hill's notice that the Uruguay Round is reaching its final stages and will not be completed until 15 December. Senator Cook, after a brief stop in Malaysia, will be going on to Geneva where he will be spending, in effect, the whole of that time in the last stages of the negotiations in his capacity—Senator Hill may have overlooked this—as chairman of the Cairns Group. Ministers from all over the world will be attending those negotiations in Geneva. It would be an absolute abdication of Australian government responsibility were Senator Cook not to be there under those circumstances.

Senator Ray is involved in the annual Langkawi defence industry exhibition and sales promotion exercise which is taking place in Malaysia. The dates for it are specified without regard to the timing of our Senate sittings. As far back as I can remember it has been regarded as appropriate by ministers to attend and to lead Australian defence industry delegations on these occasions. Under those circumstances, it would be understood by all reasonable people—which, in this instance, does not comprehend Senator Hill or the opposition—that there is ample justification for their absence from this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the decision of the MARA Foundation of Malaysia not to send 15 scholarship students to Eynesbury College in Adelaide, which is a privately owned educational establishment, at substantial financial cost to the college. How does the minister explain to Australian business why it should suffer as a result of the gratuitous indulgences of the Prime Minister? How could the minister also have got it so wrong when he advised the Senate on 25 November this year that, in his opinion, the relationship was `unlikely to be blown off course by the cross-winds of this kind'? Why did he not immediately, after the offensive remarks by Mr Keating, seek to minimise the damage rather than talk down the likely consequences?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in nobody's interests that the present problem with Malaysia escalate any further. I hope very much that the Malaysian cabinet may be prepared to accept a cooling-off period—a pause for reflection—before taking any further punitive or retaliatory measures of the kind that have been foreshadowed. I will certainly be making every effort that I can, including direct contact with my counterpart, if possible, to see what might be achievable in this respect.

PARA.TAB: Our basic message remains very simple: no offence was intended and, if it was taken, we regret that. We value our relationship with Malaysia. We will do everything we reasonably can to keep it warm and productive, with the visits of Senator Cook and Senator Ray being current demonstrations of our commitment in that respect. But if a good relationship is to continue, it must be wanted and worked for by both sides.

It may be helpful to reflect on the circumstances that have surrounded each stage of the development of this problem. When each side understands how the other perceives a problem, there is usually a better chance of resolving it. In the first place, it would be helpful if the Malaysian side were to acknowledge the circumstances in which Mr Keating's original remarks were made. He had been asked on numerous previous occasions about his attitude to Dr Mahathir's non-appearance in Seattle and on each occasion replied in neutral terms.

However, on 21 November the question was put in the form of a request for comment on a reported statement in the New York Times that morning by Dr Mahathir that, `Perhaps you have to thumb your nose at people before they notice you'. To the extent that Mr Keating's reply emerged more sharply on this occasion than it had in earlier replies, this was an understandable reaction in the circumstances. I note that that was certainly the reaction of the opposition spokesmen Mr Peacock and Mr Fischer, and I do not think that their change of heart subsequently does them much credit.

In the second place, I think it would be helpful for Australians to understand the cultural context in which Mr Keating's remark was reported in Malaysia. The Malay word for `recalcitrant' is `kurang ajar' and to call someone kurang ajar in Malay, I discovered just a few days ago, is extremely insulting, much more so than the use of the English word would indicate. It means in Malay that one is ill-educated; it reflects seriously on one's background and family, implying that one's parents did not bring one up properly. I understand that Mr Keating's comment had all the more resonance in Malaysia, or at least in the Malay language press, because it was made just a few days after a particularly acrimonious exchange involving the use and subsequent withdrawal of this expression between a Malaysian minister and a member of the opposition Democratic Action Party.

A third circumstance that should be taken into account by each country in evaluating the actions of the other is the very different way in which Australian and Malaysian political cultures operate in response to issues of this kind. In Malaysia when some real or perceived international slight is reported, then—other things being equal—the media and just about all other interest groups tend to reflexively line up in defence of the person or institution in question. In Australia, by contrast, the media and other key interest groups are very much more likely to line up against the person or institution in question, assuming that if a criticism is made there must be some case to answer. In these circumstances, the two different kinds of national reactions tend to feed off each other, with every report generating another round, respectively, of indignation and self-laceration.

A fourth circumstance that perhaps needs to be appreciated by the Malaysian side is that we in Australia cannot help but feel a little wounded by the strength of a number of the reported comments and reactions coming from Malaysia. Not only were there the actions taken by the information minister, and a number of statements made suggesting that commercial relationships with Australia were at risk—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister's time has expired.
—I seek leave to complete this answer, given its importance.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have seen the Kelantan Premier saying, for example:

ANSWER.PARA: What do you expect from a leader whose forefathers were ex-convicts and social discards . . . this kind of person is not properly brought up, hence the bad manners.

Even taking into account the questions of translation to which I have referred, this goes much further than any Australian statement. Mr Keating's letter last week made the point very clearly that his remarks had not been calculated to offend: if he was less than fulsomely conciliatory or apologetic than Dr Mahathir would have preferred him to be, then perhaps some of the background atmosphere against which the letter was written will help explain why.

PARA.TAB: Finally, the important thing at this stage is that no action be taken which will make the present situation worse than it is. With a relationship as fundamentally strong as Australia's and Malaysia's, there is no inherent reason why it need go off the rails. If we can have a cooling off period—and if we each make a real effort to understand why the other side has acted and reacted as it has—then there is no reason why our relationship cannot flourish in the future as it has in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. That was a considered answer; it is hard to see how it will help the matter. I would have thought lecturing the Malaysians at this stage was the last thing that would be constructive and helpful. My question was in relation to Eynesbury College in Adelaide. Why should it suffer financially as a result of the gratuitous indulgences of the Prime Minister? Can I have a considered answer to that question?
—I do not accept the premise that that was a gratuitous indulgence and, therefore, an answer is not necessary.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer to the announcement yesterday that an agreement has been signed between an Australian consortium, KITComm Pty Ltd, and PacAstro Inc. of Virginia in the United States for an Australian launch of two communications satellites. Is the minister able to provide any further details about this agreement and what implications this development has for the future of the Australian space industry?

—I am able to inform the Senate that last week an agreement was signed between an Australian company, KITComm, which is a joint venture between Kennett International Technology of Queensland and several private investors, and an American company, PacAstro Inc. from Virginia in the United States. They have agreed to prepare a proposal to launch low orbiting satellites on an equatorial course from the very north of Australia near Darwin. The two-stage rockets are very inexpensive and very small. The satellite would be around 250 kilograms and would be used for remote monitoring and sensing work on a commercial basis only. I emphasise that this whole project is commercially driven, market driven, and is not requiring a government contribution.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the consortium has already had discussions with the Northern Territory government. In today's press, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Perron, was very enthusiastic about the project. The project offers two launches of satellites but this could lead to launches, either at the site in the Northern Territory or from Woomera, of polar orbiting low earth satellites.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't you tell us about this the other week?

—No, I did not mention this last week. This is a new development which I am sure that Senator Panizza, with his interest in satellites, would more than welcome. This is a new development involving the launching of rockets from the Northern Territory. The site that is being considered in conjunction with the Northern Territory government and the Australian Space Office would be within a 30-kilometre range of Darwin. I emphasise that there would have to be an environmental impact statement and consultations with the local community to ensure that all safety factors are taken into account.

PARA.TAB: I notice that in this morning's media, the chief of the Australian Space Council and also the director of the Northern Territory Economic Development Organisation, Professor Watt, talked about a $6 million to $10 million program for building this site, which would be within a 30-kilometre radius of Darwin. The rockets would take off eastwards in an equatorial orbit over the sea. Again, I want to emphasise that all appropriate measures will be considered, including an environmental impact statement.

I am pleased that the efforts of the Australian Space Office over the last few months, in consultation with the Australian company KITComm, have enabled us to get to this stage. When the actual development takes place is a matter for further discussion. Again, I emphasise that no Australian federal government money is required for this investment. However, we will continue to provide all advice that is appropriate. Again, this is another significant step forward in getting Australia a modest but reliable space program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that Jakab Industries in Tamworth is likely to lose a $30 million contract to supply civilian and army ambulances to the Malaysian ministries of health and defence? Will the government compensate Australian industry for losses resulting from Mr Keating's intemperate and ill-considered remarks against the Malaysian Prime Minister?

—I am not aware of that particular commercial case. But, of course, I am aware that a number of Australian businesses are concerned that if the situation with Malaysia further deteriorates, their commercial prospects may well be put at risk. That is something obviously of very great concern to the Australian government.

PARA.TAB: Our reaction, however, is as I have described it: we do not accept that the Prime Minister's original remarks were as have been described. Indeed, it will be recalled, I hope, by those from the other side who can bring a little honesty to bear in this debate that the initial reactions of Mr Peacock and Mr Fischer, both of whom publicly commented at the time, were very understanding of Mr Keating's remark and said as much at the time because they well knew the context, as I have described it today and as has been described before, in which Mr Keating made his remark.

We all want to avoid a situation where there will be problems of this kind arise with Australian industry, but it is a matter of doing what any country has to do—namely, maintain its own dignity and an appropriate sense of national self-interest in the way in which it responds to these situations. I believe and the government believes that the response that has been given by Mr Keating, in which he has made it absolutely clear that no offence was intended and that, if offence was taken, it is regretted, is an appropriate response under the circumstances and ought to be accepted by the Malaysian government in the spirit in which that response has been given.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The minister seemed to miss the question that was asked. He is aware, is he not, then, of AWA and its potential $40 million worth of contracts to Malaysia which may be lost? I ask him again: what are he and his department doing to assist specific Australian industries with contracts now in jeopardy as a result of those self-indulgent remarks of Mr Keating in Seattle?
—There is nothing I can usefully add to my earlier answer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. Can the minister advise the Senate of the progress of plans for the celebration of the United Nations International Year of the Family in 1994 and of what activities are planned for Australia next year?

—I am pleased to have the opportunity to say to Senator Hill that I might have missed prayers but I was coming in on a wing and a prayer to be here on time. I am sorry I missed the opening, but I was certainly determined to be here. I have just come back from the Australian launch today by the Prime Minister of the International Year of the Family celebrations, which are timed to correspond with the launch tomorrow in New York of the United Nations international family year.

PARA.TAB: The function today in Bankstown was a great success. It was a lovely occasion, attended by children from local schools, families and prominent Australians who will be supporting the year. There was music, dancing, poetry and Aboriginal dance theatre. The Bankstown Girls High School was there. It reflected the range and diversity of talent in families across Australia. The International Year of the Family will provide a unique opportunity for Australians to celebrate the diversity and vibrancy of Australian families. I think everyone here would acknowledge that families are the essence, backbone and strength of this nation and are a very powerful contributor to Australia's culture.

The federal government will be using the International Year of the Family to examine issues that are relevant to Australian families and, in particular, to develop the three main themes that have emerged: families and work; family harmony; and, in particular, families of the future. The federal government intends to make use of the International Year of the Family to make sure that programs and policies affecting the family not only actually reflect the needs of our community and our families now but also will be relevant to families of tomorrow. We are committed to supporting families and providing extended and increased opportunities for them.

One of the things that will emerge from the International Year of the Family is an Australian agenda for families. It will emerge after extensive consultation and discussion around Australia with the national council on the IYF in particular, but also with any number of people who are clearly interested in being involved with the year—all the way from corporate sponsors to prominent Australians and, indeed, just about every dimension or portfolio interest one could think of.

There is very large and lively interest from the corporate sector and also from people involved in the arts, television, media, storytelling and dance—the whole lot. There are prospects for a very fruitful year and, I would hope, one that will be as widely involving as possible of as many Australians as possible. There will be all sorts of activities. Early next year I will be launching a calendar of events to highlight not all, of course, but the large majority of the activities that will feature in the International Year of the Family. I look forward to celebrating and I sincerely hope that it is also the intention of the opposition to join in a large celebration around this country of all Australian families.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the recent application by Australian Defence Industries for approval to export 40,000 fragmentation grenades to Sri Lanka. Does the minister accept that fragmentation grenades are a lethal and indiscriminate weapon which could easily cause serious civilian casualties, especially if used in the booby trap role envisaged by ADI itself? Does the minister agree that the Sri Lankan government's human rights record is so bad as to place the exportation of fragmentation grenades to that country quite outside the defence export guidelines? Has ADI sought approval to export such grenades to any other countries? If so, which countries and have those applications been approved?
—A question without notice. How come you have the answer already?
—A pretty devastating interjection.

—It is par for the course. This matter has been in the press; the question is not entirely unreasonable. An application for approval in principle has been received for the export of 40,000 grenades, as Senator Bourne says, to Sri Lanka. The question of the approval for that export is a matter for my colleague the Minister for Defence to decide. In reaching a decision, he will consider the recommendations of the Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Exports on which the foreign affairs portfolio is represented. The minister has yet to make a decision on this issue and it is not to be presumed what the outcome of that process will be. As to the question of the capabilities of weapons of this kind, booby traps and so on, I think that is a question better addressed to the Minister for Defence.

PARA.TAB: As to the second part of the question about the Sri Lankan government's human rights record, I think it is fair to say that it is generally regarded as improving, notwithstanding the appalling circumstances which continue in that country with the war, in effect, in operation against the Tamil Tigers. The UN Human Rights Commission set out recommendations in 1991 regarding human rights abuses in Sri Lanka and how they might be redressed for the future. By and large, these have been accepted by the Sri Lankan government and action has been taken to initiate improvements.
As to the last question, which was about approval to other countries, that is a question better addressed to the Minister for Defence and I will refer that to him for an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I draw the minister's attention to the forthcoming decision of the High Court in what has become known as the duplicators' case. Could the minister advise the Senate what contingency arrangements might be put in place in conjunction with the states and territories should the High Court rule the current business franchise fees invalid?

—It is true that there is speculation as to the implications for state and territory finances should the High Court decision invalidate these business franchise fees to which Senator Chris Evans refers, and of course we will all know tomorrow.

PARA.TAB: Business franchise fees are an important element of the revenue base of all states and territories. They are worth, I understand, some $3 billion annually. Obviously, therefore, the Commonwealth has received representations from the states and territories and we have indicated that we are prepared to take immediate measures to provide interim safety net arrangements so that there is no disruption to their overall financial position.

In the short term, this will involve safety net arrangements based on adjusting existing wholesale sales tax and excise rates. In the longer term, I understand that the states and territories would like a system closer to their current arrangements. The Commonwealth is prepared to consider such an arrangement, but a major consideration will be that any tax levied on behalf of the states and territories should be readily distinguishable from existing Commonwealth taxes.

The Prime Minister has written to all premiers and chief ministers setting out the principles on which the Commonwealth will proceed in the development of these arrangements. We have emphasised, for example, that the rates of customs and excise and wholesale sales tax would be increased with the aim of raising an amount sufficient to ensure that each state and territory would receive at least what it would have collected from existing business franchise fees without requiring revenue raised in one state or territory to be returned to another, which I think people would accept is a necessary principle. This would mean, though, that most states and territories would receive increased revenue and would be required to return such additional amounts to taxpayers generally within their borders.

Let me be quite clear, therefore, about what this means: not one red cent extra will be retained by the Commonwealth. So let us put down all the furphies about tax grab: none extra will be accepted by the Commonwealth. Neither will those states and territories—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that l-a-w law?
—Why does not Senator Campbell wander off and ask his state government whether it thinks this is a good idea?
—Are you sure ours will?
—Senator Boswell is quite wrong because we will not do it unless all the states and territories ask us to.
—What he is saying is that nobody believes you because you are a member of the Labor Party.

—Fortunately, nobody listens to Senator Macdonald. Neither will those states and territories enjoy a windfall. They will not be allowed to pocket those funds. They will be required to return any such windfall to their citizens. It is a matter for them to determine the best way of achieving this outcome. If people do not like it, the democratic processes of those states will be the processes by which that will be addressed.

PARA.TAB: But it has been very strange to see that both the current shadow Treasurer and the former shadow Treasurer have been at pains to find some sort of ulterior motive in this, when we will only proceed if all the states and territories indicate that they wish us to and we will act in accordance with their requests only. The shadow Treasurer has seen the announcements as a $1 billion tax grab when, in fact, the Commonwealth will require that the states and territories return any windfall to their citizens.

The revenue will go to the states and territories. If people want to argue that it will not be returned, they need to go and talk to the governments of those states and territories and see if they share that view. I am advised that they do not; they accept that there is no alternative to this mechanism for proceeding and that it is the appropriate basis, because we have to have a uniform rate—the constitution requires that—and that the appropriate mechanism for returning the funds to the citizens is via the states.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I want to know whether the minister has seen Mr Reith's comments, reported in the Canberra Times, and whether the government is considering his suggested option as an option for the government to pursue.
—It is hardly a supplementary.

—It is on exactly the same matter, and I welcome the question and the opportunity to respond. The former shadow Treasurer seems to be extremely confused. He finds it objectionable that the Commonwealth collect these taxes on behalf of the states and at their request when no-one thinks there is an alternative.

PARA.TAB: He seems to be suffering from a very short-term memory lapse; in other words, he cannot remember what he said on the same page. At one point on the page he said that it would mean that the Commonwealth would collect more taxes and the states would lose taxes; then 200 words later, he advocated that there should be changes to the arrangements for income tax collected on behalf of the states by the Commonwealth—exactly the same issue within 200 words. Pardon me, the memory lapse is getting worse. The fevered leadership speculation, I am afraid, is going to his judgment. There may be some other explanation for his irrationality, but it seems to me that is an extraordinary error of judgment. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to Mr Keating's advice to Aboriginal negotiators to `knock down everybody in your way' to get the Native Title Bill through the parliament. How can the people of Australia be expected to take the Prime Minister's rhetoric on reconciliation seriously when he makes this sort of statement which urges division and confrontation—a statement which has been described by respected Aboriginal leader Charles Perkins as sounding like an incitement to physical conflict and `the worst thing he has heard a politician say'?
—It is definitely not the worst thing Charlie Perkins has ever said.
—Charlie Perkins himself is responsible for a few sallies in the past that I can recall that make the Prime Minister's on this occasion seem positively tame by comparison.

PARA.TAB: The point that the Prime Minister is making is simply this: the Native Title Bill itself has been the product of an extraordinarily protracted consultative process and represents the closest thing to consensus we are ever likely to achieve on a piece of legislation as sensitive as this, as difficult as this, as far reaching as this in this country. It does attempt to strike a balance between the principles, on the one hand, of justice for Aboriginal people and, on the other hand, recognition of the reality of land management issues and the economic interests and needs of this country.

It is a process of consultation which has produced, as I say, a consensus piece of legislation, to the extent that consensus is ever achievable in a piece of legislation of this kind. Under those circumstances, Mr Keating is simply making the point, in his usual graphic and effective way, that it is very much in the interests of the nation and very much in the interests of the Aboriginal people themselves, whose leadership he was addressing and whose leadership is absolutely committed to this legislation, to ensure that by any appropriate means it is passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How does the Prime Minister seriously expect to achieve a genuine reconciliation with Australian Aborigines when the success of his Native Title Bill depends on steamrolling over anyone with an alternative opinion, including that of many Aboriginal people?

—He might not achieve a reconciliation with Charlie Perkins, but that has been beyond a lot of us in our lifetimes and is likely, I fear, to remain so. The object is to reach as much of a sense of commitment to this legislation as we possibly can. The process by which this legislation has been drafted and brought to fruition, we believe, is such as to very much encourage that spirit of reconciliation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer to the minister's announcement yesterday of the sale of Hollywood Repatriation General Hospital in Perth to the Ramsay Health Care Group. How will the minister ensure that the veteran community in Western Australia will continue to receive high quality health care?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I made what I believe is an historic announcement for the veteran community of Western Australia. I was able to tell them that Ramsay Health Care Pty Ltd, an Australian owned and operated company, has been selected to take over Hollywood Repatriation General Hospital early next year. This means that the future of Hollywood hospital is guaranteed. I am able to assure the veteran community of Western Australia today that its access to Hollywood is absolutely guaranteed as a condition of sale.

PARA.TAB: The federal government will pay $500 million over the next 10 years to purchase treatment for entitled veterans and war widows which will guarantee their health care into the next century. They will continue to have access to Hollywood for its full range of excellent treatment services without having to obtain authority first from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. In fact, the new Hollywood private hospital will not only retain its existing services but also enhance them by expanding Hollywood's present links with the University of Western Australia medical school.

The aim is to set new standards and make Hollywood the nation's leading private hospital with teaching status. Links in orthopaedic surgery, general medicine, general surgery and neurological surgery will be extended to include a number of other important areas. In addition, Ramsay Health Care plans a $20 million building and refurbishment program which will be implemented progressively. Major constructions will include a 150-bed block, an independent 40-bed psychiatric facility, four new operating theatres, and a new day surgery centre. A large medical centre, with up to 50 consulting rooms and practice suites, will be built and the outpatient clinic area will be redesigned. Ramsay has also guaranteed that it will maintain the aged and extended care department, the special psychiatric facility, the palliative care unit and the chapel.

I am pleased to say that on the same day in February that Ramsay Health Care takes over Hollywood, Western Australia's 30,000 entitled veterans and war widows will gain access to the repatriation private patient scheme, which will provide the wider options for local treatment that they particularly need as they grow older. Under this scheme they would be able to go to Hollywood or to their local public hospital as private patients in shared accommodation without the need for their doctor to contact the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The repatriation private patients scheme will also make it easier for them to gain access to local specialists.

I emphasise that the federal government, through the Repatriation Commission and the Department of Veterans' Affairs, will continue to be responsible for the repatriation health care of veterans and war widows.The new health care arrangements will be closely monitored by the Western Australian treatment monitoring committee, which is made up of representatives of ex-service organisations.

I also want to place on record the government's deep appreciation of the crucial role played by the ex-service organisations in the consultative process leading up to yesterday's announcement. Not only did they make an enormous contribution to the developing of Hollywood's role, but also they acted at all times to ensure that the interests of the veteran community came first. Through the contract with Ramsay and the introduction of the repatriation private patients scheme, I am confident that this is a very good result for all Western Australian entitled beneficiaries, the veterans and war widows.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Science and Small Business

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to universal condemnation over the weekend by the science community of the performance of the science minister, Senator Schacht. Do the government and the Prime Minister now accept that the minister's refusal to consult and his abrasive and confrontationist style are thoroughly inappropriate in this sensitive policy area and have only succeeded in alienating large sections of the science community? If the Prime Minister cannot bring himself to be conciliatory towards Malaysia, will he at least apologise to the long-suffering science community by removing Senator Schacht before he does any more harm?

—The opposition honestly ought to be able to do a bit better than that. Obviously, there has been some controversy and some difficulty in particular aspects of that portfolio, but Senator Schacht as the minister responsible has the full confidence of the government, the full confidence of the Prime Minister and the full confidence of the cabinet. In fact, the decisions that were taken fully reflect the government's commitment to the course of action which Senator Schacht has recommended to us. It is a nonsense question and it does not deserve to be taken with any degree of seriousness at all.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister disagree with Professor Collins that the Prime Minister has got to understand that he has a major political liability on his hands and he has got to put a stop to it? Is the minister also concerned that Professor Collins's criticisms are shared by people like the BHP chief executive, Russell Fynmore; CRA technology chief, John Innes; and the president of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering, Sir Rupert Myers?
—I would not disagree with what Professor Collins had to say about me, but he cannot get it right all the time.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Will the minister release the Attorney-General's advice concluding that native title over Beecroft Peninsula at Jervis Bay has been extinguished and that compensation may be payable? How does the minister justify asking cabinet to pre-empt the outcome of a future native title claim by the Jerringa community by endorsing his submission which will virtually guarantee that the East Coast Armaments Complex is built at Jervis Bay? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the first part of Senator Woodley's question, as to whether the advice from the Attorney-General can be made available, I will have to refer that to the Minister for Defence, who can respond at a later stage. In relation to the other parts of the question that Senator Woodley raised, I think, as Senator Ray informed Senator Woodley in this chamber earlier in November, cabinet will be shortly considering a submission on the east coast armaments complex. A claim made to the federal minister for aboriginal affairs in December 1989 over the whole of the peninsula, excluding the village of Currarong, was not supported because the Commonwealth-owned lands on the peninsula are held under freehold title. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. In light of the previous minister's election promise to private child-care centres that `no service will need or be required to put on new staff, increase qualified staff, buy new equipment or in any other way incur costs because of accreditation', how can the minister justify to the parents of Australia the extra staff costs and other costs that accompany her accreditation program? Can the minister give a guarantee that the 1992 costing of 88c a week per child is comprehensive and accurate, given it was based on a different handbook from that currently before the Senate; that it was drawn from an unaudited seven-week pilot study of 1.4 per cent of child-care centres; and that it is dramatically different from the private child-care industry's independent costing of $30 to $69 per week?

—The other night I addressed in Melbourne a very large meeting of parents and providers of child care who were predominantly from the private child-care centre in Victoria. One of the people who asked a question was an accountant who said that he had done a lot of accountancy work for child care and that he had examined the cost of child care. He had found figures of $40 to $60, but the average was $44, sometimes $30 and sometimes $13. He wanted to know how I could say 88c. My view is that, if he were examining the costs in a child-care centre and could get a variation of from $13 to $60 on his own figures, there was quite clearly some room for discussion about what exactly was being included in the figures.

PARA.TAB: I was able to provide him with the evidence from a child-care centre in South Australia, which has not had any requirement to do the accreditation process but which was so interested to know about it that it immediately sought the guidelines, once they were tabled, and has taken itself through the accreditation process. The parents and participants found it a very constructive exercise and their best costing was 55c.

The figure of 88c that I gave is from a private consultant. It was a result of a survey. There is considerable disagreement with the figure by the private accountants in their own industry. What I said then was that the accountant might like to provide the department with some of the figures that he has so that collectively we could see whether there are what obviously seem to be clear discrepancies between what is being included in the costing.

On the evidence that I have and on the continuing evidence, the structure is designed to keep the costing minimal. I believe those figures of the private consultant—being an independent audit of the process when done and being confirmed by a recent case of one in South Australia, which I believe one should be cautious—

TALK.START.PARA: —A case of one!

—I am saying that one should be cautious, of course, but it is a figure that is not wildly out of step with the private consultant's figures. I say again that I believe the private sector people are including things in the costings that are not properly evaluated or described. So I can only confirm that the government's private consultant fees give me no reason to wonder about those figures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. There are significant differences between the two books. Principle 51 in the current book specifically states:

QUESTION.PARA: Where several staff members work together, each of them should care particularly for an agreed group of children, so that each child receives consistent care from only one or two staff members.

Previously, the piloting study had this restriction for infants only. Does the minister not agree that applying such staffing restrictions to all children, regardless of age, places a greater staffing cost on child-care centres?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to hear Senator Boswell float that out. Quite clearly, the concern the private child-care centres have relates to staffing arrangements. Staffing arrangements are a matter of the state, not of these accreditations. It has always been understood that way. The number of staff per child is a matter of state regulations and those regulations are set by the states; they are not proposed to be changed by the accreditation, which does not address staffing. The private child-care sector and the opposition must appreciate that the staffing arrangements are not included in these figures to any large extent. The relief staff for the accreditation process is incorporated but the staffing arrangement Senator Boswell is talking to is a matter for states and properly does not belong in the accreditation figuring.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to recent reports of piracy attacks on merchant ships and the concern expressed by the Australian shipping industry. Can the minister advise of action being taken at the national and international level aimed at addressing this threat to seafarers' lives and the marine environment?

—There have been a number of major articles in the last two days referring to, unfortunately, the continuing problems that piracy is causing the shipping industry, particularly now with the adoption of far more advanced forms of attack on merchant shipping which involve both automatic weapons and explosives. These attacks not only involve a threat to the safety of the ship's crew but also a serious threat to the risk of collision or pollution if the ship is then left disabled with no crew in control. This is a major international problem requiring cooperation between nations to coordinate efforts in regions where there is a relatively high level of pirate activity.

PARA.TAB: Australia strongly supports action that is currently being taken by the United Nations International Maritime Organisation to deal with the problem. Since the early 1980s the IMO has received over 400 reports of piracy and armed robbery against ships, with almost half of that number occurring in the last three years. So, clearly, this is a problem which is escalating. The IMO believes that the actual total is considerably higher than this.

Unfortunately for Australia, our major trading routes coincide with some of the main danger areas in the world for piracy. Five Australian ships have been attacked by pirates in these areas. In January this year the IMO convened a special working group on piracy in the South-East Asian region, comprising experts from seven member countries including Australia. This group travelled to the Malacca-Singapore straits area in March this year and received full cooperation from these coastal states. This resulted in action by local authorities, which has seen a substantial improvement in shipping security in this region in the last few months.

The report of the IMO working group has been widely distributed. It recommended a comprehensive range of procedures and measures that can be taken by ships and crews to protect themselves from piracy. These include: development by ships of an action plan to combat piracy, including heightened surveillance, better lighting on board the ships, securing and regularly inspecting the key access doors of the ships, and detection equipment, such as the provision of an additional stern radar to warn of approaching small craft.

In September this year, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority issued a marine notice for Australian shipping that was based on these recommendations. The main thrust of the anti-piracy measures taken so far by the international community has been in the form of advice to shipowners on measures that can be taken when transiting the high risk areas and recommendations to coastal states in the areas of known pirate activity.

In addition, Australian naval vessels are provided daily with information concerning the location of Australian vessels and they are able to offer humanitarian assistance to any vessel in distress, including a ship which is under attack. This applies both on the high seas and in another country's territorial waters, with the limitation that Australian vessels may not pursue or capture the offenders. Australia will continue to cooperate with countries in the region and with the wider international community in efforts to combat this serious threat to our international trading fleet.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Is the government aware of numerous complaints from community-based Landcare groups regarding the substantial delays in receipt of their funding as a result of a directive from Minister Kelly that the funds are only to be made available through sitting Labor members in their electorates? Is the government also aware that the delays caused by the minister's politically based directive are threatening the ability of Landcare groups to undertake their projects because of the seasonal nature of these projects? Why has Minister Kelly seen fit to politicise $7 million in Landcare funding at the expense of the environment? Finally, what is the limit to which Minister Kelly—the minister for playing favourites—is prepared to go in using taxpayers' funds to promote the political ambitions of the Labor Party?

—I did look up my briefing folder from Mrs Kelly, despite the very prejudiced way in which that question was asked. I do not think Senator Calvert would be surprised to know that I do not have a briefing on the smearing way in which he asked the question about the operation of the Landcare program. So I am not surprised that I do not have any briefing with me. However, I will refer the question to Mrs Kelly for a response and I will bring it back to the Senate as soon as I can. When I do so, it will be a factual response; it will not be a response based on the honourable senator's political innuendo.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. Earlier this year the Prime Minister's Science and Engineering Council received a report entitled The Role of Intellectual Property in Innovation. I understand that the government has considered and responded to the recommendations contained in the report. Can the minister inform the Senate of the government's response to the report? What are the implications for the commercialisation of research and development and the transfer of technology?

—The Prime Minister's Science and Engineering Council received a report a few months ago on the role of intellectual property in innovation. This was a response from particularly the industries concerned that we get the maximum advantage from the development of science R&D in Australia by protecting it internationally as well as nationally in the intellectual property area. As a result of those recommendations to PMSEC, the government established an IDC and has responded. Two weeks ago I was able to announce that the government has endorsed the need to raise the profile of intellectual property and will undertake programs increasing the awareness and understanding of intellectual property issues throughout the business sector and higher education research institutions.

PARA.TAB: The PMSEC report estimated that, in world markets, intellectual property supports $600 billion worth of industrial products and processes annually. What must be emphasised in the Australian context is that, as our manufacturing exports grow, our international competitiveness will be underpinned by our ability to obtain protection for intellectual property.

The government's response to the report will, firstly, raise awareness of the importance of intellectual property and its protection; secondly, help to build stronger intellectual property systems in our region; and, thirdly, serve to make the Australian intellectual property system more accessible to firms and research groups. On behalf of the government, I would certainly like to place on record our appreciation of the efforts of the working group that reported to PMSEC, upon which the government has taken these decisions to enhance the intellectual property system in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. What planning has the Department of Defence done against the range of contingencies that will arise if the North Korean government persists in not cooperating with the provisions of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty? Can the minister assure the Senate that Australia will support the United Nations in any military action that the United Nations deems necessary in relation to this issue?

—Mr Deputy President, this is more appropriately a matter for the portfolio of foreign affairs than for defence at this stage, although, if it did come to a question of involvement in military action, obviously defence would be involved.

PARA.TAB: Our belief at the moment is that this rather delicate situation in North Korea is capable of resolution through the process of negotiation, bilaterally between the United States and North Korea, trilaterally with South Korea as well, and also through the processes of the International Atomic Energy Agency and the disciplines that are being exercised there.

It is premature to be making any pessimistic evaluations at this stage about where this process is going, although a number of pessimistic scenarios have been around since this became an issue some time ago. In the event that non-compliance seems inevitable with the IAEA processes, the next step would be to refer the matter to the security council of the UN. But there are many steps to go through before it gets to that stage, and there are a great many steps to contemplate before one would have to deal with the possibility of the security council in turn recommending some more decisive military action. I simply do not want to speculate about that at this stage. I do not think any government in the world would want to at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I intentionally did not ask this question of the Minister for Foreign Affairs because I did not want any of the flim-flam and delusions that pass for assessments that come out of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The specific question is: has any planning been done by the Department of Defence against the contingencies if the worst case arises and North Korea does not cooperate with the United States and the United Nations? This is a matter in which Australia has a vital interest, because we would inevitably be involved in it in some way or another. We have certainly shown an interest in supporting the United Nations in the past in guaranteeing some sort of actions in the Korean peninsula. For those reasons, I am a little disappointed that the foreign minister prated in on this. I ask Senator Faulkner whether he will take it up with the Department of Defence and find out whether it has looked at the situation at all.
—Order! The supplementary question has to be directed to Senator Gareth Evans.

—I will see what the defence minister might wish to say on that subject. I believe that it would be premature for any such contingency planning to occur, for all the reasons that I mentioned before. I deeply regret that Senator MacGibbon chose to describe my honest contribution to the debate as flim-flam. I did not think I was usually guilty of that. I am very distressed that he used that description on this occasion.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I note the recent opening of the last section of the F3 freeway between Newcastle and Sydney. How much of the funding for this road was from federal government sources? Will there be any benefits from this road to areas other than Newcastle?
—Oh, come off it! Of course there will be benefits.

—I hope that Senator Tierney is not too offended by that outburst from his colleague Senator Panizza. I am pleased to say that Senator Tierney was in attendance at the opening of this extremely important transport link.
—In the front row?

—He was in the front row and I was pleased to see him there. Last Wednesday the New South Wales transport minister and I officially opened the last connecting section of the F3 freeway from Sydney to Newcastle. This section covers the last 19-kilometre stretch between Freemans Waterhole and Minmi, plus an extremely important seven-kilometre dual carriageway link to Wallsend. That is the Newcastle connector link.

PARA.TAB: Originally, that link was not due to be completed for another two years, but it was fast tracked in order to coincide with the opening of this magnificent new freeway, and magnificent it is scenically as well as technically, as I am sure Senator Tierney would agree. The connector link will maximise the benefits to Newcastle of the additional significant tourist potential that this freeway will create for the Hunter region.

The total cost of the highway extension is $225 million, with an additional $15 million for the approach roads to the north. As part of the national highway system it was fully funded by the federal government. The new freeway is estimated to provide a 15-minute time saving on the trip from Sydney to Newcastle. More importantly, it provides drivers on that route with the assurance of a safer and more convenient trip. The freeway also provides better access from Sydney to the Hunter region, which will add to its tourist potential and encourage greater interaction between industries in the central coast regions of New South Wales. The freeway construction—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait until Christmas and see what happens.

—That is not what Senator Tierney told me he would say in the Senate this week. That is extremely ungracious of him. The freeway construction involved a massive engineering task through extremely difficult terrain and it has resulted in a world class road. This included the construction of 23 bridges and the movement of over seven million cubic metres of earth and also the inadvertent mining of 25,000 tonnes of coal which was exported.

PARA.TAB: In driving along that road, I noticed how extraordinarily quiet the drive was. This is the highest standard of pavement construction that I have seen. Engineers present at the site say that it is the best they have seen anywhere in the world. The reason I mention this is that it is an absolute textbook example of the excellence of Australian construction and, I might add, world class standards of Australian construction at world competitive prices.

I know that the Abigroup and Leighton Constructions that built the road are actively tendering for international projects in our region and this road would certainly act as a very good advertisement for the excellence of their work. Our expertise in road building, particularly in difficult terrain and in tropical climates, is currently being sought by a variety of rapidly developing nations throughout the Asian region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans, to questions without notice asked by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) and Senator Brownhill this day, relating to relations between Australia and Malaysia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans's response to those two questions, which pointed out that the Malaysian crisis was brought about simply by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) gratuitously offending the Prime Minister of Malaysia, needs to be addressed. Senator Evans said that it was in nobody's interest for the problem to escalate. I think everybody would agree with that. He also said that there was a need to avoid the potential to damage our commercial relationship with Malaysia. That commercial damage has already occurred. It is no good pretending otherwise.

PARA.TAB: In last Friday's Australian there was a letter written by five people in Melbourne. They said that the attack on Dr Mahathir was a totally unnecessary threat to the growth of trade between our two countries. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: It demonstrated a misreading of Malaysian cultural sensitivities. To quote two recent conversations we have had:
It continues:
If the issue is not resolved, we might as well pack our bags and go home.
This statement was made by an Australian co-venture in Malaysia. A British company based in Kuala Lumpur said:
If the conflict continues, it will set Australia back several years in Malaysia.

That has already occurred. I would like to quote from a letter received by a Queensland joint venturer involved in a major project in Kuala Lumpur which was of such magnitude that it required the consent of the Malaysian government. In a very polite letter to the Queensland venturer, the Malaysian counterpart said:
We refer to our recent discussion on the subject matter—
being the major project in Kuala Lumpur—
wherein regrettably we have to direct you not to commence with any Conceptual Layout works as we are particularly concerned that this presentation—
being directed to the Malaysian government—

we . . . cannot afford any downside risks on our presentation being done up by an Australian . . . firm in view of the latest "sensitivities" created by "uncalled for" and inappropriate remarks uttered by Mr Paul Keating.
It goes on to say:
You would certainly appreciate that we took the trouble to invite—
And it names the two people concerned—
for this particular project and dearly love to work closely with them on same if not for this unfortunate incident.
It concluded:
We seek your understanding on this matter and apologise for any inconvenience caused.
That is only the tip of the iceberg as far as the damage caused not by the government but by one man, the Prime Minister of this country, is concerned.

PARA.TAB: Senator Gareth Evans made some remarks to try to excuse the Prime Minister but I think Senator Evans's response has probably added to the problem because he pointed out that the Prime Minister, in making this gratuitous insult, did not know what the word `recalcitrant' meant to the Malaysians. Senator Evans pointed out that it meant ill-educated and reflected on the family and background. Having learnt that, surely it is up to the Prime Minister to do something about it.

It is all very well for me to criticise without giving some sort of positive response and the best response that I think can be given is the one that was offered by Dr Hewson. Dr Hewson asked—and not only did he ask on his own behalf but he also asked on behalf of every Australian group doing business with Malaysia today—what would stop the Prime Minister of this country, who made the remark, picking up the phone and talking to the Prime Minister of Malaysia to sort the problem out? That is a fairly simple solution. What is wrong with a one-to-one conversation between Mr Paul Keating and the Prime Minister of Malaysia?

There is no doubt that this matter has got out of hand. There is no doubt that millions of dollars of exports in this country have been put at risk in not only products but also the service industry—and examples have been given by Senator Hill, Senator Brownhill and a host of others as well as to the damage that has been done to our international relations, particularly our relations with Malaysia.

The Prime Minister of this country has a reputation for gutter language and he gets away with it here because the population has been desensitised to it. But to use it on the international scene has caused this problem and he himself is responsible—nobody else. If he was the one who was taking the blame, I do not think we would worry, but the adverse effects this is having on business, employment and our export trade with that country cannot be tolerated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to take note of Senator Gareth Evans's answers to questions from me and Senator Hill. Senator Evans keeps telling us that Malaysia should accept a non-apology, but why did the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) have the stupidity to make such an inflammatory remark in the first place? Last week at the export awards dinner the Prime Minister waxed lyrical on what we were achieving with our exports and with one stupid intemperate remark he brings it down. In answer to my question Senator Evans said:

PARA.TAB: We all want to avoid a situation where there will be problems of this kind arise with Australian industry, but it is a matter of doing what any country has to do—namely, maintain its own dignity and an appropriate sense of national self-interest in the way in which it responds to these situations.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask again: why could we not do something to fix up the problems associated with some of the industries that I mentioned?

PARA.TAB: For the minister's interest, I will talk a little about Jakab Industries. It is a local engineering company which has exported to various countries over the last seven to eight years. For the last three to four years it has been working hard with Malaysia on the present contract to supply ambulances and the Prime Minister, with one stupid remark, knocks it out the window.

Negotiations are at the stage where the company is expecting a phone call or communication from Malaysia to give the go-ahead. Things have gone quiet. The manager said, `They have gone very quiet'. This order, worth $30 million, was the largest order this company had ever had. It has had some success in placing vehicles into Asia. Its last big order was 40 vehicles into Japan. This contract into Malaysia to provide civilian and army ambulances would have been the icing on the cake for this local Tamworth company which just this week celebrated 30 years in business. So it is a real kick in the guts, a real kick in the head, to this company, and it is a real disincentive for people in Australian industries to do something.

The minister also said that he did not know anything about AWA. Of course, AWA has quite a lot to say about this situation. It stands to lose some $40 million. It is part of the $3 billion frigate contract tendered to the Sydney company Transfield. It was expecting to be a key supplier to that contract. Malaysia is currently AWA's third biggest export destination, accounting for more than $6 million of the company's $69 million of total exports.

Ten per cent of this company's exports are going down the drain because a very stupid remark was made by a Prime Minister who did not understand what happens outside the chamber. It is very easy to talk about things in the chamber, to throw mud and sling rubbish at people, but, as Senator Gareth Evans knows—he has been the Minister for Foreign Affairs for long enough now to know—one has to have a little bit of decorum when dealing in international affairs. And one stupid remark has put those companies in a great deal of jeopardy.

I believe, as Senator Parer does, that the Prime Minister should swallow a little bit of pride and actually ring up and talk face to face, so to speak, with the Prime Minister of Malaysia and make sure that these companies, which will suffer if something is not done about it, will actually have the chance to meet those contracts. I condemn the Prime Minister for his comments. I also condemn the government for not even thinking of the damage it is doing to Australian companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —In history we can look back upon some great statesmen. One would remember when Kennedy used to telephone Kruschev and when Bush used to telephone Gorbachev and Yeltsin. Yet here we have a position in which our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) will not even get on the phone and talk to his counterpart in Malaysia for the good of Australia. Surely the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), who has spent a lot of time in Malaysia and Asia and has worked very hard on relationships there, could get on his telephone and talk to his counterpart and try to mend this dangerous rift.

PARA.TAB: Unlike what the minister said on 25 November—that the relationship was unlikely to be blown off course by cross-winds of this kind—it would seem that it has been blown off course. When I note that in my own state of Tasmania 300 university students from Malaysia are likely to be largely affected, and when we see the damage that this will do to education not only in Tasmania but right around Australia, we see that it is a very serious matter. In fact, Malaysian students make up the bulk of overseas students in Tasmania.

I remember very well that on a delegation on which I accompanied Senator McMullan back in 1987 we spent a lot of time talking to Malaysian universities trying to encourage them to become part of the arrangements with Australia and use our education system. I believe that all up it will cost Australia something like $9 million in lost revenue if these boycotts that have been imposed by Malaysia on its students go ahead. It is a very serious matter. I hope that at least the foreign minister, through his relations with his counterparts in Malaysia, will work very hard to try to get this back on track.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add to what my colleagues have said with regard to the answers given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) to the questions asked by Senators Hill and Brownhill.

PARA.TAB: Australian service industries have been active in recent years in endeavouring to sell their services in South-East Asia, and Malaysia has been a very willing buyer of Australian services. I can quote actual instances of the sale of engineering services to Malaysia being put at risk by the action of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I quote from two letters written by the Chairman of Electricity Supply Association of Australia Limited, Mr Graeme Longbottom—one to the Minister for Trade (Senator Cook) and another to the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr). The letter to Mr Kerr states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The impact of the Prime Minister's statement has been immediate and damaging to prospects of multi-billion dollar projects for the Australian Electricity Supply Industry in Malaysia and other Asian countries.
The letter to Senator Cook states:
These projects, along with many others involving Australian interests, have been placed on indefinite hold as of 24 November 1993. Also put on hold are contracts that have already been signed.

The industry was affected by previous disputes with Malaysia and the `buy Australian last' policy of several years ago where contracts and awards were cancelled and negotiations protracted and finally abandoned. The letter to Mr Kerr also states:
In Tasmania's case the Hydro-electric Commission Enterprises Corporation-
that is the commercial arm of the HEC—

is extremely active in Malaysia and recently established a subsidiary company in Kuala Lumpur. HECEC believes that at least $1.5 billion of contracts, it hoped to secure in conjunction with others, have been jeopardised by the Prime Minister's comments.

These comments are from letters that the ESAA sent to the Minister for Trade and the Minister for Justice. These are very serious matters. As my colleagues have suggested, I think phone calls are urgently required to fix this matter up and to get Australian business sold in Malaysia again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to take note of the answers given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans). My colleagues have mentioned some of the larger businesses, but I was contacted at the end of last week by one small business which is located fairly close to my office and with which I have had association. It said that some exports it has been sending to Malaysia are in jeopardy because of the comments that have been made. In fact, the business will be dealt a $400,000 blow this year and possibly a $500,000 to $1 million blow in the following year.

PARA.TAB: It said that it was negotiating some informal arrangements with the Malaysian authorities regarding some regulations for the importation of its product, that those had been progressing very satisfactorily but that they had gone quite cold. It is not only the big businesses at risk but also the smaller businesses, like the one that contacted me. In fact, it said that some five to 10 jobs in that business would be in jeopardy as a result of this.

On behalf of that business, I ask that the government address this issue with urgency because smaller business as well as larger ones are suffering as a result of the rather ill-informed and somewhat off-the-cuff comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last couple of years, the Northern Territory has developed very special relationships with many South-East Asian countries, particularly Malaysia. In fact, the Northern Territory government has recently created a ministry for Asian relations. I am certainly aware that Mr Stone's activities have been of a very high order in Sabah, Sarawak and a number of other Malaysian states.

PARA.TAB: It is important that the activities of the Northern Territory University, which is drawing on the student base of Malaysia, are not in any way interfered with. I am fearful that the intemperate expressions of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) will have an effect. This in turn would flow through to good trade arrangements and the educational systems that are building up.

It is also important to note that in the August budget the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, created a new special committee, entitled the Wran committee, to look at and develop very special arrangements between agencies and departments of the federal government and the countries of Asia.

I hope we will see that this present situation is nothing more than a hiccup and, in fact, that Mr Wran and his colleagues on that committee will not have to spend much of their valuable time undoing the damage which has been done and devising new systems to replace those which have been damaged by the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is entirely reasonable for honourable senators to be expressing concern on behalf of various of their business constituents about the possible implications for them of this contretemps continuing. I am aware of some of the particular cases that have been mentioned—for example, the HEC one—on the basis of personal correspondence that I have received or at least caught up with since I have been back from overseas. I am certainly aware that there are potentially very large adverse consequences, should the situation, as I say, further deteriorate.

PARA.TAB: All I can say under those circumstances is that we will do our best to try to resolve the issue. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made a considered, deliberate and careful effort to do so last week with his letter, making clear that it was not a calculated intention to offend; and he made it further clear over the weekend that, if it had that effect, then he regretted it. So the language has been used which one hopes will prove to have some effect, particularly if, as I said today, we can go through some cooling off process and some slightly more systematic attempt on each side to understand what the other has, in fact, been saying in the context in which it has been said.

I have been invited to talk to my counterpart; I propose to do so, if it proves possible. I know my foreign ministerial colleague very well. We have been working together for a long time now and I do want to explore what the options are to try to resolve this in a more satisfactory way. But it is a matter of judgment in each case as to what is likely to be productive and what the nature of the relationships are. I can assure those opposite that it is a matter of the highest priority for me to try to see if we can find a way through this which is both principled and sensible in practice.

I do not have any problem with the concern that has been expressed. It is not unreasonable for concern to be expressed; I share the concern. What I do have a problem with though, I have to say, are the recurring references to the Prime Minister and his `intemperate', `ill-judged' remarks, or whatever other adjective appealed most to the particular senators in question when they embarked upon their contributions to the debate.

I think they all have rather forgotten, have they not, that their own leadership and their own shadow foreign minister, Mr Peacock, in particular, made very clear at the outset, when those remarks were first made by Mr Keating, that—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the expert. You are supposed to be advising the Prime Minister.

—I would not want those opposite to take the view that Mr Peacock was not an expert in these matters; I mean, he has had ample experience and can make a judgment. But each of the main leaders of the opposition parties, Mr Peacock and Mr Fischer—and subsequently, I think, Dr Hewson himself—made clear that they did understand the circumstances in which Mr Keating made his remarks and were not disposed to make a political issue of them.

PARA.TAB: I refer, for example, to the Age report on 23 November—and I have not heard this denied by Mr Peacock or anyone else—and I quote the relevant portions, the first of which states:

The shadow foreign minister, Mr Peacock, said he could easily make capital from Mr Keating's statements, but in view of Dr Mahathir's attitude leading up to the APEC meeting, the remarks were understandable.

SPEECH.PARA: A little later on in the same article, it is stated:

PARA.TAB: A spokeswomen for Mr Peacock said later that Mr Peacock also understood Mr Keating's frustrations with Dr Mahathir and knew "that straight talking is sometimes a good thing".

SPEECH.PARA: Still later in the same article, it is stated:

PARA.TAB: A spokesman for the National Party leader, Mr Fischer, also supported Mr Keating-

TALK.START.PARA: —Peacock put out a release later.

—Yes, it is true that a few days later there were retractions galore on the opposition side. For example, on 29 November—and there are similar press releases from others on the opposition side—Dr Hewson said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the time of Mr Keating's comments in Seattle, the Opposition—in the national interest—did not seek to make the situation any more difficult than it otherwise was.
But the matter has now clearly moved on.

Away they went, and they have been fiercely critical ever since. The only thing that has moved on in this situation is the political breeze as it is perceived by members of the opposition. They think there is an opportunity to make some political capital out of this and have been doing so with totally hypocritical indignation ever since. If it was understandable for those remarks to be made in the opinion and judgment of opposition spokesmen, some of whom, certainly in the case of Mr Peacock, are amply experienced in this matter, then it should remain understandable in the context in which those remarks were made. What we have to try to do, however, is to ensure in a non-partisan, cool atmosphere that this issue is resolved as quickly as we can. I hope that we would have support rather than criticism from the opposition in that endeavour.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
