TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), to a question without notice asked by Senator Christopher Evans this day, relating to the High Court's forthcoming decision on State business franchise fees.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier today Senator McMullan, in responding to a question from Senator Chris Evans in reference to tomorrow's expected High Court decision in the so-called Capital Distributors case, attempted amongst other things to point to what he saw as an inconsistency in remarks that had been made in the last day or so by my colleague in the other place Mr Peter Reith in his statements about the matter.

PARA.TAB: Several points need to be made in relation to the situation that the Commonwealth may find itself in tomorrow if, as seems likely and as is expected, the High Court finds that the states can no longer collect more than $3 billion in franchise fees. If that is the outcome of tomorrow's case, then that will obviously play very much into the hands of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who, as we know, is the most centralist prime minister that this nation has ever had. He is a prime minister who has no regard whatsoever for the rights of the states, either those rights that the states have been given under the Constitution or otherwise through convention.

What concerns me, therefore, is that in the hearings before the High Court earlier this year the Commonwealth Solicitor-General informed the court on 20 April this year that if the states' powers to impose business franchise fees were overturned, then the Commonwealth would impose new taxes in their place. In other words, we would have a reduction in taxes collected by the states because of the High Court decision against the collection any longer of franchise fees. But, `Not to worry, states', says the Solicitor-General to the High Court, `because the Commonwealth will impose new taxes in their place'. That is a fairly extraordinary proposition to put, in my view. It is certainly highly inappropriate for a Solicitor-General to put to the High court because it runs the very serious risk of influencing the High Court's decision. The High Court's decision should be based on its own neutral analysis of the laws and actions and powers of the states under the Constitution.

What has not been answered in this place, to my knowledge, is whether the Solicitor-General was instructed by the government to make that commitment for new taxes so as to influence the High Court's decision against them, as indeed has been claimed by the states through at least two of the state premiers.

I would like to know, and I think the Australian public has a right to know, when cabinet made this decision about new taxes because that is what we are talking about. We are talking about the Commonwealth imposing new taxes. Australians have the right to know—the parliament and the taxpayers need to know—how many Australians will have to pay more tax under the Commonwealth's proposals. On the face of it, it looks as though the Commonwealth government would be simply adding yet a further episode to its ongoing saga of expansion of the Commonwealth's indirect tax base, including, in particular, sales tax and excise—the very prospect against which it has railed for so long.

What Mr Reith has said in recent days, which I would have thought no right-minded federalist who believes in the separation of powers between the Commonwealth and the states and the rights of the states could possibly disagree with, is the proposition that, as any new consumption tax imposed by the Commonwealth will enhance the power of the Commonwealth, any new system must contain a quid pro quo. In other words, in some way the Commonwealth must make room for the states in some aspects of revenue collection just to maintain the status quo. But to say that if the states lose a revenue base a la the High Court decision tomorrow, if that in fact happens, we simply compensate by increasing Commonwealth taxes seems to add to the already enormous increase in centralism and the centralising of power under this government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: STATEMENT RELATING TO THE MOTION TO DEFER CONSIDERATION OF THE INTERSTATE GAS PIPELINES BILL 1993

SPEECH.PARA: 1. On 22 November 1993 following a recommendation by the Selection of Bills Committee contained in its Report No. 10 of 1993, the Interstate Gas Pipelines Bill 1993 (the Bill) was referred to this Committee by the Senate. The Committee undertook enquires into the Bill including a public hearing and received a number of submissions and revised submissions from interested parties advocating amendments to the Bill. The Committee was to table its report to the Senate by Monday, 6 December 1993.

2. Details of the framework embodied in the proposed legislation were forwarded to state and territory governments, industry and gas users for comment. The process of discussions on the scheme were expedited because of the deadline for introducing the legislation into the Parliament. The Second Reading Speech indicates the Government wants the scheme established by the Bill in place before the end of this financial year to assist the sale of the Moomba-Wilton Pipeline. The Bill is said to provide certainty for potential buyers of that pipeline by clearly setting out the regulatory environment that will apply to that and future interstate gas pipelines.

3. At and following the public hearing on 26 November, the Department and the Association continued negotiations in an attempt to resolve outstanding differences about the regulatory scheme. While substantial progress has occurred, areas of dispute remain. On 3 December 1993, the Minister for Resources, the Hon. Michael Lee MP, wrote to the Committee to advise that the Bill will be dropped down the order of business and will be brought forward for debate early in the next session of Parliament. The Minister's letter outlines the current state of negotiations between the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Australian Gas Association and reports more work is needed to resolve outstanding issues.

4. The Committee therefore has resolved to seek an extension of time to report on the second sitting day of the first session of Parliament in 1994. This extension will enable the Committee to facilitate negotiations between the parties and report the outcome to the Senate.
Senator Bruce Childs
Chairman
Senate Committee on Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Childs

I am writing to advise you that I have decided that the Interstate Gas Pipelines Bill 1993 will be dropped down the order of business and that this will now be brought forward for debate very early in the next session of Parliament.

Since the Standing Committee hearings on 26 November connected with the above bill, the Department and the Australian Gas Association (AGA) have been in close consultation with the objective of resolving outstanding issues. As I understand it, there remains one key matter of difference to address; that is the issue of the interstate pipelines that will be covered by the bill, and defining these in an effective way that achieves certainty and avoids circumvention on the intention of the legislation. More work is needed to ensure that "delivery points" are not used as an artifice to circumvent the third party access and antimonopoly provisions of the Bill. I have therefore agreed that Departmental discussion with industry will continue and I will consider the need for any amendments arising from these discussions.

On the other matters raised by the Association during the Committee's hearings, I advise the Committee that I am prepared to introduce an amendment that will enable the interstate carrier to refuse the provision of haulage services to another person if the proposed arrangements do not comply with minimum "objective" standards. The standard will be based on national or industry standards and will be determined following consultation between the Department, the Trade Practices Commission and the AGA.

On the question of a statement to the Parliament on the issues raised by the Association, I have noted the Association's request and will be mindful of this when framing a statement following finalisation of all the amendments to the bill decided as appropriate.
Yours sincerely
Michael Lee

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak on the seventh annual report of the Affirmative Action Agency, which covers the period June 1992 to May 1993. As honourable senators will recall, unlike the Federal Sex Discrimination Commissioner, who has the task of enforcing anti-discrimination legislation which prohibits discriminatory behaviour, the Director of the Affirmative Action Agency has the job of removing discrimination from the workplace by requiring employers to take positive action to ensure that their employment practices do not discriminate against women. Organisations covered by the Affirmative Action Act are required to develop and implement an affirmative action program and to report on the program annually to the Affirmative Action Agency.

PARA.TAB: The annual report of the Affirmative Action Agency, which has been tabled in the Senate today, covers a significant period in the history of the agency. The last year has seen the completion of the first major review of the effectiveness of the affirmative action legislation, although much of the work of the review was completed in 1991-92. The final report, Quality and Commitment: The Next Steps was published in January 1993.

The report has found that, while a high rate of compliance with the act has been achieved over the last five years, a great deal still has to be done to achieve equality of opportunity for women in the workplace. We only have to look at how few women have reached the top echelons of both business and government organisations to see evidence of this. The last year has also been significant for the agency because of a number of structural and policy changes to the agency's function. Not only has the agency become a statutory authority but also its director has been given the power to vary reporting requirements for those organisations with an excellent record on affirmative action. In addition, from January of this year the federal government has adopted a policy of contract compliance whereby employers who fail to comply with the Affirmative Action Act are no longer eligible for government contracts for goods or services and specified forms of industry assistance.

Finally, changes to the affirmative action legislation late last year also extended the role of the agency. SPEECH.PARA: In taking note of the Auditor-General's efficiency audit of the national highway, I want to point out to the Senate that I believe the government has acted very inefficiently in regard to part of this project. The inefficiency relates to a problem concerning the construction of the F3 freeway north of Newcastle. I made some remarks about this earlier today after the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) was asked a question in this place by Senator West. The minister in his answer lauded the construction of the last section of the freeway into Newcastle. He referred to the world-class standard of that road. He somewhat unfairly interjected on my comment, saying that I did not say what I said when I saw him at the freeway opening.

PARA.TAB: I said precisely what I was going to say when I spoke to the minister at the F3 freeway. I told him then that I would compliment all authorities—state, local and federal—in the Senate on their efforts in getting that section of the F3 freeway into Newcastle completed in such quick time. I said that I would also compliment all levels of government on the standard of the road and on the fact that, at last, the centre of Sydney is linked to the centre of Newcastle, and expand on what that will mean for the local economy. I really feel that I have done what I said I would do.

I also said to the minister that this road is not finished. One of the most disturbing things I saw on the plaque on the side of the road was the bit at the bottom that says, `This marks the completion of the Newcastle-Sydney freeway'. The Newcastle-Sydney freeway is a concept that is about 20 years out of date. Certainly the intention originally was to link the two cities. Indeed, the freeway came through the centre of Newcastle on the original plan.

About 15 years ago, it was realised that there needed to be many more roads to the north. North of Newcastle a booming north coast was developing. Further north of that was one of the fastest growing areas in Australia, which is Brisbane and the environment around it. Sydney also needed an excellent link road between those two cities. The original concept of the expressway was completely out of date. People should have been talking about the freeway into northern New South Wales, which certainly was not, and still is not, finished.
This whole issue is summed up in the editorial in the Newcastle Herald of 3 December 1993, the day after the minister left. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The region is now closer in time and distance to Sydney and business and population growth should accelerate if the Hunter plays its cards correctly. While the Federal and State governments deserve applause for the funding and construction of the road, they should also remember that the job is not really finished. A 60 km per hour zone and a roundabout at Ourimbah hardly suggests freeway conditions and petering out of the freeway into a two lane road at its Northern end could be dangerous. These problems should be resolved quickly.
Let us look at how quickly the government is moving on this.

PARA.TAB: The minister announced at the opening of the road that feasibility studies and environmental impact studies were being done on a link road from Sugarloaf to the Branxton section of the New England Highway. That road is very necessary to take heavy trucks, and it would do enormous things for the city of Cessnock and the town of Kurri Kurri, which have been suffering under the current traffic arrangements for the past eight years. It should have been well advanced by this stage.

I suggest that the minister's environmental impact statements should have been done about five to eight years ago. The next stage of the construction of this road—the final completion of the road—should be well advanced if priority is given for that section. I suggest that it be given a higher priority before it is done. It certainly should be done. On the minister's planning, the job is probably 10 to 20 years away from completion.

Before that work is done, a link between the end of the F3, the New England Highway and the Pacific Highway urgently needs to be built. It is absolutely amazing that we have built 163 kilometres of road north of Sydney—it ought to be seen from the air—and it finishes in a swamp. Eight kilometres away is not only the New England Highway but also the Pacific Highway.The federal government has put in place a national highway strategy, yet it has left this glaring hole in the national system. I would like the minister to visualise what will happen around 17 December this year—

TALK.START.PARA: —And Easter Thursday.

—And Easter Thursday next year out of Minmi. I will lay bets with the minister on the length of the traffic snarl that will be created when people travelling north to Brisbane and the New England area for their holidays come into a country one-lane road off expressway conditions. Blind Freddy would have been able to see 10 years ago what was going to happen.

PARA.TAB: I know that the minister will say that a lot of money has been spent—I agree with and applaud that; it is terrific—but why finish an expressway eight kilometres short of its destination? We urgently need to overcome this problem. It is not only a matter of taking Sydney traffic to the north. As the minister is well aware from the letters to him and his response to the people of Beresfield, there are many other traffic snarl problems in this area. Into that traffic snarl, this road feeds Sydney traffic on a one-lane system.

There has been some plan to fast-track perhaps one side of the expressway's completion into the New England Highway system. That would greatly relieve the problem. The minister is nodding. Perhaps he can tell us when that is due to be completed. I believe that snarls like the ones that will be created around Christmas time and beyond will be around for quite a few years.

The government had the bright idea of completing the northbound section of the freeway and making Lenaghans Drive, a two-laned road, a one-way southbound section. If it were out in the middle of nowhere, that would be a sensible idea. But, in effect, this part of the road is in a fairly rapidly developing area of western Newcastle. There are a whole lot of plans to put in even further developments there. I wonder how the locals who go up and down those roads will cope. If this one-way road system proceeds, a person who wants to visit a neighbour who is in the wrong direction by one kilometre will have to travel eight kilometres up the road and come down another six or seven kilometres on the other side of it.

The answer is fairly obvious. When the Roads and Traffic Authority does the monitoring of traffic on this road, it will become extremely apparent that a much higher priority must be given to the proper completion of the F3 Freeway, which means linking it to the New England Highway and the Pacific Highway. This currently huge gap in the national highway system in one of the busiest areas of Australia will then finally be removed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words on the Auditor-General's report No. 15 of 1993-94, which is an efficiency report that has been undertaken under the provisions of the Audit Act. It is an important report because it is an audit into the government's national highway program. The national highway links Australia's major cities. It is a large program which provides for the construction and maintenance of the national highway. It is fully funded by the Commonwealth government and is administered by the Department of Transport and Communications, or DOTAC, by way of special purpose payments under section 96 of the constitution.

PARA.TAB: The budget for this program is large. In the last financial year, 1992-93, the budget for the national highway was $810 million. As I understand from the report, the proposals for a new national highway program to be introduced during 1994 are currently being considered. Because of that, the report by the Auditor-General has particular relevance at this time.

The Auditor-General reviewed the economy, the efficiency and the cost effectiveness of the management of the program's funding as administered by the Department of Transport and Communications. In his report, the Auditor-General has identified the scope for DOTAC to considerably improve its management of the program. As the Auditor-General said in his summary of the key points:

SPEECH.PARA: The ANAO considers that the Government intention evidenced in various statements requires DOTAC to actively manage and maximise benefits nationally. This is also consistent with the general requirements for special purpose payments. DOTAC considers—
this is in response to the Auditor-General's comments and findings—
that it has given effect to the Government's intentions, and has exercised an appropriate form of program management in the context of the policy framework of the current program.
The Auditor-General says that there is a divergence of views between his office and DOTAC in respect of DOTAC's role in managing the national highway program. The Auditor-General states that this:
. . . highlights an apparent ambiguity that should be formally resolved before the introduction of the new program in 1994 or if the current program is extended.

I hope in his response to this report the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) will inform the Senate of the government's views on this ambiguity and what is being done to resolve it. The Auditor-General continues:

The ANAO established some network management criteria and found opportunities for DOTAC to achieve potential savings and improvements in program oversight. The ANAO considers the audit findings are relevant to both the existing program and new program.

The Auditor-General believes that economies can be found out of the budget for the national highway program. He believes that there are ways to `drive the roads dollar further'. There has been notable evidence over recent years to support that view. The Auditor-General goes on to say:
The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics report of July 1992 identified a maintenance repair option that could result in average annual savings of up to 15%.

On my calculations, 15 per cent adds up to around $60 million per year. That is, by any person's definition, a lot of money if it can be used more efficiently through improved arrangements. The Auditor-General stated in the report that as well as those improvements:
Economies could be achieved by negotiating reductions in the administration expenses of State Road Authorities.

The report specifically mentions two economies that can be achieved. They are project management and contract administration costs which have the potential cost saving of up to $21 million and a further potential saving of up to $8 million through general administrative costs.

PARA.TAB: They are some of the ways taxpayers could get better value for their dollars spent on roads under the national highways program. There are other aspects that were commented on in the audit report. The audit report states that management requires improvement. For example, the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: DOTAC should ensure monthly payments match the States' actual expenditure and take account of surplus cash from the previous year. ANAO found that in 1992-93 the Commonwealth lost a potential $4.1m in interest on ALTD fund payments surplus to the States' requirements, of which $2m was on payments for the National Highway.

Those matters are of serious concern. They are points with which DOTAC does not agree in all instances. Indeed DOTAC contests many of the findings of the audit report in relation to the current program. For that reason, that places further importance on the need for the government to give a considered response to the audit report. If there are differences of view, then they ought to be resolved. I hope the minister will respond to this report. I did not get the feeling from the minister's body language that we will get much of a response at the moment. I hope that there will be a formal response to some of these matters because I presume we are close to looking at the 1994 program. This is another useful report from the Auditor-General and one which requires a response from the government and certainly warrants careful consideration by this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Short that this is a useful report. The differences between the Auditor-General's examination of this matter and ours are not very great at all. We agree with the Auditor-General that with constant attention further efficiencies can be achieved. That is the attitude that we take constantly.

PARA.TAB: A comprehensive response has been provided in that report and I am surprised that Senator Short has not read it. Throughout the report individual references are made to DOTAC's responses to various matters raised. A comprehensive response is contained as an appendix to the report. I see Senator Short nodding, so I assume that he has seen that.

We believe the concentration should be on outputs rather than inputs. If there is any difference between our views, that is where it lies. The fundamental situation is, and I have no intention of changing it, that the Commonwealth provides the money for these projects. We have just been talking about $225 million that was provided for a magnificent piece of work. We got very good value for money for that project and it came in well and truly under budget and on time with the opening of the F3 freeway at Newcastle. We are concentrating on getting value for money for our outputs.

I advise Senator Short that a major survey has been done by an independent business organisation which comprehensively indicates that we are achieving world best practice in Australia with the construction of roadways. As I said during question time today, these projects are world class and price competitive. That is the bottom line. Although we provide the money, the work is managed largely by state government traffic authorities.

I point out to Senator Short that we have a group of 30 officers in the department who are responsible at the Commonwealth end for administering the national highway system. The Victorian state government administers an equal length of road—that is, 18,500 kilometres; a useful benchmark—with a group of 1,500 bureaucrats, not 30. If people want to go down this track, it is perfectly possible that the Commonwealth could set up a much larger bureaucracy with its own in-house engineers. We could set up our own pavement testing systems. Senator Short will acknowledge that that is mentioned in the Auditor-General's report. But we choose not to do that. The best results that can be achieved for taxpayers in Australia, and we can demonstrate this, is by not duplicating what state government authorities already efficiently provide.

We provided every cent of the $225 million in funding for the F3 freeway project but the project was managed by the New South Wales department of works. It managed the project very efficiently. In past years there have been fixed allocations to the states and there has been the provision that where projects come in under budget the money is retained by the state and rolled over into other road projects. As Senator Short well knows, there is never any shortage of road projects on which we can effectively spend taxpayers' dollars.

I think that has provided a very efficient in-house efficiency measure on state government road authorities—that is, in order to stretch the Commonwealth dollar for the states' own benefit as far as possible, they have been able to bring projects in efficiently under budget, retain that money and spend it on additional road projects. I can give a dozen examples off the top of my head of where that has happened in all states and territories of Australia. The Northern Territory is very efficient at spending the Commonwealth dollar as, I might add, is Western Australia. We do it with great alacrity. We probably have a better record for spending it quicker than anybody in the country and getting value for money on it.

I do not think it is efficient for the Commonwealth to increase dramatically the level of bureaucracy that we have, which we keep deliberately small, by duplicating the control and management functions that are already efficiently provided by state government road authorities; they do it very well and they have been doing it for a long time. We do not want to set up a separate system of road maintenance and checking.

The Commonwealth has insisted—and this is where we have given the lead—that state governments implement procedures such as pavement testing systems to test the efficiency with which road maintenance is carried out. It has been largely at the insistence of the Commonwealth government, as part of the conditions for these grants, that state authorities have moved to do this. So the Commonwealth has a very good track record of keeping the efficiency with which the state government authorities construct the roads at a very high level.

In terms of getting value for money—having seen it in my own electorate in the Northern Territory and in projects that I have personally been involved with on the road side of it—by and large, I think the state authorities do a very effective job of competently administering these road projects, and that is how it is set up. I feel, with the greatest respect to the Auditor-General, that to go to the extent that is required in terms of the inputs into the dollar of setting up a duplicate bureaucracy at Commonwealth level with our own engineers and so on testing the maintenance on the roads when state government authorities do it, we think, in a very efficient fashion would be very inefficient and provide a poor return for the taxpayer.

I will give one example of the kind of thing I am talking about which can produce off-the-top-of-the-head figures of $20 million, which Senator Short quoted. A fixed percentage fee is provided with contracts from the Commonwealth to cover all the unattributed costs that go into road projects—and they are significant—such as pre-planning procedures; all these things have to happen and they have to be paid for.

As Senator Short has correctly said, that figure is set at four per cent. It has been set at four per cent for 20 years. We are currently reviewing it. Where the Auditor-General got his $20 million from is very simple. The Auditor-General has simply recommended that that four per cent figure be reduced to three per cent. Arithmetically, we cannot argue with that—if we use three per cent instead of four per cent, we save $20 million. Whether we can or not is another question.

We are negotiating that with the states at the moment. Senator Short has quite properly said that we are setting up a new arrangement for funding from next year on with us being responsible for the national highway system and state governments being responsible for roads outside of that with untied grants from the Commonwealth. We are now reviewing that figure. I confidently expect the states will say that the real cost of doing all of that is eight per cent instead of four per cent. I might be out a percentage point or two but I expect them to at least double it because of additional demands.

When plucking figures out of the air, it is just as easy to say that it should be eight per cent instead of four per cent as it is to say that it should be three per cent instead of four per cent and save $20 million. All I am saying is that those assumptions have to be tested a little more scrupulously than simply saying instead of four per cent it should be three, and we save $20 million if it is three. The states would contest that it has to be double what it is now, I have no doubt, but we will arrive at a figure which I think reasonably reflects the real costs of these unattributed costs for projects which are there. They have to be paid for by somebody, and we pay for them.

By and large, I think we are well served with the management that is provided by both state and territory road authorities. They are a pretty committed bunch of people; they are highly experienced. They do it on our behalf and, frankly, I think they do it far more efficiently than the Commonwealth could by setting up a duplicate system of checks and balances which the Auditor-General suggests we do.

I conclude by commenting very briefly on the matters that Senator Tierney raised. They do not relate to the report, nevertheless, he raised them and they should be responded to. We acknowledge the need to complete the rest of the roadworks. I apologise to Senator Panizza for mishearing his interjection at question time today; he made the correct comment that every time we provide these roadworks they help. Certainly, they create other problems. The obvious one is that at any particular point in time a bottleneck will occur at the end of the particular section just finished—at a cost of $225 million—and the next bit.

As Senator Tierney has acknowledged, the amount of work that we do unquestionably benefits the area. As I said during question time today, the important contribution that this new freeway extension from Sydney will make to Newcastle is that the connecting road between the city of Newcastle and the F3 freeway—and it is a magnificent piece of road, if honourable senators ever get a chance to look at it, from a scenic as well as an engineering point of view—has been brought forward two full years in order to coincide with the opening of the freeway so Newcastle can get the maximum benefit from this faster link to Sydney.

What was said at the opening of that road—and I think it is true—was that it is quite extraordinary when one thinks that the first road connection that existed, a dirt road, between Sydney and Newcastle was only completed 63 years ago. When one has a look at what is there now in some of what is without question the most difficult terrain in which to build roads in Australia—just in that short 19 kilometre section there are 23 major bridges and a whole stack of road cuts and so on that have to be put in as well—it is a pretty significant enterprise.

The Commonwealth is well aware that the work has to continue. We are not going to unnecessarily spend taxpayers' dollars on ploughing money into what are acknowledged as being temporary links. We are conducting a major environmental impact study into the permanent link between the F3 and the New England Highway. That is considering at least five major options for the routing of that road, and that is not an easy thing to do. It involves, for example, compulsory acquisition of land. It is not a simple task to determine where to put something as big as that. That will take at least 12 months. At the completion of that EIS we will have a firm decision on the preferred route for the permanent link and work will then commence on constructing that link.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: As pointed out in the majority report, the matter of the Centenary House lease between the Commonwealth, on behalf of the Australian National Audit Office, and John Curtin House Ltd, which is owned by the Australian Labor Party, was the subject of intensive examination by the committee. The majority report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The ostensible cause of concern in this matter has been whether the terms of the lease are "commercially sound". Underlying this are allegations and imputations of, in effect, impropriety: that the lease was negotiated at other than arm's length in order to provide advantage to the lessor—

which is in fact the Australian Labor Party. That is the reason why we put out a minority report. For instance, the term `ostensible cause of concern' was used, when the concern that we had was that Centenary House relates to the misuse of taxpayers' money, involving a lease agreement entered into by the Australian Property Group on behalf of the Australian National Audit Office. It is a classic example of the saying that if it walks like a duck, quacks like a duck and swims like a duck, one can be excused for assuming it is a duck.

PARA.TAB: The background to this situation is that the Australian National Audit Office sought to combine all its facilities under one roof. It contacted the Australian Property Group to act on its behalf to find it one space instead of being under many roofs, as it had been previously. The Australian Property Group then entered into negotiations with Lend Lease. It called for expressions of interest from the various groups which would be interested in building a property for the Australian National Audit Office.

As the negotiations progressed, Australian Estate Management—the owner of Commonwealth property throughout Australia—advised the Australian Property Group that it would not give its consent for the Australian National Audit Office to go into a separate building when it, the Australian estate manager, was attempting to accumulate property to justify the building of the York Park building in Barton. For some reason, that refusal to consent was withdrawn within a couple of days. No satisfactory answers were given to the committee by Australian Estate Management as to why that refusal was withdrawn.

The Australian Property Group was also requested by Australian Estate Management to market the York Park building. Under the way the government operates, the Australian Property Group has a monopoly on government buildings and the letting of premises within the Australian Capital Territory. What came through in the committee's hearings was that for some reason the Australian Property Group did not market the York Park building. The question one must ask is why it did not do that.

The Australian Property Group knew in October 1990 that the so-called Lend Lease building was the new ALP headquarters, but it did not tell the Australian National Audit Office about that connection until March 1991. In fact, in all communications between the Australian Property Group and the Australian National Audit Office the term used was `the Lend Lease site' or `the joint venturers'. Why did the Australian Property Group do that? One must ask why the Australian National Audit Office was not advised immediately that the owner was the Australian Labor Party. Why was it hiding that information?

At the time of occupancy of Centenary House, the rental per square metre was estimated to be in the order of $40 per square metre higher than the average market rate within the Australian Capital Territory. As far as I can gather, this was the most extraordinary deal that anyone has ever seen. Here was a building, owned by the ALP, under a contract negotiated by the Australian Property Group, which offered the Australian Labor Party a—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not even built then.

—I love to hear Senator Murphy making his interjections; they make our life so interesting. A deal was made that offered the Australian Labor Party a 15-year lease. For the period up to the occupancy, which was about two years, there would be a 10 per cent escalation of the rental, and from the date of occupancy, for 15 years, there would be nine per cent or market rate—whichever was the higher. This makes an absolute nonsense of this remark in the majority report:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . APG—
a government department—
and AVO are of the view that over the medium to long term, the "market" in the Parkes/Barton area of the ACT will come into balance—
and listen to this—
providing benefit to ANAO.

Anyone with a primary knowledge of mathematics would know that an agreement that states that the rental will be increased by nine per cent per annum or market rate—whichever is the higher—will never achieve a market rental. I draw that to the Senate's attention.

PARA.TAB: Prior to September 1991, the Australian Property Group also knew that the lease would include this escalator, or ratchet clause, of approximately nine per cent, but provided the audit office, its client, with a draft letter of intent seeking the concurrence of the Australian National Audit Office. The letter did not mention a nine per cent escalation factor, which the Australian National Audit Office found out when the details of the lease became public in June 1992.

The Auditor-General himself has said that he probably deserves a little bit of criticism because he should have checked, but has pointed out that he relied on the operations of the Australian Property Group as the organisation he had to go to to work out a decent lease. Everyone is aware of the fact that the Australian Property Group has incredible bargaining power because it is able to offer a government tenant, which means security of rental. Normally, when that occurs it puts a value on the property which is substantially higher than when one takes the risk of a non-government tenant.

As it turned out, the Australian Labor Party, through Centenary House, spent about $17 million. On the basis of the rental and the guarantee of a nine per cent increase every year for 15 years or market increases, whichever is the higher, and using the capitalisation factor of 8 1/2 per cent—a very conservative one, I might say—that promptly gives the ALP, at the expense of the taxpayers of Australia, an immediate capital gain of $12 million.

This government has become arrogant. We have seen recently the efforts of Mrs Kelly from the other chamber in handing out largess—again, other people's money; again, taxpayers' money—simply to win elections. That is bad enough, but when a deal is made that gives a handout to the Australian Labor Party through the taxpayer—

TALK.START.PARA: —To the taxpayers.

—Senator Murphy says, `Through the taxpayer'. I thank Senator Murphy for that interjection. Here is a gift to the Australian Labor Party, at taxpayers' expense, of $12 million. This is unconscionable. If the government is confident that this deal is above board, why does the owner, the lessor, not agree to negotiate it? Why is that the case? That is another unanswered question. As I pointed out earlier, this was a series of actions which individually may not mean very much but which, when accumulated, raise the suspicions not only of people on our side but of the public at large.

PARA.TAB: There were three major players in this exercise, apart from Lend Lease, which was acting on behalf of the ALP. They were: the Australian National Audit Office, as the eventual tenant; the Australian Property Group, which was required to act as any other real estate would do—to act on behalf of its client and get the client premises at the lowest possible rental; that is its job—and the Australian Valuation Office, which was called in and which would normally, I expect, be called in to give an opinion as to the valuation of the rental per square metre. I would not have expected the Valuation Office to be called in to go into all the details of the contract. That is the area of expertise of the Australian Property Group, yet the AVO was called in to give a much broader opinion.

When I got wind of this in January last year and put out a press release highlighting the fact that this deal had been made, my office was phoned by a person claiming to be an interested citizen. When that person was tracked down, it was found that he was the major negotiator for the Australian Property Group. Why did he do that? Well we may ask.

There were two major players from the Australian Property Group and one from the Australian Valuation Office. The biggest surprise of all is that all of the major players have since left. They have taken early retirement—and it is not as if they were approaching the age of retirement; they were not. Two have left and one has been promoted to another department. It is just one of those coincidences! Then we had the comment made in the majority report that, whereas these people had in fact left, the current officers advise that they had the benefit of a briefing from him. We were not born yesterday. They had a briefing from the main architect and he said that everything was okay.

When I raised this question here the other day it reminded me of a little bit of history. Does the Senate remember the Petrov affair when Dr Evatt wrote to Mr Molotov and asked, `Is Petrov lying?'. He then got up in parliament and said, `Mr Molotov has written and said "Yes, he is"'. It is about as believable. You cannot ask someone who was a major player and who had left and then say, `However, we have had the benefit of a briefing'. That is like Caesar on Caesar.

It is all those factors that add up. We all know—and no-one is disputing the fact—that here we have a Labor government in power whose organisational wing, the ALP, has arranged a deal through another group, the Lend Lease Corporation, with the net result being that, on a conservative calculation, from the day the Australian National Audit Office occupies that building, the ALP has a notional capital gain of $12 million. It can go out tomorrow and make $12 million at taxpayers' expense, paid for by the Auditor-General.

What is even worse, and adds to the questions, is that the Department of Finance has not accepted the lease conditions. It has told the Australian National Audit Office that it will only pay for rentals on the basis of one per cent per annum. Where did the Department of Finance get its information about potential rent increases? The Australian Property Group. That is who advised the Department of Finance about the prospective rental increase. So the auditor—

TALK.START.PARA: —A prospective rental increase for what? Just tell the whole truth.
—A rental increase.
—But not for that particular building.
—The financial agreement is between the Department of Finance and the audit office.
—The trouble is that you are only believing that bit of the evidence that you want to believe.

—Senator Murphy can respond to this if he wishes, but that is what the Department of Finance has told the audit office, which means that the audit office now has to fund an eight per cent increase in rental every year out of its budget allocation, which in turn means that the audit office will have to cut back the amount of work it does. It does very fine work, I might say—not just in ordinary auditing work, but also in efficiency audits.
—Sports rorts.

—Senator Patterson reminds me of the great job done by the Auditor-General with regard to Mrs Kelly, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, and the preferences given to Labor marginal electorates at the last election, again at taxpayers' expense.

PARA.TAB: The Australian National Audit Office is the jam in the sandwich. It did everything that was required of it. It used the Australian Property Group because it had to. It was not fully informed. At no stage did we get answers to the key questions that we asked. We asked the Australian Property Group: why did you not inform the audit office as to who the real owner was? For a period of nearly 12 months, the audit office thought it was lend lease through a joint venture. It may not have made any difference, and I personally—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us why you keep raising it.

—I know Senator Murphy does not like me to keep mentioning it, but they are the facts. The other thing that adds to our suspicion is the number of questions the estimates committee asked which went unanswered. An unanswered question put by me, which so far has had no response from the APG, was: why was the Centenary House—or the ALP—lease not to be a model for others? The claim was made that this is a good deal. If it is a good deal, why is it not the norm for all properties leased by the Commonwealth? I know of no other similar deal.

PARA.TAB: Another unanswered question from Senator Bishop and Senator Campbell asked for details of other leases which had a fixed escalator of nine per cent per annum; there was no answer to that. We were advised that we would get a copy of the Centenary House lease as signed; as at today, that still has not been received. I asked the Australian Valuation Office to advise on Property Group lease terms; there has been no response to that. Senator Campbell asked a question about effective net rental higher than that of Centenary House; there was no response to that. I asked the question as to whether there had been any contact between the then minister, Senator Bolkus, or his office to facilitate Centenary House lease; there has been no response to that question either.
There is a clear inconsistency in the majority report. It states initially:
On the basis of the evidence before the Committee, allegations and imputations of impropriety (or worse) cannot be substantiated.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said they could not be substantiated, it states:
. . . there are questions of serious moment that remain unresolved.
It further states:

PARA.TAB: The current state of this matter leaves serious allegations standing against the conduct and professionalism of the Australian Property Group and the Australian Valuation Office.

SPEECH.PARA: It recommends, as has been pointed out by Senator Coates, the proposal by the Auditor-General to have the Auditor-General from South Australia look at it and—in view of the negative reaction to that by Mr Willis—that perhaps it should be also the auditor of the Auditor-General plus some third party. The Auditor-General has pointed out publicly that the auditor of the Auditor-General can turn up in the audit office at any time, but generally he is limited to the Auditor-General's office.

PARA.TAB: We have recommended in the minority report that there be a separate inquiry into this matter. While I agree that the Auditor-General's recommendation should be pursued, there must be an inquiry of such stature that will enable the people carrying it out to go outside the Auditor-General, outside the Australian Property Group and outside the Australian Valuation Office. The allegations made in some of the stories conveyed to me by telephone—and I have not canvassed them as I do not think it would be proper to do so here—are such that whoever is appointed to carry out the inquiry should be enabled to go outside and have a look. But, equally importantly, the inquiry must be such that those people who give evidence before it must be given the privilege that is available to anyone else giving evidence before the Senate.

In conclusion, this matter is serious. It is serious not just because the Australian Labor Party is the owner; it is serious because a lease agreement has been entered into which has terms and conditions associated with it which are not comparable with any other lease agreement entered into by the Commonwealth. All these separate factors indicate that an investigation is needed, and if the Labor Party and the Labor government consider it to be above-board, it should immediately instigate a review of the lease and the terms and conditions attached to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the report on the supplementary meeting of Estimates Committee D. In doing so, I begin by explaining my involvement in this matter. I was given the great honour of participating in this particular estimates committee as a stand-in for another senator who was on leave. So I came to this issue fresh and, in doing so, perhaps I was able to come across the evidence in a different way to that of many of the other committee members. I was only aware of these issues in so far as they related to press speculation. I had to make myself familiar with the detail of the evidence that had been heard by the estimates committee and with the various allegations that had been levelled publicly up to that point.

PARA.TAB: As a consequence of my examination of the evidence, I am firmly of the view that there is no impropriety with regard to the leasing of the building known as Centenary House. I became aware that all major political parties in this country lease property to the Commonwealth. That was a fact that I was not aware of until I joined this committee. The National Party has rented property to the Commonwealth; the Liberal Party has rented property to the Commonwealth; and, of course, now the Labor Party is the owner of a building which is rented to the Commonwealth. This is a basic fact of life of which many people in this country are unaware.

We are seeing double standards being applied when it comes to any matter relating to a commercial arrangement between a building owned by the Australian Labor Party and a government agency, despite the fact that all the evidence available clearly indicates the arm's length arrangements between the government and the commercial contract entered into between a government agency and the owner of this particular building. Not one skerrick of evidence has been produced to suggest anything to the contrary. Despite all the wild allegations of those opposite, not one skerrick of evidence has been produced to suggest that any minister of the Crown or any member of parliament has behaved in any way that is inappropriate.

All arrangements have been based on the very simple proposition of sound commercial practice. The Auditor-General's office has made all the effective decisions in terms of the selection of this particular site, it has sought a particular site to meet its specifications and it is effectively in control of those arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —If someone negotiated a deal like that, you would sue him. If an agent negotiated a deal like that, you would sue the agent.
—Well, we might come to the question of competence in terms of arrangements—
—We will come to the issue of negligence.

—And negligence perhaps. These are matters that Senator Campbell may find answers to with which he is not entirely happy. People listening to Senator Parer on this broadcast today might believe that somehow the Auditor-General, Mr Taylor, was not aware of the ALP's involvement in the ownership of the property until very late in the piece. It might also be suggested that the Australian National Audit Office played something less than an active role in the selection of the building and the negotiations leading to the agreement. Of course, both those propositions are clearly wrong.

PARA.TAB: I preface my remarks by making a few comments about my support for an independent, credible auditor's office, and for ensuring that there is a proper functioning office that can keep public accountability on government expenditure that, equally, has high credibility in its dealings with other government agencies. My investigations suggest to me that had some of the answers given to us on that committee by the Auditor-General's office been given by a government agency, there may well have been a political outcry and a very damning report before this parliament.

To suggest that files were not adequately kept and that officers were unavailable in normal circumstances in any other agency would lead people to the conclusion that entirely the best practice was not followed—however, not the best practice followed by the Labor Party, by the Valuation Office, or by the Property Group but in terms of the operations of the audit office. Mr Taylor specifically canvassed the issue of ALP ownership at a meeting of senior staff on 12 April and recommended—it is indicated in correspondence—that the office wished to proceed because the ownership had no bearing on the operations of the audit office and the use of that tenanted space. Mr Taylor admitted that he had addressed senior staff on this matter in the Canberra Times on 30 October 1991.

We need to appreciate that in the negotiations at all relevant times the audit office was involved and consulted. In my judgment, after examining the evidence, it agreed to the terms and conditions of the lease. The 15-year duration of the lease was entirely appropriate to the circumstances on the evidence presented to the estimates committee. It was a specified building to meet the particular requirements of the particular tenant. The developer required the longer term lease to ensure ongoing commitment and to finance the construction. The ALP's involvement in the presentation of various planning documents obviously postdated the arrangements that were entered into, suggesting to me that the audit office clearly had an understanding of what was involved in the lease and in the terms and ownership of that particular property.

There was further documentation on the escalations clause in the files that the committee received. The auditor indicated to us that he was not aware that on 13 August 1991 Mr Dominic Collins had written to Mr John Barwood of the Australian National Audit Office, Medibank House in Phillip, indicating the various options that were available to the audit office, and seeking its agreement before entering any commitment. He outlined the following options:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) (i) Set a rent level at the time of entering a commitment; or
(ii) Set a level now that would apply to the completion of the project.
(b) (i) Establish a gross rent similar to the arrangements in Medibank House; or
(ii) Establish a net rent which provides for the tenant to pay all outgoings.
(c) (i) Negotiate a rent structure based on fixed escalations; or
(ii) Negotiate a rent structure based on market rents.

This clearly indicates the level of discussion that had taken place between officers of the ANAO and the Property Group. What was clear to me in the documentation that was presented is that the audit office was involved through its senior officers. The evidence clearly indicated that the Property Group and the Valuation Office were not prepared to deal with officers unless they were in a senior position within the audit office and clearly had the authority to act for the audit office.

PARA.TAB: So I have no doubt in my mind as to the sequence of events that occurred. Firstly, there was the request and the drive for the establishment of new premises essentially coming from within the audit office. The specifications were required to be laid down and there was an expression of interest from 14 different groups seeking to provide a building, including, as I recall, the Liberal Party. Of the 14 options pursued, the Lend Lease-ALP proposition was the one selected. After it was clearly identified publicly that the ALP was involved, the audit office decided to continue with the development.

Those essential facts are clear. What I am concerned about and where there needs to be further inquiry is the relationship between the Department of Finance and the audit office. There is some tension in that relationship. In terms of the discussion surrounding the resource agreement—which goes beyond the rental of any one building; it goes to the entire financial operation of the audit office—it is not entirely clear to what extent the audit office understood its obligations and the Department of Finance understood its obligations. There appears to be some discrepancy there. This discrepancy may arise essentially because different agencies were involved in the preparation and the negotiation of the lease arrangements. One government agency was responsible for the resource agreement and another agency responsible for the leasing arrangement. The only agency that seemed to have a grip on both levels of activity was the audit office. The Property Group was not party to negotiation on the resource agreement, and the Department of Finance was not party to the negotiations on the lease. I repeat: it appears that the audit office was the only agency that was party to both.

So we have a problem which relates to the question of responsibility. The honourable senator opposite indicated a moment ago that there was concern about the responsibility of officers concerned to undertake fair and proper authority. As I understand the relevant spending of public moneys provision, finance regulation 44A, it requires that, in accordance with that regulation, it is the responsibility of the officer responsible for spending public moneys to ensure that any proposal is in accordance with Commonwealth policies and will make an effective and efficient use of the public moneys.

Further, finance regulation 44B, amongst other things, permits a person to enter into a commitment requiring the payment of public moneys only if the proposal to spend has been approved by a person with authority to do so, the commitment is consistent with any terms in the approval, the person entering the commitment is satisfied that the expenditure represents value for money, and sufficient funds to cover the expenditure have been or will be appropriated. These issues need to be addressed in any future inquiry. They do strike me as somewhat odd. If we apply the same standards to the audit office that the auditor applies to other government agencies, perhaps we will come up with some further questions and get some interesting answers.

There are some basic questions here about political propriety—not the political propriety of the Labor Party or of any particular agency but about an opposition that is effectively bereft of ideas and that finds it necessary to go into these sorts of issues because essentially it has nowhere else to go. It is a major problem in its arrangements. It tells one more about the Liberal Party's thinking than it does about the operations of this government. There is no evidence to suggest any impropriety on behalf of officers of the Department of Finance, of the Valuation Office, of the Property Group or of the Australian National audit office. There is no basis for any claims that are being made about any impropriety involving this government. There is a normal commercial arrangement which responds to the very location that the audit office sought for the property at Centenary House, being the central business district of government in Australia.

What an inquiry perhaps would indicate is ways in which we can get improvements in the administration of government agencies such as the audit office in terms of its leasing arrangements. However, in my judgment, given the evidence we have seen before this committee, an inquiry will not demonstrate that the allegations Senator Parer has been making have any substance whatsoever.

Essentially, this is an issue that goes to the provision of very high standard accommodation—to the specification provided for by the audit office. Of course, ownership of the building does not mean control of the actual activities of any particular tenant—any more than a government agency that rents space from either the National Party or Liberal Party has to fear interference from those political parties. The contrary proposition is founded on basic assumptions which are fundamentally flawed. When this matter is looked at properly and rationally with an objective examination of the evidence, it will be seen that there is no basis whatsoever to the claims of impropriety that are being made.
