That was the evidence given to the committee. Senator Carr chooses to ignore that evidence, but that is one of the facts of the matter.

PARA.TAB: There is enormous doubt as to the communications between the Australian Property Group and the Australian National Audit Office. Senator Carr and Senator Murphy choose to have the Senate believe that the Auditor-General was in some way not up to the mark in not knowing that he had a lease with a nine per cent rental increase. The facts revealed in the estimates committee—and Senator McMullan was there and admitted it—were that the Australian Property Group never, in any correspondence, advised the Australian National Audit Office of the specific detail of the term of the lease or the rental increase. It did not really know about it until after it was signed and it was all put to bed. That is why, all of a sudden, this has become a big issue. The Australian taxpayers have realised that they have been locked into a deal by the Australian Property Group to pay the Australian Labor Party millions and millions of dollars for the next 15 years. My view and the view of the opposition is that this deal should be investigated and renegotiated because the Auditor-General cannot operate under this lease.

I want to turn to the Australian Property Group. It could have negotiated, in the interests of the Auditor-General, if the Auditor-General's office required security of tenure over a 15-year period, a quite normal arrangement, which would have been a 10-year lease, which is still an extremely long lease. Anyone who says that the ALP or Lend Lease could not finance the project on a 10-year lease with a high starting rental is kidding himself and trying to kid the Senate. A 10-year lease to a government tenant with a fixed starting rent and fixed escalators is a tremendous deal for anyone to finance. As I have said in the estimates committee a couple of times, when I have been boring everyone and myself, one would have developers and financiers queuing up at the door, running from Canberra right down the Hume Highway. Hundreds of developers and financiers would be clambering on top of each other to finance the deal. So it is absolute rubbish to say that one has to have a 15-year contract to get a financier interested in that deal. People would love to have done that deal on a 10-year lease. The Auditor-General could have been given a five-year option to renew the lease at the end of that 10-year term. That would be a quite sensible and normal commercial negotiation.

The Australian people deserve to know the facts from the Australian Property Group. Ms Cathy Argall, who gave evidence to the estimates committee, could not in any way show the estimates committee—she certainly could not convince me—that the deal that it negotiated had anything in it for its client, the Australian National Audit Office, the people who pay the APG's fees.

To the contrary, these minimum escalation clauses work very much against the interests of the tenant for whom the Australian Property Group was negotiating. There needs to be a thorough investigation into how the Australian Property Group negotiated, on behalf of its client, the correspondence that was carried out between the Australian Property Group and the Australian National Audit Office. There is absolutely no doubt from the evidence we were given on 9 November that the Australian National Audit Office was not kept informed of absolutely essential elements of the negotiation, such as the escalation clauses.

The proof of the pudding is in what the Australian National Audit Office has told the world at large: we cannot live with a nine per cent rental increase. If the Australian National Audit Office had been told by the Australian Property Group prior to entering the commitment that it was going to have a nine per cent minimum guaranteed rental increase, the Australian National Audit Office could not have possibly agreed to it. The Department of Finance would not have let it agree to it. The fact of the matter is that there was an enormous breakdown in communications. My view is that the Australian Property Group was negligent and failed in its duty to its client. Again, in a private negotiation between a private sector company and a property consultancy, if that property consultancy went and entered into some sort of agreement on behalf of a client that locked it into a 15-year lease with nine per cent increases, the private sector client would sue that agency for negligence and that agency would most likely have to pay significant damages.

These matters need to be investigated. My view is that the Australian Property Group and the Australian Valuation Office have a lot more questions to answer in terms of their professional integrity, whether or not they acted on behalf of their clients in a professional manner and whether or not property officers at the Australian Property Group and valuers at the Australian Valuation Office were not very negligent with respect to the advice that was provided and the whole way that this deal was entered into.

It is a very sad reflection on the Australian Property Group, which has many fine officers right around this country, and the Australian Valuation Office, which is staffed with professionals right around this country who do tremendous work for the Commonwealth and the people of Australia, that a slur on these organisations has eventuated from what is effectively a slimy deal involving the Australian Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party is the only winner out of this deal. It has a guaranteed income. It will ensure that, regardless of the political fortunes of the Australian Labor Party; no matter how bad Mr Keating gets; no matter how many Thai teak tables he has; no matter how many ministers, such as Mrs Kelly, make a joke of his government; no matter how many failures or political disasters strike the Australian Labor Party; and no matter how many seats we rout them by at the next federal election, the Australian Labor Party is assured of at least a 15-year future. It had a guaranteed income at the expense of the Australian taxpayer and, I might say, at the expense of the independence, impartiality and resourcing of the Auditor-General and the operations of his office.

It is absolutely crucial, as Senator Carr said, that we have a strong, vigilant and well-resourced Auditor-General's office that can look, without any fear or favour, at the operations of government and government entities, and provide information to the parliament and the taxpayers of Australia about the efficiency and financial accountability of those entities. If the Auditor-General has to suffer a nine per cent decrease in the amount of money that he can resource into his primary role of conducting investigations—it is being sucked away by a great big vacuum cleaner called the Australian Labor Party's property fund; and it is going up year after year at nine per cent—his ability to assess independently the operations of the government will be limited.

Of course, the Australian Labor Party would like to see that happen. Senator Carr, Mr Keating and their brethren do not really enjoy the Auditor-General bringing down reports like the one that was brought down two weeks ago on the mismanagement and plain political pork-barrelling that went on in the handing out of sports grants prior to the last election. They do not like the operations of their government—the mismanagement and the maladministration—being brought under the scrutiny of the Australian National Audit Office. They do not like the operations of their government being brought to the attention of Senate committees. They are intent on screwing down the financial resources and the manpower resources of Senate committees. They have absolute contempt for Senate committees and they also have contempt for the Australian National Audit Office. If Australia is going to be a vigorous democracy with a government that is accountable to the people through the parliament, we need a strong and independent auditor and we need a strong Senate committee system.

I conclude by calling for a thorough investigation of the handling of this property transaction by the Australian Valuation Office and the Australian Property Group. If, as I suspect, there have been significant failures in both of those organisations, it really is incumbent upon the government to renegotiate this whole unconscionable contract that has been entered into with the Australian Labor Party. It is quite outrageous that the Australian taxpayer should be funding the ALP into the next century by way of this exorbitant rent and these unconscionable rental increases.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the report of Estimates Committee D. In doing so, I hope I do not take up as much time of the Senate as did Senator Campbell who, in a political diatribe, accused the ALP of orchestrating something that it has had nothing to do with. With regard to the report itself, the opposition seems to be seeking an inquiry. It should be noted that under the heading `Conclusions', we recommend that there be an inquiry because of some of the questions that are left unanswered. I hope the opposition will support this recommendation because it will be the quickest way to get the matter finally resolved and removed from the political arena and to stop the politicising by Senator Parer and Senator Campbell.

PARA.TAB: This recommendation is in line with that of the Auditor-General. We have sought to add two other people to such an inquiry. This is in contrast with what the opposition seeks to do—to ask another Senate standing committee to finally determine some form of inquiry. That would just prolong the matter. Of course, that might suit the opposition because it would allow it to keep the political aspects of this whole matter going.

I want to deal with the facts of this whole issue. The minority report raises a question about the propriety, competence and professionalism of the Australian Property Group and the Australian Valuation Office. The minority report says that the advice given to the ANAO by both of those bodies was either less than it should have been or completely wrong. In regard to the terms of the lease, the minority report says that the lease does not conform with the standard lease arrangement used by the Commonwealth. The opposition knows full well that there is no standard lease with respect to Commonwealth property. The Commonwealth leases many properties around Australia and those leases vary significantly.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a standard lease.
—There is a base lease but there is not a standard lease, and Senator Campbell would know that.
—They call it a standard lease.

—Senator Campbell can call it what he likes, but there is no standard lease that is fronted up each time a property is leased between the Commonwealth and any property owner. The Liberal Party ought to know that because the Commonwealth leases property from the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: The ANAO sought accommodation whereby it could bring all of its operations under one roof. It sought accommodation in what is known as the Parliamentary Triangle, within the Barton area. We should look at what property was available and what options were available. Senator Parer mentioned the York Park building. He said the Australian Property Group did not market and did not present this building as an option to the ANAO, when it fact it was presented. One of the reasons the ANAO chose not to take York Park as an option is that it was not certain that it would be built. In fact, at that time it had not even been approved by cabinet. Today it is still not completed.

It really comes down to the decision making process. Who made the decisions with respect to finally going into Centenary House? It is quite clear from the evidence presented to the committee that the Auditor-General made that decision. In a letter to the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) he indicated that what was known as section 22, Barton, at that time was the choice that the ANAO had made; and, indeed, it had sought the assistance of the APG and the Department of Finance to enter into an agreement for that property.

With regard to the processes, firstly Senator Bishop pursued this matter. We can see from the way that the Opposition has handled this matter that it has been a political front for it. The opposition has been pursuing it as a political operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cynically.

—As Senator Bolkus says, it has been pursuing it cynically. Initially, Senator Bishop said that the Auditor-General was never made aware that the ALP owned the building. Even Senator Parer said today that the Auditor-General did not know that the ALP was the actual owner. It was not a building at that time; it was a concept. The building was not completed until very recently.

PARA.TAB: Paragraph 9 of a minute which was prepared by the Australian National Audit Office says:

SPEECH.PARA: The record shows that the first discussion of the Lend Lease site as the ALP headquarters occurred at the Management Committee meeting of 22 March 1991 . . .

So it is very clear from the Auditor-General's own minute that they were aware that the ALP owned the building back in March 1991. That is a very important point to take note of because that was over 12 months prior to any lease being finally signed with the proponents of the lease. So it was not as though it was locked into some arrangement before it knew the ALP owned the building. Indeed, what does it matter if the ALP did own the building?

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—Senator Patterson may scoff at that, but the Commonwealth leases property from the Liberal Party. It also leases property from the National Party; it leases property from the Democrats.
—Not on those terms.

—That is not the fault of the ALP, nor the fault of the government. If the Liberal Party is unable to employ people to negotiate suitable arrangements for its accommodation, it ought to have a look at its negotiators.
—We actually do it in a proper way, not in the `skulduggerous' way that you do it.

—Senator Patterson will get her opportunity. It is very important to note that some of the statements made in the minority report are factually wrong. Had this report been given outside this House, some people from the Australian Property Group may have very seriously looked at the circumstances with regards to libel. With respect to advice the minority report states:

SPEECH.PARA: It therefore appears that the ANAO were acting on the basis of representations made to it by the APG—
That is as though the Australian Property Group had been specifically trying to get the Australian National Audit Office to take the Centenary House option when, in fact, that is not true.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, the important question in this whole decision making process is: who made the decisions with regard to the final signing of the lease? We have heard all the rhetoric: the Auditor-General did not know this and did not know that; he was not aware of the nine per cent escalator; he was not aware that the ALP owned the building; he was not aware of the period of the lease, et cetera. In looking at the criticisms that the Auditor-General has laid at the feet of other government enterprises—even with respect to these sorts of matters—one would have to wonder at the circumstances confronting the Auditor-General with regard to his own enterprise going into a lease arrangement.

One of the very important claims made at the committee hearing was that the Auditor-General's office did not know that it would have to meet the additional cost. A letter dated 16 November sent to the secretary of the committee from the Department of Finance refutes that claim. It has with it a range of correspondence which, in my view, supports the position of the Department of Finance. Over and above that, the Auditor-General has picked up on leasing arrangements in some other reports. We ought to be aware of what is common practice with all government enterprises in relation to the financing of arrangements through the Department of Finance. I am no expert in this area, but if one reads some of the correspondence, one sees that it raises very serious questions as to who knew what.

With regard to the arrangements, we also have a letter that was tabled at the committee hearing, signed by Dominic Collins from the Australian Property Group and sent to a Mr John Barwood of the Australian National Audit Office in August 1991. That letter relates to proposed offices for the ANAO at Barton. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: I must apologise for not getting back to you earlier but I thought it essential to discuss issues further with the Executive Director of Lend Lease before replying.

The arrangements proposed in respect of funding for fitout is that the ANAO contribution is to be limited to $M1.7 on the basis of the current brief. This payment would be made at the time of a formal agreement being entered into. Any additional costs for ANAO would be limited to changes made after agreement has been reached on the fitout requirements.

A number of options are available in relation to the rental level determination. You will appreciate that developments of this nature are financially driven and a rental level has to be agreed up front to meet the financier's requirement to ensure viability of the project.
I am currently looking at the following options and would seek your agreement before entering any commitment:
(a)(i)Set a rent level at the time of entering a commitment; or

TAB.TAB: (ii)Set a rent level now that would apply at the completion of the project.

SPEECH.PARA: (b)(i)Establish a gross rent similar to the arrangements in Medibank House; or

TAB.TAB: (ii)Establish a net rent which provides for the tenant to pay all outgoings.

SPEECH.PARA: (c)(i)Negotiate a rent structure based on fixed escalations; or

TAB.TAB: (ii)Negotiate a rent structure bagsed on market rents.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be pleased to discuss the above with you at any time.

When we asked the Auditor-General and his office about this letter, they said that they did not have it. They also made the point that their records were not complete. Again, the Auditor-General's office says that the records are not complete, yet it accuses other enterprises within government on the basis that that occurred elsewhere. What Senator Campbell said was right—we cannot accept that.

PARA.TAB: The government accepts the need to have an inquiry. That inquiry ought to clarify some of those issues. That really goes to the matter of the funding shortfall referred to in the minority report. In particular, page 14 of the minority report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the period of the lease there is a total shortfall of $34.1 million which the ANAO will have to find from its own resources.

Some statements contained in this minority report are factually incorrect, and that is one of them. It does not take account of anything other than the basis of the rental that may be paid, and it certainly does not take account of inflation.

PARA.TAB: With respect to rents paid, Senator Campbell tabled a graph that he has tabled about six times elsewhere. It seems to change on most occasions; I think he said it was a new graph today. When one looks at accommodation costs, both nationally and within Canberra, and commercial rental accommodation costs in the eastern seaboard versus Western Australia and here, one could go to Sydney and Melbourne and have vacancy rates of 20 per cent or maybe higher. The vacancy rate in Canberra is less than five per cent. It does not matter what one buys in the Barton area and in the Parliamentary Triangle—which is where the ANAO wanted to be. If one bought a car in the Parliamentary Triangle one would probably have to pay more for it. Since I have been in this place I cannot even begin to think about purchasing property or, indeed, renting accommodation in the Barton area, and certainly not within the Parliamentary Triangle. It is important to note that assessments of rental comparisons within the Barton area over the last 10 years which were presented to the committee showed that the actual rental growth over that period has been substantially higher than nine per cent.

There are reviews at five, 10, and 15 years of the arrangements for Centenary House. As Senator Campbell pointed out, if the market rate does exceed nine per cent at the year of the review, the base is adjusted in accordance with that. It is adjusted only by that factor and only for that particular review year. The escalator remains at nine per cent until the next review.

Finally, it is a pity that the Liberal Party has chosen to politicise this issue rather than to deal with the facts. It has tried to infer that the ALP has been doing something untoward by the mere fact that it now rents accommodation to the Commonwealth. I reiterate that what Senator Parer and Senator Campbell chose not to mention was that the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Democrats do the same. I do not know what those arrangements are. In the case of this particular arrangement, a representative acted on behalf of the ALP during the negotiations with the Australian Property Group. All of the parties normally involved in arrangements to be put in place for Commonwealth rental were involved.

The claim that the ANAO was not kept informed is not supported by the evidence. The evidence clearly supports the fact that the ANAO was informed. In fact, the Australian Property Group said during the committee hearing that it offered assistance—that is supported by the letter that, unfortunately, the Australian National Audit Office says it does not have—with respect to negotiations with the Department of Finance for the financing of the rent requirements. That offer was rejected.

Likewise, as has now been further supported by the Department of Finance correspondence, the Department of Finance says very clearly that the Australian National Audit Office was well aware of the arrangements that it was entering into. It was well aware of what the Department of Finance was prepared to finance by way of the agreement. It very clearly says that in the agreement between the Australian National Audit Office and the Department of Finance.
I asked a question of the Auditor-General with respect to this agreement. He said that the agreement was only for the fit-out. Point 1 of the first paragraph states:

SPEECH.PARA: This agreement details the terms and conditions for the funding of the ANAO's accommodation move in Canberra to Section 22 Barton. It formalises agreements previously reached through the interchange of correspondence and meetings of officers from the Department of Finance (DOF) and the ANAO.
It goes on to say:
The purpose of this agreement is to allow the ANAO to fit out and occupy leased premises in Section 22 Barton.
It then states how the repayment of moneys will be conducted as follows:
Where the ANAO adopts a strategy to provide accommodation for less than 100 per cent of its staff at a particular location, the resulting savings will be made available to the ANAO.

As I understand it, that is how the Auditor-General thought he may be able to meet the additional cost in rent. Therefore, we really have to deal with the facts. The majority report of this committee supports an inquiry. I urge the Senate to adopt the majority report and resolve this issue once and for all.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a rather poor attempt at defending the indefensible. This agreement to lease is one of the most appalling documents that we have ever seen in the whole history of public administration. On its own admission, the Australian Property Group has said that this agreement is a one-off. There is no precedent for it, there is no other one like it and the Australian Property Group has informed all and sundry that it is not to be regarded as an acceptable model under which any other agreement is to be reached.

PARA.TAB: Why is it that we have this very special agreement that delivers $86 million out of the public till to the Labor Party coffers over 15 years? Why is it that the Department of Finance said that it believes the nine per cent annual increment, as provided for in the agreement for lease and the lease itself, is an unacceptable term; that it is not commercial; and that, therefore, the department will only provide for a one per cent increment, which means that the Labor Party will receive $34 million less than is provided for under the lease?

The Auditor-General has given evidence that by the year 1995-96 he will have run out of money to do his job properly. That may well suit the intent of some in the government—they would probably quite like that—but it does not serve the public interest. The Department of Finance is very sensible, and thank goodness we have the Department of Finance, which was able to bring this to the attention of the people.

As I said, we have heard some rather pathetic attempts to defend the indefensible. I understand why the Labor Party would go to the barricades to protect this lease—$86 million will pay for a lot of elections. Indeed, the day that that agreement to lease was entered into, the Labor Party entered into a mortgage for $50 million. In other words, that lease document was a bankable document.

The financial statements of John Curtin House state that the building cost no more than $22 million to build. But the Labor Party got a mortgage for $50 million, because the lease document is a bankable document. Why is that so? The reason is that the agreement is for 15 years with a five per cent option and a built-in nine per cent annual increment that may not be negotiated down; it may only be negotiated up.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean a five-year option?

—I am saying a five-year option after 15 years, with a nine per cent annual increment—unprecedented in any other government contract—over a 15-year period, and $86 million goes into the coffers of the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: When this matter was brought to the Senate's attention, first by my colleague Senator Parer in a press release and then by my asking questions in the estimates committees, we suddenly discovered that we could not get the particulars of the rental, the increment and all the terms and conditions that would be associated with this document and lease. I said to the Australian Democrats, `Democrats, will you please agree with the opposition that we won't give the government its appropriations bills until such time as it tables the lease documentation in the parliament?'. The Democrats agreed to that and at half past one in the morning we got the documents, but guess what? All the salient parts—all the figures—were whited out.

It was not until later that I really recognised the significance of all this. I thought the government had been using executive power to enter into these lease agreements, but I found out subsequently that it had been relying on the Lands Acquisition Act. That is why the Attorney-General's Department signs the leases and is involved in giving advice at the last minute.

I am advised, and evidence was given, that, as we know, the Lands Acquisition Act provides that, once an agreement is signed, it is mandatory upon the government to table all relevant documentation in both houses of parliament. Guess what? It did not happen. Not only did it not happen, but when the department was forced to give us the documentation, it deliberately whited out all the particulars, which the act on which it relied said must be included.

Was it an oversight? That was the answer given by the manager of the Australian Property Group when I asked him why they did not comply with the law. His answer was that it was an administrative oversight. How convenient!The Labor Party is saved and its money is protected because another subclause in the act states that failure to table the documentation will not render the agreement invalid. What a shame!

TALK.START.PARA: —You are getting angry again.
—You bet I am angry, Senator Bolkus, because it was you who was in charge of the negotiations.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Bishop knows full well that I was not in charge of the negotiations. The negotiations were conducted in the department without my knowledge. There is not one piece of evidence on the record anywhere to suggest that.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President.
—I am on a point of order. Sit down!
—Order!
—The point of order is that Senator Bishop is deliberately misleading this Senate in the way that she has tried to mislead it for three years. It is an old issue, and she knows it.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Thank you very much. There is no point of order. Senator Bolkus was the minister in charge of the negotiations. He cannot abrogate his responsibility by trying, as Senator Collins has done, to blame the public servants. The fact is that he is the minister responsible. The Labor Party is the beneficiary—the party of which he is the endorsed candidate. The man who represents the Labor Party was in charge of the negotiations. All this attention has been focused on the nature of this agreement with the Auditor-General—not the department of fisheries, the department of primary industry or anybody else—becoming the tenant of a political party. I do not care which political party it is; it is not right.
—You know that is not the truth.

—It is absolutely the truth. Senator Bolkus knows full well—it is in the evidence and on the record—that the Labor Party was never put on the list in the first place. At all times, it was concealed that the Labor Party was to be the landlord of the Auditor-General.
—Tell us about that.

—The Labor Party's name did not appear. It was at a secret meeting that someone popped along and said, `Guess what! This building is available'. It was referred to as lot 22 Barton or the Lend Lease development. We never saw the Labor Party's name on it until we saw the actual development plans. That was very convenient.

PARA.TAB: So we have this sensitive agreement and the Labor Party benefiting from the taxpayers' purse to the tune of $86 million over 15 years. There was legislation in place that required the documentation to be tabled in the parliament, and that was deliberately not complied with. When we forced the Labor Party to put the documentation on the table it whited out all the particulars. Administrative oversight? Pardon my cynicism, but I do not think so. At every turn there was an attempt to keep this matter hidden until it was locked up, and the Labor Party benefits at the taxpayers' expense.

Evidence has been given that the rental is way above the rental paid by everybody else in the Canberra area. There is evidence in the so-called independent report by Baillieu Knight Frank that says, `This is a legal matter, get some legal advice.' It is very interesting to see, when people go around collecting evidence in this town, how frightened individuals are that they might not get government business if they provide further evidence that might go against the Labor Party. What a sinister town this is becoming!

At the end of day we find that no proper outside valuations were made, that it was a cosy in-house deal. The consensus afterwards is that it is a non-commercial lease and that the Auditor-General has been duped into becoming the meat in the sandwich. This is because the agreement is between the Commonwealth and the Labor Party. It was not signed by an agency of the government; it was signed by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) who is exercising delegated authority under the Lands Acquisition Act. Those are the facts. The Commonwealth has entered into an agreement which benefits the Labor Party and all propriety was cast asunder and it was not properly disclosed.

My colleagues Senator Campbell and Senator Parer have in very fulsome ways outlined why this process reeks to high heaven. Senator Parer says that this lease should be negotiated so that it is in accordance with the principles of the Department of Finance. He and I have said these things over a period of months. Yet at every turn the Labor Party resists because at stake is its $50 million mortgage. If this lease is broken, where is the cash flow going to come from to meet the mortgage repayments. The taxpayer is being held to ransom so that the Labor Party can circumvent the laws that require disclosure of how much tomato sauce was bought to use at a sausage sizzle, as we on this side of the chamber have to do. The Labor Party bypasses those laws and takes the money straight from the taxpayers' pocket. It is a pipeline to the Mint; $86 million straight into the Labor Party coffers to buy its way into office.

This is the most disgraceful agreement we have ever seen. It is one which many of us will continue to pursue until there is some decency in the Labor Party and it says that it will renegotiate the agreement in accordance with the principles of the Department of Finance. That is what is being called upon with this agreement. What we are calling for in this debate is that there be some decency and the agreement be renegotiated so that there can be at least some acknowledgment by the Labor Party of the uncommercial, unfair advantage it is giving itself by way of funding out of the taxpayers' purse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address another issue which is in the Estimate Committee D report. I have concerns about the issues raised by my colleagues, but they have canvassed the issues very broadly and expressed the concerns of the coalition. My concern relates to the contract to market the disability reform package. Page 4 of the majority report states:

SPEECH.PARA: This matter again received substantial attention during the Committee's meeting with Senator Patterson directing questions about the involvement of the Office of Government Information and Advertising in the letting and management of the DRP contract.
At point 12 it continues:
Attention is drawn to the attached minority report on this matter by Opposition members of the Committee.

I express concern that that is the only comment that the Chair had to make on this issue. I am not a member of that committee but I went to that meeting because, in order to investigate this issue, I had to go across a number of estimates committees. We have seen some articles in the press recently about the role of estimates committees and their value. Had we not had estimates committees this issue would have been undiscovered and we would not have known the extent of the problems associated with the letting of this contract and the implementation of the contract. I take issue with those journalists who say that estimates committees do not do anything.

PARA.TAB: I know that they may seem time consuming and, as Senator Alston said publicly, we may need to address the ways in which those estimates committees are conducted. That is the government's business. It can do that. It can organise the departments to be there. We have been very constructive in suggesting, for example, whether we need the Australian Institute of Family Studies to appear. The coalition has been very cooperative in that regard. We would be cooperative if the government came up with a reasonable solution.

Notwithstanding the issue about estimates committees, the minority report I submitted highlights my grave concerns about the letting of this contract. This contract was for $4.9 million of taxpayers' money and it was to publicise the disability reform package. I became interested in this matter when workers in the disabilities area came to me and said that they were concerned about what was happening with the contract and they had questions about it.
I bring to the attention of the Senate some of the points I outlined in the minority report. That report states:

SPEECH.PARA: that the Working Committee of the Ministerial Counsel on Information and Advertising only sought one alternative to the mainstream advertising approach. . .

I will explain this. This program was to be publicised. The working committee of the ministerial council had a process of looking at, by selective tender, companies that might do this. Since only one name came up it would be possible to assume that that company would have an unfair advantage during the final selection process for a contractor to market the DRP if the committee was looking at an alternative marketing approach. The only company nominated was this company.

PARA.TAB: We asked questions about how the company was chosen. We asked about the method used by the Office of Government Information and Advertising to choose an alternative to the mainstream advertising approach. What it did was insert three key words in a database of 1,500 potential contractors and it selected the name of the company. Then we asked it what it did about vetting this company and whether it had determined whether the company had the capacity to undertake a contract worth $4.9 million. I chased around various estimates committees to find out what happened because nobody seemed to know. The committee that was organising and supervising this contract said that it thought OGIA had done it. What we found out was that it obtained two oral references about the selected company. One of the references was from a government department in New South Wales. It obtained these oral references to see whether the company could undertake this contract.

One concern we have is that no checks of the financial capabilities of this company were undertaken prior to the contract being awarded. Normally, certain procedures are undertaken to ensure that a company is able to carry out a contract of this size. If the company's last annual return to the Australian Securities Commission had been obtained—and that is very easy to do—prior to the letting of the contract and it had been checked, it would have revealed that the company was trading at a loss, that its liabilities exceeded its assets, and it was probably balance sheet insolvent. This is a company to which the government intended to let a contract worth $4.9 million of taxpayers' money.

A contract was let to this company and this year the company went into liquidation. There were 229 unspecified creditors; some may be associated with other work that the company was doing but some were related to the contract. OGIA has estimated that this work is to the tune of $114,000. When we asked questions about these matters it was also contended that the Commonwealth had no financial responsibility to these unsecured creditors, although it appeared to many of the creditors that the company was working on behalf of the Commonwealth.

In some cases the company used a letterhead with a logo at the top which was also being used by the department, but with a different address. Also, some of the company's officers were working out of Commonwealth offices. Therefore, the creditors considered the company was operating under the umbrella of the Commonwealth. They thought that they were actually negotiating with someone who was doing a job on behalf of the Commonwealth, but the Commonwealth says that it has no financial responsibility for these companies that are out of pocket.

Another matter that is of great concern is that some of those people have disabilities. People with disabilities were contracted by the company to undertake programs to promote the disability reform package. The irony of all this is that this company—a company which was contracted to promote the disability reform package, to talk about what the government is doing for people with disabilities—has employed people with disabilities whom it has not paid.

This contract was being supervised—and I use that word loosely because of what happened—in some way by three departments that were represented on the management committee. This committee was responsible for managing the contract. The committee was also attended by someone from OGIA who was chairing that committee but seemed, from what was said in estimates, not to be responsible in terms of the contract itself. So it appeared that the three departments were responsible for managing the contract with OGIA chairing and coordinating it.

In May-June 1992, a number of meetings were held—I think some eight meetings in five weeks, but I will not be held to that exact figure—and there were discussions as to whether the contract should be terminated. Two of the departments said that the contract should be terminated. One department said, `No. We should go on'. If you were in business and had let a contract for $4.95 million, and if along the way you had some grave concerns about the contract and went to the managing director or your shareholders afterwards and had said, `Look, I'm awfully sorry, two out of three decided that we should not go ahead, but we could not reach a consensus so we went on with it', you would not have a job and the shareholders would have you for breakfast. In this case, the taxpayers ought to have questions answered for them. Here was this contract being let and two out of the three departments had expressed grave concern about whether the contract should continue.

Another concern that we raised was that while the contract stipulated that Corporate Impacts, the company that had the contract, be paid on a monthly basis—that is, $200,000 per month—all except $62,000 of the $4.95 million designated for the contract had been paid to Corporate Impacts by February 1993. I do not know what the government was going to do between February 1993 and June 1993 when the contract ended, because it only had $62,000 left to pay out of the $4.95 million.

Yet another concern that we expressed was that an officer from OGIA gave evidence that two designated persons to the contract may have mischarged the Commonwealth in excess of $220,000 between them. Another concern raised was that despite the fact that these two designated persons are the directors of another company which, according to form 507 lodged with the Australian Securities Commission by the liquidator, has a damages claim of $1.88 million against Corporate Impacts, the Commonwealth does not seem to have examined this matter.

Also, an officer from OGIA gave evidence that the network facilitators, the people employed by Corporate Impacts, employed to carry out this contract worked 13,000 fewer head hours than the 55,000 head hours stipulated in the contract. In the face of this nearly all of the contract is paid out; only $62,000 is left of $4.95 million. So one would have assumed that those head hours that were in the contract would have been fulfilled.

A further concern that we raised in the minority report was that form 507 lodged with the Australian Securities Commission by the liquidator of Corporate Impacts indicates that 16 of the network facilitators who were employed by Corporate Impacts to implement its network marketing approach to the DRP contract, which was endorsed by the working committee of the ministerial council, are owed entitlements by Corporate Impacts. So Corporate Impacts owes money to people it employed.

Another concern is that an officer from OGIA gave evidence that one of the directors may have mischarged the Commonwealth for travel costs entailed in the execution of the DRP contract. It was also revealed that to date an undisclosed number of deliverables with an undisclosed value have not been provided to the Commonwealth by Corporate Impacts. It was also revealed in these estimates hearings that in spite of the concerns expressed about the financial viability of Corporate Impacts by the management committee, from November 1992 onwards a further contract of $29,500 was awarded by the Commonwealth Environmental Protection Agency of the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories to Corporate Impacts in April 1993. That was a matter of weeks prior to its application for voluntary liquidation in May 1993.

An issue of grave concern is that an officer of OGIA has questioned the objectivity of the liquidator appointed to Corporate Impacts. The Commonwealth's concerns about the execution of its contract are of such gravity that it is currently considering legal action. Evidence was provided in another estimates committee that a company contracted by the Commonwealth to evaluate this contract was threatened by Corporate Impacts with legal action resulting in delay of the evaluation report. I have seen the draft report and I must admit that from that evaluation it does not seem that the problem was all Corporate Impacts' way. The evaluation says that there had been a recommendation that a director or coordinator be appointed to liaise with Corporate Impacts and the three departments. That apparently was never done. Had that happened, some of these problems may have been ironed out—I doubt that all of them would have been ironed out, but who is responsible? I kept asking the minister: where does the buck stop?

Some of the officers told their respective ministers that they had concerns about the contract and how it was progressing, but nothing seemed to be done. Senator McMullan had some responsibility and nothing seemed to be done on his part. So the situation is just dragging on. I admit that it was an unusual contract; it went across a number of departments with OGIA chairing it, and that meant that some issues could slip between the stools. But people went to their ministers and said, `We have grave concerns' and yet nothing was done about it.

Another concern was that evidence was provided in another estimates committee that a former member of the management committee that managed the contract is taking legal action against Corporate Impacts and its principal arising out of allegations made about him in the context of the DRP contract which he considers to be defamatory.

A further concern that we raised is that evidence provided in another estimates committee shows that it has cost two of the three departments represented on the management committee—namely, the Department of Social Security and the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services—over $247,000 and in excess of 9,900 staff hours to supervise this contract. During the estimates hearings an officer from OGIA described this contract as having `always been a troublesome, difficult relationship—more and more troublesome as it has gone on'. So we not only have to consider the cost of the contract; we have also to consider almost a quarter of a million dollars expended in staff time and administrative costs.

Another concern that was expressed was that evidence provided by officers appearing before Estimates Committee D and another estimates committee indicates that there is a lack of clear guidelines stipulating who has responsibility for checking the bona fides of a contractor when a contractor crosses a number of Commonwealth agencies. We saw that this was not done. This company was not investigated appropriately, as most other companies would be before such a large contract was let.

Another concern was that evidence provided by officers appearing before this committee and another estimates committee indicates that there is a lack of clear guidelines for the procurement of marketing and advertising related services. So there are two problems—one when there is a crossing across departments and the other when what is being procured is not equipment or tangibles. There are not clear guidelines for procurement of marketing and advertising related services.

Another concern expressed was that evidence provided by officers appearing before this and another estimates committee indicates that there is a lack of clear guidelines outlining how decisions relating to the management of the contract are made if the contract crosses across a number of Commonwealth agencies.

The overall concern for me is that the aim of this project was to publicise the government's changes in disability reform when, really, the people who have lost out in this are people with disabilities. They have not been served well. In terms of the outcome of this contract, the evaluation is not as favourable as it might have been if it had not had all the problems that have been associated with it. More people—more doctors, more employers, more carers—would have known about the government's program to encourage people with disabilities into open employment.

I return to the issue that I raised earlier. There are people with disabilities who are unpaid creditors. I find that ironical. I cannot believe that we had a contract for $4.95 million and the company was not investigated properly beforehand. That was atrocious. Every taxpayer ought to be concerned about that. I hope that the lessons we have learnt through the letting of this contract—the problems associated with crossing departments, the problems associated with crossing agencies and the problems associated with the procurement of advertising and marketing services—are addressed by the government so that we do not find a farce like this again.

This situation is a farce. Two officers from two departments thought we should stop the contract. Because one was not happy about it and there was not consensus, nothing was done about it. I think that the ministers ought to ask questions about their responsibility. I have asked questions about their responsibility and where the buck stops.

I believe that a Senate committee ought to give further consideration to the issues, which I have outlined in the report, of the letting of the DRP contract, the management of the contract and, specifically, why advice from two of three departments on the management committee that the DRP contract be terminated was ignored.

Such a committee should also investigate debts owed to unsecured creditors from the DRP contract, look at the possibility of the mischarging of the Commonwealth by Corporate Impacts, examine the allegations that have been made about the objectivity of the liquidator, examine why a further contract was let to Corporate Impacts in April 1993 although the Commonwealth must have had significant doubts about the company's financial viability, examine what sorts of mechanisms are put in place so that a department is aware of companies with whom other departments are currently having problems, and also examine the effectiveness of current purchasing guidelines. I express concern that Senator Coates did not see fit to address the issue in more detail in the majority report. I commend the minority report to honourable senators.
