DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS REFORM BILL 1993INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS COURT (JUDGES' REMUNERATION) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 and the Industrial Relations Court (Judges' Remuneration) Bill 1993. I intend to split my contribution to the debate on these bills into five parts: the industrial relations court; the boycott provisions; reform of the Australian industrial relations system; lack of consultation; and the use of conventions.

PARA.TAB: I intend to deal principally with the reform bill as the remuneration bill only provides for salaries of judges appointed to the industrial relations court. As we are opposing the establishment of the industrial relations court under part 7 of the reform bill, we will also be opposing the remuneration bill.

Debate on the establishment of a specialist industrial relations court has been around for some 25 years. The last occasion was during the debate on the Industrial Relations Bill 1987, which was aborted by the Hawke-Labor government. By the time the Industrial Relations Bill was reintroduced in 1988, the High Court had determined that the industrial division of the Federal Court did have the authority to make determinations on industrial relations matters. Therefore, the government did not proceed in this direction. I refer honourable members on the other side of the chamber to what the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, had to say at that time.

Nothing has changed since 1988. The opposition has not been able to find any valid reasons that this court should be established and the minister has not even attempted to justify the need for it. On that basis, there is no justification for the establishment of this specialist industrial relations court which will make already complicated legal systems even more complex. One could well also mention the additional costs of putting another court in place and how much it would cost taxpayers. The Law Council of Australia spelt it out clearly to the Senate committee. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: No reason is given why the Federal Court could not exercise the jurisdiction, even the new jurisdiction, proposed for the Industrial Relations Court. There is no suggestion that the Federal Court has not performed effectively in its Industrial Division.

The opposition will be moving an amendment to part 7 of the reform bill to delete all reference to the industrial relations court to ensure that the Federal Court of Australia continues to have jurisdiction for industrial relations matters.

PARA.TAB: The second matter I wish to address is the boycott provisions at part 6 of the bill. The opposition totally rejects the changes to the boycott provisions, as does every employer organisation in the country, and we will be moving to delete part 6 of the bill. In cases such as Mudginberri, Dollar Sweets, Columbus Shipping Line, the live sheep export dispute and the boycotting of our mining industry, the main protection for industry has been the secondary boycott provisions of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. They have worked and worked extremely successfully. Under this bill, they have been diluted to such an extent that they will be useless both as a threat against taking illegal or irresponsible action and as an option for obtaining speedy resolution to disputes.

The new 72-hour rule is just a licence to damage business going about its legal activity. The situation was best expressed to the committee by two comments, the first by Dr Blain, an adviser from the Western Australian government. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we very much support the thrust of what you are saying, that is, we very much support the retention of the existing provisions for 45D and 45E. I think an important part of the rationale for our support is what we would call the threat effect. I think this is what you were alluding to, perhaps in different words. The fact that it has not been used on a large number of occasions is not the major point. The major point is that it is there to be used if the situation requires.
The second comment, by Mr Barry Watchorn of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, relates to the 72-hour rule. He said:

. . . you are looking at a regime in which there is a theoretical 72 hour window of opportunity, albeit that the commission can cut short, where boycott action can bite on an employer. There are cases in which 72 hours can be extremely damaging, certainly for those involved in organising exhibitions. And dare I say it, in such extravaganzas as the current Madonna series of concerts, 72 hours could be too long for any of that.

The fact that political boycotts will now legally return without any protection in the Trade Practices Act is unfortunate and will mean that industry in this country will be very severely damaged and could well move offshore.

PARA.TAB: The third area I wish to deal with is reform of the industrial relations system in Australia. This bill will go down in history as an opportunity lost. This bill is an unmitigated disaster. Let us look at the intent and the result. To do so, we should recall what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) promised in his speech of 21 April. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me describe the model of industrial relations we are working towards. It is model which places primary emphasis on bargaining at the workplace level within a framework of minimum standards provided by arbitral tribunals. It is a model under which compulsory arbitrated awards and arbitrated wage increases will be there only as a safety net. This safety net would not be intended to prescribe the actual conditions of work of most employees but only to catch those unable to make workplace agreements with employees.
Later in the same speech the Prime Minister said:
We want it to be close to 100 per cent of employees under federal awards.

The question now becomes: will the legislation fulfil the Prime Minister's statement? If the evidence given to the Senate committee in most of the submissions and from a vast majority of witnesses is any guide, the answer is a categorical no. For example, Mr Vernon Winley, assistant director of the Business Council of Australia, told the committee:
Our view is that the Industrial Relations Reform Bill misses the opportunity to introduce real reform into the industrial relations system.
Again, during the committee hearings Mr Bryan Noakes of ACCI was asked whether this delivers what the Prime Minister promised. The answer was:
No, it does not, not in the least.

The Prime Minister's vision for industrial relations reform pivoted on a massive expansion of workplace or enterprise agreements, on productivity improvements and resultant increases in employment opportunities. But that vision, which may have been able to be achieved, was hijacked by the ACTU. In the end, all that was achieved was to make already complex procedures more complex and difficult to satisfy, even in the relatively simple certified agreements area. This was best illustrated to the committee by Mr Reg Hamilton of ACCI who said:
The second issue I wish to raise relates to paragraph 7 at page 3 of our written submission, where we indicate that the new certified agreement provisions add some eight new tests.
He went on to say:

It seems the count has gone up. We are now advised that there are an additional two tests, so that should read that the new certified agreement provisions add some 10 new tests to the existing provisions.
So much for simplification and making it easier!

PARA.TAB: In the area of enterprise flexibility agreements covering employers and non-union employees, the situation is even worse. In fact, when asked if this legislation would be an impediment to improving employment in the small business sector, Mr Robert Bastian of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia said:

SPEECH.PARA: From my understanding of it and from what I believe to be the average small employer's understanding of it, unquestionably yes.
The more one delves into this bill, the more obvious it becomes that it is a step backwards, not a step forward.

PARA.TAB: The fourth matter I wish to address is the lack of consultation. Mr Brereton claims he consulted widely. Let us look at the response to this claim. In doing so, I acknowledge that he or his department did table the number of meetings that were held with various groups, but it is worth noting that a number of speeches made at conferences and the like were included in the meetings with employers or employer organisations. I refer to an extract from the submission made by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry to the Senate committee. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The process of developing the bill was inappropriate and not in accordance with a tripartite approach. The framework for the bill was developed by bipartite discussions with the ACTU through a negotiating committee on which ACCI was not represented.
Nor, might I add, was any other employer or employer organisation. Later in the same submission, ACCI stated:

No agreed positions were reached, no policy proposals were put to employers in writing, and ACCI received no response to its comprehensive written submissions forwarded to the Government in May. No written advice of any kind was received from the Government until after it had reached agreement with the ACTU, and on no occasion has ACCI been formally provided with a copy of that agreement.

This view was consistently put by all employer representatives. What has emerged is a lopsided bill which gives increased power to the trade union movement; it does not provide equity between the various parties. This was best expressed by the National Farmers Federation which, like others, stated:
No, we do not think it provides equity between the parties.

An analysis of the submissions from 27 individuals and organisations received by the Senate standing committee on this bill, shows just how widespread opposition to the bill is. Submissions from the ALP governments of South Australia and the ACT and the one from the ACTU were the only cases of support without reservation. The Queensland Labor government, while expressing support, expressed reservation about the intrusiveness of the bill with regard to states rights.

PARA.TAB: One submission thought the ILO related provisions for workers with family responsibilities were too narrow. Another submission, from the Coal Association, did not address the terms of reference but made some very valid points about its unique industrial relations position with regard to the Coal Industry Tribunal, which no doubt will be debated at another time.

The remaining 20 submissions—that is 20 out of 27—all expressed opposition to the legislation for a variety of reasons, including concern that the Industrial Relations Reform Bill would not achieve its stated aims; union bias; reduced employer legal powers, especially the secondary boycott provisions; the use of external affairs powers; the complexity of enterprise agreement procedures; and the unnecessary duplication of existing legal procedures.

Even if the consultation had been balanced, there is little chance that equitable legislation would have been drafted when it is noted that 27—or about 25 per cent—of all federal Labor members and senators list as an occupation before entering parliament paid or senior representational positions with a trade union or trades and labour councils. It is clear that the consultation process was lopsided. In fact, one can only conclude that employers were delivered a fait accompli to fiddle at the edges. The dissenting report's principal recommendation that the bill should be returned to the minister is absolutely valid.

Another area which I find disturbing—and the last one I have time to address today—is the increasing tendency of the federal government to justify its legislative program by using ILO and United Nations conventions, and to impose the intent of them on states by application of the foreign affairs powers. In the case of this legislation, the inclusion by annexure of ILO and United Nations conventions has reached new heights and, as far as we can ascertain, for the first time we have witnessed the use of ILO recommendations which carry no legislative weight and which, in some instances, are contrary to the provisions contained in the relevant convention.

Another worry is the inclusion in the bill of ILO convention 135 on workers' representatives, which was ratified by the Keating government on 26 February 1993 and which will have no effect on Australian law until 12 months have elapsed since ratification. This ratification was contrary to the guidelines laid down by the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet to the effect that initiatives of this nature should not be undertaken during an election period.

Obviously, this government is too lazy and incompetent to introduce its own legislation program. It relies on bad information provided domestically by the likes of the ACTU or, internationally, by the ILO—in both instances, sources with barrows of their own to push. The Keating government is hiding behind the skirts of international government by using the foreign affairs power in a manner which was never intended. By this means, legislation has been enacted which has profound effects on federal and state jurisdictions without proper debate in the federal parliament or between the federal and state governments.

This government ignores the mandate given to the state governments to reform industrial relations, particularly in Victoria and Western Australia—and it is worth looking at the recent survey with regard to industrial relations reform in Victoria. Instead, it uses a sledgehammer approach with the use of the external affairs power to impose its own will on those states which maintain their legislative independence and continue to resist pressure from the ACTU or the TLCs.
Federal Labor is quite open in this regard. The minister's second reading speech in the House of Representatives and his colleague's speech here use the same words. They state:

SPEECH.PARA: In States where the standards, as outlined in the legislation, are adequately met, the federal provisions will not apply.

Yet we see from this legislation that we could well have the situation whereby, because the words in the Queensland and federal legislation are similar in that the minimum wage is set by an arbitrated mechanism, but that of Western Australia is set by the minister on a recommendation from the Western Australian Industrial Arbitration Commission, the minimum wage in Western Australia could be higher than that in Queensland while being illegal or not accepted under this legislation. If anyone can think of anything crazier than that, I do not know what it can be. The Senate should amend the bill's title and call it the `Trade Unions Sanctions and Power Enhancement Guarantee Bill 1993', because that is what it is all about.

PARA.TAB: During the bill's SCEET hearings, witnesses were asked about their comprehension of the bill. It was best summed up by Mr Robert Bastian of COSBOA who said:

SPEECH.PARA: I say over and over again that we do not understand the full ramifications of this bill. Nobody does. That is point one. I stress again that the smaller end of things is where employment is really occurring and where this bill seems, in my view, to land most harshly. Quite frankly, the government is not much further advanced than I am in terms of approaching the back of a TV set with a screwdriver. I just do not think we know what we are playing with here. My strongest counsel would be to say not to ram this thing through in the next couple of weeks, let the debate run for as long as it takes to get a clearer picture.
I am repeating myself. We know that the reversal of direction has been wrought by the very forces that we are frightened of.

When the bill was introduced in the House of Representatives, the minister indicated that there would be a number of technical and other amendments. We have already seen 177 amendments and no doubt more will be introduced here. Whether we like it or not, we are going to be debating this bill and subsequent bills to correct errors, resulting from inadequate drafting instructions, and unforeseen consequences for many months, if not years, not to mention the bad policy behind this legislation. Quite simply, the bill is not ready for debate. It is wasting our valuable time. It has not been prepared with any equity in mind and it will not achieve its intended objectives, even to the extent that the existing act, left in place unaltered, would achieve more.

PARA.TAB: On that basis, the coalition does not support any aspects of this bill and accordingly will be voting against it. Certainly in my 3 1/2 years in this parliament I have never seen so much anger and concern expressed by such a wide spread of the community with regard to a piece of legislation. That has come through the committee hearings we have had, through personal comments, through meetings that I have attended and through my fax machine today. I hope that I am not the only one receiving faxes in this place, but I have received more than 300 letters from concerned small businesses today expressing their frustration and concern that this legislation will inhibit their ability to perform and their ability to expand their operations, employ more people and address some aspects of the unemployment problem that we have in this country.

I do not believe—and nor does the rest of the coalition—that this bill will improve the unemployment situation. It will be another encumbrance on businesses, which will exacerbate the problem. I will quote from a letter I have selected from the pile I have received. The first one says:

SPEECH.PARA: Plumbers use `unions' for joining pipes.
The other sorts of unions need to remain limited by law so that small businesses can contribute to the national income.
As Senator, you are obliged to prevent legislation detrimental to this nation. We request that you use your power to stop this Bill.

The other letters are similar. What I can do is raise the issues in this place. I appeal to the Greens, the Democrats and Senator Harradine to recognise that there is a whole group of people in our community who feel totally aggrieved by the federal government's approach to industrial relations. The government certainly has no mandate for what it is doing as a result of the last election. It should stop pandering to the ACTU and look at serving the national interest. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the debate on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 and the Industrial Relations Court (Judges' Remuneration) Bill 1993. The second of these bills is a machinery matter and relates to remuneration for judges. It is part of the reform package. I will say very little about that bill. I will confine my remarks essentially to the reform package itself.

PARA.TAB: I have a feeling of great pride in being associated with the Labor government which has championed legislation such as this. I am proud that in my first year as a Labor senator and as a member of the Australian Labor Party I am able to support the introduction of legislation of this type which redresses many of the imbalances that working people in this country have faced for many years. The bill provides a minimum safety net for all workers throughout Australia, no matter what state they live in. The bill in many respects highlights the very basic divisions that exist between the major political parties in this country.

The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) in his second reading speech indicated that no legislative package could ever hope to satisfy the competing views of all groups with an interest in industrial relations. What is encouraging, he said, is that he had found throughout his consultations a measure of consensus on the need for reform of the kind that we are proposing, although there is obviously discord on the detail of how it should be achieved. For its part, the government believes that the proposals strike the right balance between enhancing flexibility and ensuring an adequate safety net of employee protection. The right balance has been something that Labor governments have been seeking to achieve since 1983, when this government came to office.

The basic principles of Labor's industrial relations policy assume partnership. They assume a notion that all aspects of the work force—be it business, be it unions, be it workers or be it government—can work together. They assume that through enterprise bargaining the government is able to initiate policy frameworks that devolve that partnership approach to the enterprise level and achieve workplace flexibility and productivity growth without sacrificing the basic rights and conditions of Australian workers.

The new stream of enterprise bargaining will allow even greater flexibility and open new ways for both the lightly unionised and the heavily unionised workplaces to enact change. It is a partnership which is recognised in this bill. It recognises that industrial relations legislation must be based on striking the balance and delivering fairness. At the current time the arguments concerning this package revolve around the appropriate mix of flexibility and protection. Some employer organisations argued before the Senate standing committee, as Senator Crane has indicated, that the maintenance of a compulsory award system reduces flexibility. This was not the view supported by the committee.

Supporters of the bill argue that a cooperative relationship between employee and employer would improve flexibility and productivity as workers negotiate in an atmosphere free from fear. These divisions between the various state governments on this issue highlight the very basic difference that exists between the various political parties in this country. The Labor government in South Australia supported the thrust of the bill and saw it as a positive step, while the submission from the Victorian government was critical of the bill.

The committee's report presented to the Senate dealt with the bill's implications for the states in regard to states' rights and responsibilities. The report found that the bill would enable the Commonwealth to use its external affairs and corporations powers to underpin laws dealing with industrial relations. After listening to a range of state government objections, the committee was satisfied that, where a state had appropriate and adequate standards regarding minimum entitlements, the jurisdiction will remain within that state. This is certainly not the case in regard to Victoria and Western Australia.

It should be noted that, in regard to the provision of enterprise flexibility agreements, only those covered by federal awards will be covered by the new legislation. We see the flood of workers from Victoria seeking federal award coverage for the very reasons that this bill highlights—the need to protect basic human rights and industrial decency. The Senate committee report stated quite clearly that the fears expressed by some regarding the intrusion on states' rights are more imagined than real.

Let us look at some of the aims of the bill as distinct from some of the hysteria that we have heard. The industrial relations system we have before us has three basic goals. It aims to promote productivity in workplaces and ensure efficiency in industry and, therefore, economic growth and prosperity for the community as a whole. It aims to ensure the quality of working life for workers arising from a cooperative relationship between workers and their employers. It aims to ensure the recognition that workers do not have equal bargaining power with their employers to prevent exploitation. In the present economic climate it has to be appreciated that high unemployment is a weapon used by some employers to force down wages and conditions. Leaving workers and their employers to deal directly with each other without any support from state safety nets would be forcing workers back into the worst excesses of the industrial revolution. We would be left with the unequal relationship of master and servant. Those who support the deregulation of the labour market seem only interested in one aspect of flexibility, and that is flexibility downwards for wages and conditions for working people. This is the sort of bargaining position that has been epitomised by the champion of the New Right in Victoria, Mr Peter Boyle, whose infamous statement `make them fear the sack' rings very loud in the ears of many workers throughout this country. It has become the way of industrial relations for many in Victoria. It is the sort of approach that the coalition, as we have just heard, supports.

This approach would completely work against the three goals that I have already indicated tonight. It would do nothing to enhance productivity and certainly nothing to promote cooperation. It would serve to perpetuate and encourage exploitation. This government, on the other hand, through the Industrial Relations Reform Bill, is committed to a system which recognises the unequal bargaining power between workers and their employees and which provides a framework of minimum standards within the process of enterprise bargaining.

Any industrial relations system must establish minimum standards; otherwise the law of the jungle would apply. But any such minima must be reasonable and comprehensive. They should be capable of being relied upon; otherwise their existence is fanciful and provides no real protection. The Australian community supports the award system which has been in place in this country throughout this century.

This legislation accepts awards as setting the minimum wages and conditions for the great majority of workers in this country. This is fair and appropriate. Those minima can then form the basis of agreements entered into at workshop level to provide greater flexibility and productivity as well as additional benefits for working people.

This can be compared with the unfair and unjust approach to minimum standards that we see in my home state of Victoria where basic minima include: four weeks additional annual leave for each year worked after a year has been worked and no pro rata entitlements; one week's sick leave for each year worked after a year has been worked and no pro rata entitlements; an hourly rate of pay equal to the base award rate for the classification of employee as at the time the act commenced. Of course, recently in Victoria special legislation has had to be introduced to try to provide the basic minimum award entitlement to an $8 increase that the arbitration commission recently granted because acts instituted by the Victorian state government clearly are not capable of being able to cope with such situations.

The other minimum requirement is 52 weeks unpaid parental and adoption leave and a right to work part time with employer's agreement for two years after the adoption or birth of a child. These basic conditions enacted by the Victorian Employee Relations Act are substantially inferior to the conditions enjoyed by workers under awards—that is, both federal and other states' awards. The Victorian government does not even argue that these conditions are sufficient to protect workers. In its submission to the Senate committee investigating the bill, it merely emphasised that those conditions are minimal only. Heaven help people who are forced to rely upon them!

It is because workers in Victoria no longer have access to compulsory arbitration that this federal legislation provides additional protection through extending minimum standards through international conventions. The provisions in this bill giving the federal commission power to set minimum wages are especially important for Victorian workers where the Victorian government has sought to abolish awards. I might add that this will also be of enormous benefit to Western Australian workers.

Clearly, the first avenue of these workers will be to seek federal award coverage. That process is already under way and will be enhanced by the amendments to section 111 of the act contained in this legislative package. Thereafter, a second avenue of redress will be to seek an order from the federal commission with respect to appropriate wages.

It is a tragedy that Victorian workers are in fact second class citizens when it comes to industrial relations and are to an extent reliant upon the provisions that have been enacted by the Victorian parliament. It is clear from the Victorian government's own figures that the great majority of Victorian workers are now seeking to remain on awards or remain covered by their former award conditions.

According to the Victorian government's submission to the Senate committee, of the 1.9 million employed persons in Victoria, only 210,000 have reached individual employment contracts—a measly 11 per cent. There are far fewer collective agreements—only 158. Given the secrecy surrounding the agreements, it is difficult to know the number of employees covered by them. We can only estimate that it is just a few.

So we have a minuscule number of collective agreements and 11 per cent of workers forced to bargain individually with their employees—probably it is a `take it or leave it' proposition—and with no public scrutiny to ensure that there is no disadvantage test. The greatest protection of this particular provision in this package of legislation is the provision of the no disadvantage test. This provides great reassurance to workers embarked on any process of change and reform at the workplace level. The absence of such a test is the greatest injustice under the Victorian system.

I turn to the questions of unfair dismissal and equal pay, which are two other aspects of this bill. Here again we can see that Victorians are at a clear disadvantage when compared with workers in other states.

We have a proposition where the national Labor government is intent on forging a partnership between workers, employers and government. This is in contrast to the approach of the opposition, which is content to rely on its old-fashioned 19th century notions of master and servant relationships. In recent years, that partnership approach has been extended to the workplace through enterprise bargaining, achieving greater flexibility and productivity without sacrificing the basic rights and conditions of Australian workers.

Labor's approach has been to promote fairness in the relationship between workers and employers. It has fostered the participation of workers in the process of workplace reform. The Industrial Relations Reform Bill would promote an open and accountable system which is clearly in sharp contrast to the actions that have been undertaken by the reactionary elements of the new right governments in various states of this Commonwealth.

They fear the capacity of a Labor government to introduce fair and reasonable legislation to provide the necessary framework for decency in industrial relations.

A secretive system, which is the one that those opposite support, is one that divides workers from each other. As we have seen in Victoria, such a system merely enables employers to force their workers to accept reduced working conditions without having to suffer the consequences of adverse publicity and public condemnation. It is not for the Liberal Party of the 1990s the Deakin model; it is not for the Liberal Party of the 1990s the Higgins model that talked about some decency and fairness in the approach to social relations in this country. TALK.START.PARA: —The approach being championed here tonight is the Victorian approach—in an historical sense as much as anything else—that talks about a 19th century notion about the relationship between people in a society. That system, which is operating in my home state, seeks to keep the public away from understanding industrial relations. The industrial relations bill accepts awards as setting the minimum wages and conditions for the great majority of Australian workers. The Australian community supports the award system which has been in place throughout this century. It is a provision that allows for people to actually be empowered. I conclude on this point of empowerment.

The Victorian government in its written submission talked about its notion of empowerment. In an ideal situation the coalition wants to see workers with no power over their jobs, their lives or their social conditions. We have the notion that arrangements should be put in place that prevent workers from organising effectively. As I mentioned earlier, the New Right philosophy of industrial relations seeks to govern by making people fear the sack.

The Industrial Relations Reform Bill, on the other hand, provides a framework which allows workers to bargain with their employers on something akin to an equitable negotiating position. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to congratulate the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Laurie Brereton, on his Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. This legislation is the result of a long period of consultation with unions, employers and associated interest groups. Of course, it was endorsed in its final form by the Australian Council of Trade Unions through the ACTU Council.

PARA.TAB: The main purpose of the legislation is to facilitate the spread of enterprise bargaining within the federal system of industrial relations; create a limited right to strike by modifying the operation of statutory and common law sanctions on industrial action, and thus comply with our treaty obligations regarding ILO conventions; and guarantee certain minimum standards of employment to all Australian workers. At the same time, the legislation will result in the strengthening of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The legislation will increase the ability of the IRC to ensure that awards are relevant, that equal pay is made real and available to all and that all Australians are protected against unfair dismissals.

One of the most significant changes that this legislation will bring to Australian workers is the legal right to withdraw their labour. It will therefore bring Australia into line with ILO conventions and our long neglected ILO treaty obligations, which recognise the right to strike as a fundamental exercise of employees' freedom to form effective unions.

Currently there exist myriad restraints on strike activity, including sanction provisions, compliance measures and penalties. These constraints have been a source of industrial contention. At the same time, the constraints have been the subject of much international criticism. Of course, they come from the master-servant relationship, to which Senator Carr referred, which is the basis in law for many of those sanctions.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you're back in the 17th century too, are you?

—One might say that I am back in the 17th century. Senator Crane lauded people who at the moment are stuffing our faxes with protest letters. But some of the representatives of business have indicated how way out some of those people are. I will quote from one paragraph of a letter that I have in my hand. The letter states:

PARA.TAB: We have never felt the need of a union to help us—our policy is to foster the Master and Servant relationship and when a person is first employed it is explained that if I or you need a union to settle a difference between us I am not doing my job as an employer.

SPEECH.PARA: Here is an employer who has something to say on the very point about which members of the opposition seem upset. Plenty of employers who have been backing the coalition believe in that master-servant relationship. I seek leave to table that letter, in case opposition senators have any doubt about its veracity.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1993, for the third time in four years, the ILO committee issued the Australian government with a direct request relating to Australia's compliance with ILO convention 87 on the Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise, 1948. Concerns were again raised over the lack of protection of trade unions and their members against common law action and over the scope of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act.

PARA.TAB: Questions were also raised about the compatibility of the convention and Australia's ILO treaty obligations with the boycott provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1991, mirroring sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act; essential services legislation in New South Wales, the Northern Territory, Tasmania, Victoria and South Australia; and other federal legislation. I know that members of the coalition are upset about ILO obligations, but they are obligations simply because they relate to fundamental rights throughout the world that have been acknowledged as being essential in democratic societies. We support that. We believe that it is proper to give credence to ILO conventions.

This bill addresses the majority of these concerns. It seeks to limit and rationalise the operation of these compliance measures by protecting certain forms of industrial action, reducing the operation of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act and repealing certain criminal sanctions in the IR Act 1988. I strongly support that. I strongly support those moves because I believe that such an outcome is essential in the modern industrial relations milieu that we are trying to create. This also fits in with my own experience of the unfairness of penal clauses. I had an experience of enterprise bargaining 40 years ago when I was an apprentice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Forty years ago?

—Yes, 40 years ago when I was an apprentice. I was the clerk of a chapel—`clerk' meaning secretary, in case anybody gets that position confused with those held by the clerks in this place; and `chapel' referring to a union organisation in a printing factory. I wrote a letter to the employer because the tradesmen were seeking a wage increase of #2. The employer panicked. He went to his employers' association, which was aware of the penal provisions of the Arbitration Act of the fifties. Immediately, I became the head of the match, as they say, and, under the arbitration rules at that time, the innocent, straightforward letter that I had written became a letter of demand. Of course, a move was made to go to the Industrial Relations Commission. This was enterprise bargaining 40 years ago.

PARA.TAB: In no time flat, the employer believed what his association had to say—employers' associations have not changed much over the years; they are the same today—and we had a serious situation for a relatively small factory of about 30 people. As a teenager, I was threatened with the penal clauses. I was defended, of course, by my union. But I had few rights because the law, as has always been the case, favoured the employer. This legislation brings fairness to the situation and makes possible proper enterprise negotiations.

As an aside, I might mention that I spent the rest of my apprenticeship under pressure from my employer. People on the other side of the chamber do not know what it is like to spend years under pressure and having everything one does watched and checked. It went further. My indentures were threatened by the employer and there was pressure on my parents. So I was schooled at an early age about the penal provisions of the Arbitration Act.

I am very glad to be here today to see the provisions being altered. My employer was a good employer; he was not a bad person. Even as a teenager I could see that we were each playing roles, but the system was wrong because it was unfair. Enterprise bargaining will become much fairer as a result of the changes proposed in this legislation.

I became a union official and, finally, secretary of a union. I could talk for some time, but I will not, of the cases I have come across where so many people have been victimised or injured in their employment because of the subtle, and the not so subtle, pressures. People have been tramped from their employment because they have acted as representatives of employees. This legislation changes the system that we have followed until now and gives us a chance of moving into a situation that will be much fairer.

I support this legislation because it seeks to implement a whole range of protections, based on international labour standards, for minimum wages, workers with family responsibility, unpaid parental leave and termination rights. I support this legislation because it maintains the award system. The coalition does not like that because it is fair. The coalition lost the election in March because people see it as a fair system and they want to work within that fair system.

This bill contains a number of amendments aimed at maintaining and strengthening the award system with the commission given responsibility to ensure secure, relevant and consistent wages and conditions of employment. The award framework will be maintained so that it provides an effective safety net underpinning direct bargaining while having proper regard to the interests of the parties and the wider community. In determining safety net increases in wages and conditions through test cases, for example, public interest considerations will continue to be particularly important. While the emphasis is on a consistent framework of minimum award rates, provision is made for paid rates awards to continue and be maintained in areas where employees have customarily had access to them.

The other area that I particularly commend this legislation for is the position of women workers and their gains under this legislation. I particularly welcome the legislation because it supports those who are most vulnerable in workplace bargaining—that is, women workers in traditionally female dominated industries. Historically, women have been located in the weakest and less unionised sectors of the labour force. Despite this, however, Australian workers have achieved one of the smallest gender wages gaps in the world. Because of our award system, historically, rises won by fitters eventually flowed to child-care workers and shop assistants.

This legislation proposes reforms which will maintain and strengthen the award system. This can only be considered advantageous to women workers. At the same time, this legislation supports the other factor which has aided women's relative position in the work force—that is, unionism. I make no apology for it because the facts are very clear: workers in weak bargaining positions, such as women, need the presence of a union, particularly during enterprise bargaining. The Industrial Relations Reform Bill seeks to assure employees that their conditions will be protected by the no disadvantage clause, which is the key to that in this legislation, and by the fact that unions have a right to be involved in enterprise agreements. If I have time I will refer to some of the letters I have received from some of the more fringe elements of employers' organisations who cannot stand having an equal relationship with their employees. Their letters indicate that they want to stand over people who are in a weakened position.

This is an important part of the government's attempt to extend enterprise agreements because unionism protects women more than it protects men. Gross exploitation of workers occurs in non-unionised female areas. In Australia unionised men earn 8.5 per cent more than non-unionised men but unionised women earn 25 per cent more than non-unionised women. Of course, the state Liberal governments have given us tremendous examples of that. If people from South Australia, particularly women, are listening to this broadcast tonight, I say to them: make sure that you do not make a mistake when you come to elect a state government because in every case the Liberal Party in power in state governments has given advantage to the employer.

A recent survey of enterprise bargains under the New South Wales Act in my own state show that unions protect hours of work. Union agreements provided for 35- to 38-hour weeks in 85 per cent of cases, whereas only half of non-union agreements provided for less than 40 hours. Unions protect all conditions better. Ninety-three per cent of unions have superannuation, whereas only 75 per cent of non-unionists do. It was a similar case with annual leave loading where the figures were 89 per cent and 68 per cent. With sick leave the figures were 90 per cent and 67 per cent and with long service leave the figures were 85 per cent and 52 per cent.

Another thing that I anticipate other people might raise in this debate relates to unionised workplaces. It is not true that the majority of workers are in non-unionised workplaces. At least 77 per cent of employees in organisations with 20 or more employees are in unionised workplaces—in other words, where there is a unionist working.

In the short time that I have left I wish to endorse my position by quoting an article from the Sydney Morning Herald of 2 December written by Sigrid Kirk, headed `Women the big losers in enterprise pay deals'. It states:

Women suffer serious disadvantages under the State's enterprise bargaining system, with many giving up penalties and allowances in return for no pay increases, says a report commissioned by the NSW Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a report commissioned by the government but is an indictment of a Liberal state government's industrial relations policy. The article goes on:

PARA.TAB: Under the bargaining system, women are far less likely to receive pay increases than men, have little access to perks such as cars and expense accounts, receive little training and are largely denied productivity based rewards.

SPEECH.PARA: The article goes on to list a number of what it describes as alarming findings, including:
.In almost half (46 per cent) of female agreements, penalties and allowances were deleted without increase in pay, compared with 27 per cent of male agreements.
.86 per cent of male agreements contained wage increases compared with 58 per cent of female ones.
.Almost 80 per cent of enterprise deals which delivered a wage increase to workers were male agreements, 18 per cent were female and 4.5 per cent were mixed.

I would go on, but time will beat me. What I wanted to do—and I believe I have through quoting that Sydney Morning Herald article—is show that the state Liberal government's implementation of Liberal policy in practice has disadvantaged women in particular. With its policies, it would disadvantage any person who was in a weakened position.

PARA.TAB: The letters that I have received today that Senator Crane referred to indicate the bias of certain employers who are worried about getting fairness. They indicate the colourful expression of people genuinely making representations. One says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the Federal Government is "hand in glove" with the Unions who are controlled by "THUGS".
Another says:

Should the trade union bullying of the 1890's, 1917, 1949, (put down by the Labour Prime Minister) and the 1970 & 1980's again be let loose on the people of Australia or should the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 be modified to encourage an increased understanding to the benefit of all?
Another letter states:
To tamper with the termination of an employee is a gross intrusion on the management rights of a businessman.

Many of these letters reflect the fact that small businesses, in particular—and many of these people facing enterprise agreements do have small businesses—have never had to be fair in their negotiations. They have always had the employers' association to help them. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Industrial Relations Court (Judges' Remuneration) Bill 1993 and particularly on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. This bill aims to set rules for the relationship between employers and employees, principally for the 30 per cent of the private sector which is unionised. How should we judge this bill? Should it be judged on the intricacies of the industrial relations world, which very few people understand, or should it be judged on the impact it will have on the lives of most Australians? I believe it should be judged on the latter. It is in that context that I want to address my remarks tonight. This bill needs to be looked at in the context of how the Australian economy works and the need for high economic growth within this nation.

PARA.TAB: For many years, Australia has experienced poor economic growth relative to the rest of the world. We have been slipping backwards for a long time—over and above the recession we had to have of recent years. We need sustained high economic growth, if only to look at what we need to do for the disadvantaged—the one million unemployed, the half million or so underemployed. What sort of future are we offering our children? We need sustained high economic growth. Sure, we are currently experiencing growth at the rate of about three per cent. We need economic growth at the rate of five per cent or higher. The three per cent is being achieved because there is a lot of spare capacity in the Australian economy. When that is used up, our growth will tend to stall. The key to understanding long-term sustained economic growth is investment. We need to understand where investment comes from, who makes the decisions. Without investment, there will be no long-term sustained growth. Take this one single fact: the past two years have seen the lowest level of investment in plant and equipment in this economy since World War II—less than six per cent. Instead of being less than six per cent, it should be up to a level of eight or 10 per cent.

We need most businesses—after all, there are more than 800,000 businesses in Australia—to look to expand, and they have to do that via investment. That is where new jobs come from. We need lots of people who want to invest and start up new businesses. Again, that is where new jobs come from. What do those people with existing businesses or those looking to form new businesses do? They look outwardly at the world from within this Australian economy and they ask the question: `Can I make a reasonable return on this investment? Can I make a quid on this investment?' What are the risks involved in making investments? Why is it that the rate of investment is so low in this country right now?

The fundamental question before us tonight is: what does this industrial relations bill do to encourage investment in Australia? Does it help anybody? Does it encourage anybody to invest? The answers to these questions are clear and unequivocal. If we look at the evidence that has been put before various committees going back many years—the evidence that has been encouraged by this government, the evidence contained in key reports this government has commissioned—we see there is no question that one of the key things that needs to be done in this economy is to free up the labour market for more flexibility. Without that, businesses will not expand and wealth will not be created.

If enacted, this bill will, firstly, add further impediments to business. It will discourage investment because it produces further hurdles against employers and employees getting together and making businesses work more productively. Secondly, it will strengthen the award system when we should be getting away from that and towards true enterprise agreements. Thirdly, it waters down the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act. Fourthly, it introduces much greater complexity to an already unwieldy system that not many people understand. Fifthly, it discourages investment by creating greater uncertainty in the business world.

Unfortunately, the government has given higher priority to the union movement than it has to the welfare of the economy and to the Australian people, because this bill basically supports the union movement. I do not want my comments to be interpreted as being anti-union. I do not blame the unions for what they have proposed to the government. Managers also need to lift their game. Last week, the Chairman of the Industry Commission, Bill Scales, called for labour market reform. He was reported in a newspaper article as saying that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . labour market flexibility would prove of little use if management were unable to take advantage of the benefits.
He is quoted as saying:

PARA.TAB: "It is impossible not to conclude that, without high quality management, labour market flexibility will be of little use to . . . Australia".

SPEECH.PARA: The article further states:

PARA.TAB: However, Mr Scales also expressed concern over trade union resistance to labour market reform, claiming the need for greater flexibility was "highlighted by the difficulty of getting the unemployed, and particularly the long-term unemployed, back to work".
He said the commission's call for greater labour market flexibility was not a call for low wages.

SPEECH.PARA: I am against—and the coalition is against—monopoly power. We are in favour of freedom of choice. If passed, this bill will ensure a faster track to extinction of the traditional union movement. If union officials were smart—and I know that a fair few of them are smart—they would be asking the government to truly free up the system. They would be working to sell their services by persuasion—not by legislation, not by compulsion.

PARA.TAB: How will businesses react to this legislation if enacted? Large businesses which are largely unionised will carry on as usual. A high proportion of their work force is unionised and they do have the management skills to negotiate and arrange enterprise agreements—sure, perhaps with some difficulty—in spite of what is being proposed. But the bill does nothing to encourage them and their employees to get together to work for greater productivity, hence greater wealth in this country, hence greater incomes and more jobs.

The evidence is quite clear that medium and small businesses will do nothing. Those wanting to formalise the agreements they now have will have the choice, in most states, of being able to do a true enterprise agreement through state legislation, except if they are respondents to federal awards. If that is the case, they will probably do nothing. They will not bother with this legislation.

This legislation does nothing for investment. It does nothing to encourage improved productivity, and that is what is required throughout the whole of the economy. It is a further impediment to the future prosperity of all Australians. It will lower incomes—lower than they otherwise would have been. It is an opportunity lost.

The need to free up the labour market has been identified by many reports and many advisers over many years. For example, there has been the Garnaut report, commissioned by this government in 1988; the Helen Hughes report; Manufacturing Council reports; the remarks of virtually every employer organisation and business investment organisation in Australia; and the remarks made by Bill Scales from the Industry Commission which I mentioned earlier. After all, it is those organisations which do the investment. They have to persuade investors, financiers, to put the money with them.

It is quite clear that this legislation will do nothing for people who are involved in the investment business and in managing businesses. We recommend that these bills not be passed. We urge the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine to think very seriously about them.
I will quote an article by the founder of the Australian Democrats, Don Chipp, in the Sunday Telegraph of 17 October 1993.

PARA.TAB: In Melbourne last week the Public Transport Corporation sacked an employee claiming he had been allegedly absent from work without permission about 100 times over the past two years.

—I agree; that is quite right.

PARA.TAB: Every employer, particularly small business, will testify that these sections have saved them from the worst kind of left-wing trade union thuggery, secondary boycotts and black bans.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not heard anything new in this argument. It is an argument; it is not a debate. It is an argument that has raged for, I think, more than a hundred years, although we have heard a new slant on some aspects of the argument.

PARA.TAB: The Industrial Relations Reform Bill extends basic minimum protections to all Australian workers. It shifts the emphasis from arbitration to conciliated bargaining. It accelerates the transformation of the award system from the principal instrument of pay and conditions to the safety net, maintaining minimum wage relativities and skill classifications except in essential services.

This bill legitimises non-union enterprise bargaining in Commonwealth law for the first time. This is something we have not heard from the critics of this legislation. That is a fact. We still believe that this legislation needs to be improved in key areas and we will pursue those improvements.

The concept of an agreement which was not modified in any way is a concept which is only perpetuated by ignorant reporting of the facts as they occur. The minister has honoured his claim that the bill would cause pain on both sides. Perhaps it is a Chinese saying that negotiation which leaves both parties crying is a good result.

Employers claim that Australia is uncompetitive because wage levels and on-costs are too high; some want a low safety net to allow wages to be driven down. We respond to that sort of criticism by saying that the Industrial Relations Reform Bill allows wage cuts and condition-bargaining to be arrived at through enterprise bargaining, but only if the Australian Industrial Relations Commission believes that that is not contrary to public interest.

According to Peter Roberts, writing in the Financial Review on 18 November, the New South Wales Office of Economic Development will soon release a report showing that Australian wages are actually lower than those paid in our more advanced Asian neighbours such as Japan, Singapore, South Korea and Hong Kong.

I welcome Senator Kernot's attendance to the debate. It is through her work and research only recently in Europe that we have revealed that on-costs in many parts of Europe have much less impact on employment levels than is sometimes claimed. Honourable senators wishing to comment on this sort of area should back up their hollow rhetoric with claims based on the sort of research that Senator Kernot did in Europe which revealed the extent of the falsity of the claim that it is on-costs in Australia that are making our industries uncompetitive.

The retention of awards has been criticised, too, because they are described as being too restrictive. In this legislation the new process of reviewing awards every three years should simplify those awards and turn them into a genuine safety net. The new enterprise flexibility agreements stream will prevent unions from obstructing an enterprise deal which overrides excessively prescriptive award provisions. I would suggest that that is another example of this bill's reduction of union power, in complete contradiction to the claims by some who have chosen to comment on this and communicate with us that this bill somehow extends union power. Nothing could be further from the truth. I repeat an observation I made earlier in my contribution here that this bill, for the first time, legitimises non-union enterprise bargaining.

Some employer groups have claimed that the non-union agreements stream containing enterprise flexibility agreements will not be used because the unions can have too great a role in that process. The Democrats' response to that suggestion is that precedent suggests that the Industrial Relations Commission would grant a right to be heard to a union which is party to an award to be varied by enterprise bargaining agreement even if it were not in this bill. The commission has an extremely limited discretion to refuse approval of an enterprise flexibility agreement. Unless an objecting union can show that the agreement fails the tests in this bill, the union would have very little chance of convincing the commission to reject it.

That opinion—that statement—which is based on the precedents which have been established through the history of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, is backed up by the situation we observe in Tasmania with the recent court finding in the Delta Hydraulics case. Union participation before the enterprise commissioner of Tasmania had previously been denied, but the court found that this was without foundation and contrary to justice, if you like. The concept that a union which had been party to the making of an award in the past should be denied the opportunity to be heard is not sustainable. Even if we did not have that provision in this bill, as I said earlier, precedent suggests that the Industrial Relations Commission would be loath to consider such an agreement without at least hearing from the union. I emphasise the word `hearing' because that process has been portrayed as the opportunity for unions to have a veto over such an agreement. Again, that is not the case. There is no provision for veto; there is the opportunity for that union to present its case.
The union notification provisions for enterprise flexibility agreements, in our belief, are not satisfactory as they are, and we will be seeking to amend them to modify that opportunity.

We are also concerned that some finance sector employers who are now covered by state awards want to fast-track into the federal system so they can make enterprise flexibility agreements. We agree with that and will be seeking to address it.

We will seek to reduce excessively prescriptive requirements which have been described as being a series of hurdles. Evidence given to the Senate committee of inquiry into this bill suggested there were a number of hurdles which employers would find far too difficult to jump. The fact that some of those were consequential and the fact that some of them were provisions which could be met by merely being in existence by employing somebody were conveniently ignored. But I would agree—and we can find some relevance in the claim—that some of these procedures are excessively prescriptive. We will pursue that to see if we can find a more convenient way around it.

Those procedures which remain are there to help to ensure fairness and good management in enterprise bargaining; they are not aimed at employers who are attempting to do the right thing with their team of workers. They are there to protect workers against those who would exploit their position to unfairly disadvantage the people they should be working with as a team.

The protection against unfair dismissal has been attacked as giving unions a veto over such sackings. We do not agree with that description of the provision; in fact, we think it is completely untrue. All the bill requires is for unions to be consulted where more than 15 employees are to be made redundant at the same time. Of the several dozen faxes and communications received in the last few days, the vast majority are from employers of six, eight or 10 employees who are unduly concerned about such a provision. They have been misled. These people who have gone about their business making, constructing, producing and contributing to Australia's wealth have been misled by communications directed to them by people who do not have a real interest in this bill and who just want to obstruct the progress of legislation. The people who have been contributing to Australia's wealth have been misled by the suggestion that somehow or other this particular provision will impinge on their freedom to negotiate and to work with their employees. That is not true.

The provision covers the situation where more than 15 employees are to be made redundant at the one time—and only in certain circumstances, anyway—and it makes provision for the unions to be consulted. Yet we have some incredibly draconian interpretations of that provision. The thrust of the termination provisions is to provide for procedural fairness and a proper look at alternatives for dismissal—in other words, good management and a touch of humanity. Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sure that you would be aware that the Australian Medical Association has highlighted the gross insensitivity with which some people are sacked in this country and the serious health problems that unemployment brings. It takes a bizarre imagination to cast employers in the role of victims of these provisions when the aim of the provisions is to help people who are about to lose their livelihoods.

The secondary boycott provisions have been attacked as rendering employers vulnerable to unreasonable industrial action. In principle, the scheme proposed in the bill better balances the rights of employers with those of employees. The intention is to legitimise sympathy strikes within the same company or group of companies and boycotts on multi-employer sites where one employer is endangering employees of other companies. Other boycotts will remain illegal and subject to the full force of the law. The government has responded to our concerns that the 72-hour conciliation period should be a maximum, which can be short-circuited where real harm is being caused.

The Industrial Relations Court has been attacked as being unnecessary and wasteful, but there is a range of new functions specified in this bill for that Industrial Relations Court—for instance, in the minimum entitlements provisions, which may best be vested in a specialist court. As well, at the insistence of the Democrats, the provisions for judicial registrars will provide cheap and ready access for individuals who have a case which is not efficiently presented in a major legal challenge but which is rather more suited to a small claims tribunal.

The government amendments that have been presented since this bill was first introduced in the lower house have lowered that wall between the new court and the Federal Court. Nevertheless, concerns have been raised with us that the new court will be bound by existing court rules, with all their complexity and potential for large legal costs. We would prefer that the new court be required to operate efficiently, cheaply and with a minimum of procedure. We would like the government to consider a future amendment to achieve that.

The right to strike and lockout during negotiations for single business certified agreements has been attacked as a recipe for industrial disputation which could send businesses to the wall. That is the sort of statement that has been made. But legitimising strikes and lockouts where arbitration is not available is consistent with international law. Employer groups have previously acknowledged that. Almost all unions and employees have the commonsense not to destroy their own jobs.

Another factor to be considered against the criticism of those rights to strike, to lock out or to engage in limited industrial action is that a bargaining period can be terminated by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission if one side refuses to negotiate. We raised with the government whether termination could occur on other grounds, but the fact is that any such provision would weaken the move towards bargaining and away from arbitration. Arbitration would be seen as a shelter from such a situation. Nevertheless, any return to widespread and damaging disputation would now warrant a more intrusive commission role in enterprise bargaining because the commission now has much more authority through the provisions in this bill than previously. But it is up to unions and employers to avoid an outcome that neither wants.

We remain concerned that groups with low bargaining power will miss out under enterprise bargaining. For example, work forces where women are in the majority are less likely to achieve pay rises through enterprise bargaining. But Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that no overall fall in women's pay relative to men has occurred through that process. The award review process and the minimum entitlements provisions will provide some protection for those groups, who could also include young people, old people, people from non-English speaking backgrounds, and so on. Parliament needs to monitor the impact of enterprise bargaining on such vulnerable groups and to be able to take corrective action if undesirable trends emerge. The Democrats will be moving for an annual survey to be conducted and for the results to be tabled in parliament.

We have another concern in that, although the bill requires the commission to take into account the ILO family responsibilities convention, we do not believe that the assumptions associated with that convention go far enough. With so many working couples in the workplace, it is high time that carers' leave was made available to allow workers to care for sick dependants, whether they are children, aged relatives or spouses with serious illnesses. We will be moving amendments requiring the commission to investigate and make orders on that matter. We will also move that leave to care for a sick spouse be extended to people not in traditional family units. That will require further definition in the committee stage. We have other concerns which we will be pursuing in the committee stage. Nevertheless, we support the general thrust of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. In doing so, I want to focus on the effect on the working women of Australia. While the bill will have a significant effect on all sectors of the work force, I am conscious that very little of the public debate has centred on what it will mean for working women. This comment extends not only to the debate in the House of Representatives and the Senate but also to the media coverage during the months leading up to the introduction of the legislation into the parliament.

PARA.TAB: For months we had a running saga in our newspapers about the progress of the government's negotiations on industrial reform. We have seen the Minister for Industrial Relations, Laurie Brereton, promising to bring about genuine reform in the labour market. He was going to do what none of his predecessors could achieve, namely, facilitate workplace bargaining and enterprise deals for non-unionists into the industrial relations structure. In a speech given by the minister in mid-October to mark the occasion of enterprise bargaining week, he said that the government's industrial reform package `would entrench enterprise bargaining as the very hallmark of Australia's industrial relations system'.

We all saw the minister being rolled by the ACTU. Any prospect of real reform disintegrated as a result of that. What we have not seen is extensive coverage on the impact of this proposed legislation on women. A week after the bill was finally tabled in the House of Representatives, the Minister for Industrial Relations made a very telling remark, namely, that the government would be making amendments to the bill to protect women from discrimination in the workplace. He was speaking at a conference in Sydney, a forum on the glass ceiling. He said that night—I think it was something like 4 November—that he would be introducing a range of amendments to the proposed legislation during the next sitting of parliament designed to ensure fairness and equity for women in the workplace.

That seemed very odd to me. We actually issued a press release on it. Here was the minister who had done all this so-called consulting and suddenly light had dawned on him that really he had not addressed the issue of women. It was somewhat ironic because, a week before tabling the bill, he issued a joint press release with Senator Crowley assuring women's groups that the government's industrial relations package would be fair and equitable to women. Yet he had to come in after the bill had been tabled and say that with the amendments he would address some of the concerns that women's groups had raised with him.

Within a week of the final draft, and after months of protracted negotiations with the ACTU, he admitted that the bill had been drafted without the necessary consultation to take the needs of women fully into account. One has to laugh when the Labor government touts itself as the great protector of women. What it should be saying is that women are a mere afterthought in Labor's scheme of things. So while the government and much of the media have been prepared largely to ignore the effect of this proposed legislation on women, I am certainly not.

There is another compelling reason why the position of women in relation to this bill warrants special consideration and comment. Women experience quite different employment status and occupational segregation and remuneration from men. Currently, around 3.2 million Australian workers, or 42 per cent of the total Australian labor force, are women. Of these 3.2 million women, around 75 per cent are employed on a part-time basis. In comparison, only 25 per cent of the 4.4 million Australian men in the labour force are part-time workers.

Apart from the predominance of women in part-time employment, women's employment is concentrated in particular occupations and industries. Well over half of Australia's working women are employed in the community services and wholesale and retail trade sectors. Women also dominate in finance and business services as well as in recreation, personal and other service sectors. Historically, these sectors have been less than industrially powerful than some of the male dominated sectors such as the mining, manufacturing and construction industries.

It is also true that women generally fall into the lower status occupations that tend to be less industrially powerful and receive wages below the national average. So in general women tend to occupy lower status and lower paid jobs in relatively industrially weak sectors of the labour force. Unfortunately, little is going to change under the proposals contained in this bill.

A central feature of this bill supposedly is to deliver institutional change to enable genuine enterprise bargaining. It is meant to represent a move away from our inflexible, outmoded, centralised wage fixing system. Rather than achieving this end, the bill reinforces and extends the federal industrial relations jurisdiction and the unions' role within it without extending access to workplace agreements to non-unionised workplaces.

This is simply a disaster for working women in this country. Traditionally, women have not been well looked after or represented by the trade union movement. Not surprisingly, fewer women have been and are currently members of trade unions than men. It is notable that union membership has been and still is lower amongst part-time workers, most of whom are women.

Women are also under-represented in the trade union structure. There are currently only eight women on the 38 strong ACTU executive. Recent surveys also confirm that Australia's biggest unions are themselves performing poorly as employers in putting women into influential positions. Only last week a conference on affirmative action for women in trade unions was told that an

SPEECH.PARA: analysis of eight key unions showed that jobs held by women were likely to have less power and status and be distant from decision making. The author of the survey said:
The higher we look in the union hierarchy, the less likely we are to find women employed.

By entrenching the role of unions in the new industrial relations environment, there is a very real concern that women will be disadvantaged. If unions effectively have a monopoly on the negotiations preceding enterprise agreements the best interests of women are likely not to be served.

PARA.TAB: Women need uninhibited access to enterprise bargaining if they are going to enjoy the benefits that it can deliver. I believe that there are tremendous gains for women in true enterprise bargaining but, in order to achieve these gains, women need to be at the negotiating table when the deal is being struck. They need to be informed about the process and able to engage freely in the negotiations.

I would like to make a comment on the role that the Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women has played in doing just that. It has produced a booklet called Snakes and Ladders which very clearly outlines to women the role that they can play in enterprise bargaining; that is, what they can do, how they can negotiate wages and how they can negotiate terms and conditions. It goes through these roles in a very clear, precise way. This is a positive step that the federation has taken to inform women.

I would recommend that any woman who is concerned about the issue of enterprise bargaining should read that booklet. It is a positive action that is being taken. It is the sort of thing that should be being done to encourage women to take responsibility, to be part of that negotiating process and to be there. It is often the case that men have the positions in unions. They are the ones dominating the decision making with the outcomes of those arrangements suiting men and not the needs of women who want to pick up children from school and who want to be involved in situations such as caring for older relatives or whatever else they might want to negotiate.

With the multiple roles that Australian women play—as carers, as workers, as mothers and as individuals—they need the upmost flexibility in their working arrangements. Genuine enterprise bargaining can deliver this flexibility in that it can allow women to negotiate more flexible working hours; it can reduce the stress involved in juggling a family and a job; and it can allow women to maintain a career with less interruption. But this will not happen while an out of touch, male dominated union sector and a male dominated hierarchy clings tenaciously to its pivotal negotiating role.

PARA.TAB: I am impressed by the commission's prompt response to my speech on 18 November 1993. But I doubt that because the commission says that it is not interested in political tactics. I appreciate the information contained in the letter from the CJC and I thank the commission for its gratuitous advice.

As the commission has opened up the lines of communication, I would like to find out a little more about its investigations. Accordingly, I would be grateful for the commission's advice in response to a series of questions. They are: (1) Is Mrs Bird, the Labor member for Whitsunday, a member of the parliamentary committee overseeing the Criminal Justice Commission? (2) What input does Mrs Bird and the parliamentary committee have in matters considered by the commission? (3) Do members of the committee and other parliamentarians supply the commission with information and requests for investigations?
