(6) Is the commission aware that, with two exceptions, the members of the Whitsunday Shire Council are not members of the Australian Labor Party and in fact follow other political views? (7) Could the commission indicate in a broad way what the 11 separate allegations of misconduct against the Whitsunday Shire Council are? (8) Can the commission indicate the dates on which each separate allegation was received by the commission?

If not, from what category of persons did the balance of complaints come? (12) How many of the complaints actually came from the shire clerk herself? (13) Is there is any official whistleblowers' protection legislation in Queensland. (14) If not, has it been discussed and what is the present state of legislation in that regard?

(15) Regarding the evidence that the CJC used to invoke the commission's statutory obligation under the Criminal Justice Act 1989 to investigate and take action where it appears that a person has been victimised, did the evidence come only from the person involved or was there other independent evidence? (16) I ask that the CJC might let me have the terms of the interim injunction issued. (17) When is the formal hearing on the injunction action to take place(?) (18) Is it possible to have a copy of the judgment granting the interim injunction.

(19) How many of the staff of the Whitsunday Shire Council have now applied for whistleblowers' protection? (20) Would the effect of a permanent injunction be to guarantee the awardee a permanent job for life without any possibility of ever being dismissed? (21) For someone who has obtained a permanent injunction to restrain a council from dismissing him or her, can that person ever be dismissed, regardless of how incompetent, disobedient or unsuitable that person might be. (24) Bearing in mind that the shire council elections are to be held on 26 March 1994, at what time is it expected that findings will be made publicly available? (25) Does the commission usually publishes in the media its private correspondence with members of parliament?

My interest in this matter arises from approaches made to me by constituents. I also have an interest in ensuring that elected members of local governments are able to govern and manage their councils as they have been democratically elected to do. As one who has had continuing concerns over the excesses of previous and current state governments, I am a long-term supporter of a criminal justice type of organisation, but I do understand the delicacy and sensitivity of the role of the CJC. In conclusion, I wish the CJC well in its continuing role and in its difficult task of identifying the genuine from the politically motivated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address a matter of great importance, that is, this nation's standard in South-East Asia. In particular, I am concerned that what we are seeing now is not an erosion of Australia's reputation in South-East Asia, but a landslide which will sweep our reputation away irreparably.

PARA.TAB: This evening I was motivated to speak on this matter after having received a facsimile copy of a media release put out by a Brisbane company called Voxson. I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate that media release, rather than speak to it at great length; I merely want to make a few comments.
Leave granted.
The media release read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Voxson
Voxson Sales Pty Ltd
Head Office
231 Holt Street, Penkenba,
Qld, 4008 Australia
Facsimile: (07) 868 1370
MEDIA RELEASE

PARA.EMPHASIS: AUSTRALIAN COMPANY THREATENED IN MALAYSIAN CRISIS

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland-based mobile communications company, Voxson International, has had its Malaysian operations threatened as a result of the current diplomatic crisis between Australia and Malaysia.

Voxson's Chairman and Managing Director, Mr Lucas Longginou, said he had been informed that a scheduled television appearance by Voxson representatives in Kuala Lumpur would be cancelled because of Prime Minister Paul Keating's refusal to apologise to his Malaysian counterpart, Dr Mahathir, for Mr Keating's recent "recalcitrant" remark.

"We were told that we would be dropped from the Malaysian current affairs program `Scope' because we were an Australian company and because of the Prime Minister's failure to apologise," Mr Longginou said.
Mr Longginou called on Mr Keating to apologise and said that the continuing rift with Malaysia had the capacity to cause enormous problems for Australian companies in Malaysia.

"We are constantly told by our Prime Minister that Australia's economic future lies in Asia, yet, here we have a situation which should never have occurred being allowed to fester by the hour," Mr Longginou said.

"As our Australian Statesman, Mr Keating should learn that the ill-tempered language he uses here in Australia is not appropriate, particularly in Asia, and that Australian interests throughout Asia have been jeopardised by his `off the cuff` comment.

"My company has millions of dollars and many years invested in Malaysia and throughout the broader Asian Rim and that investment, along with the investment of countless other Australian companies, could be irreparably damaged by this situation."
Mr Longginou said he received the report about the threatened TV boycott over the weekend and his company was monitoring the situation closely.
He said his Malaysian Manager had said the situation in Kuala Lumpur regarding the crisis was tense and seemed to be deepening by the day.
"The Malaysian media is now constantly pushing the `Buy Australian Last' theme and urgent action is now required to heal this situation.

"I would, on behalf of Australian industry, call upon the Prime Minister to swallow his pride and apologise so that we can all get on with the job of helping our economy—that is the most important issue in this whole situation."

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The problem raised in the media release is that Voxson, which is one of the few companies in this country—perhaps the only company—which is designing portable phones and selling them to South-East Asia, has become yet another victim of Mr Keating's unstoppable mouth. Over the weekend, a scheduled television appearance on the Malaysian current affairs program, Scope, was cancelled and the Voxson representative was not allowed on the program on the basis that it was an Australian company and that Mr Keating had offended Dr Mahathir and Malaysia generally by his comments.

PARA.TAB: What Mr Keating seemingly does not understand is that doing business in Asia is not just a matter of fronting up at the door, knocking, producing one's bag of wares and saying, `I'd like you to buy some of my mobile phones, trinkets or whatever it might be'. In Asia an immense amount of store is placed on good faith and personal relationships and, most importantly, an immense amount of store is placed on etiquette. Maybe Mr Keating does not understand this, but etiquette is the basis of all relationships in South-East Asia.

As one of the few Asian Australians involved in politics, let me say that one cannot stress too much the importance of etiquette. If one reads the Analects, one will see that half of what Confucius wrote—and I know Confucius is not directly relevant to Malaysia—was about etiquette; that is, what was good etiquette and bad etiquette, how one should learn etiquette and how one should apply etiquette. If Mr Keating does not have an understanding of etiquette, then all of the nonsense that we have heard from him about Australia becoming part of Asia is just nonsense.

We have to understand that if we want to be part of the region, if we want to be good neighbours, then we have to conduct ourselves as good neighbours. Everything that Mr Keating has done since making that comment in Seattle has only compounded the problem. He has tried to excuse it on the basis that it was part of the rough and tumble of politics. He has tried to excuse it on the basis that Dr Mahathir had not personally complained. Of course Dr Mahathir has not personally complained because that is merely an admission of the fact that Mr Keating's comments caused him to lose face.

Finally, we heard his grudging comment: `I didn't mean to cause any offence but I'm not going to go any further than that and Malaysia has to cop it or I'm going to take some action'. That just shows Mr Keating to be the sort of recalcitrant that he was accusing Dr Mahathir of being.

In conclusion, there is a very simple way out of this problem. I spoke recently to perhaps one of the most influential Malaysian born Australian businessmen. He said that the simple solution is for Mr Keating to have one of our senior government ministers, such as Senator Cook, Senator Evans or Senator Ray, apologise for any offence suffered by Dr Mahathir. Mr Keating does not even have to do it himself and that will be sufficient. But every day we dither, we make the situation worse. The problem is that we do not just make the situation worse for the government; we make the situation worse for the companies, the people and the jobs that are dependent on them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has there recently been an escalation in fighting between the military forces of the Sri Lankan Government and Tamil fighters?
(2) What is the extent of civilian casualties as a result of recent fighting?
(3) How widespread has been the practice of aerial bombardment, as used by the military forces of the Sri Lankan Government?
(4) How has Australia been involved in making representations to both sides of the conflict in Sri Lanka?
(5) What possibility remains for an external agency such as the Commonwealth or the United Nations to be involved in the implementation of a peace settlement in Sri Lanka?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Sri Lankan conflict, for most of 1993, has been characterised by occasional skirmishes, most of which have occurred in the east of the island or on the lagoons surrounding Jaffna. The Sri Lankan Government has been pursuing a strategy of driving the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) out of the east in preparation for the holding of local council elections. However, on 26 July 1993 the LTTE overran the Sri Lankan Army base at Janakpura, killing approximately 60 service personnel and 17 civilians and capturing a large quantity of weapons. Subsequently, in late September the Sri Lankan Government forces launched a five day operation, codenamed "Yal Devi", to the northwest of the Government base at Elephant Pass, resulting in the reported deaths of 130 LTTE and 118 Government troops. The LTTE responded by launching a large-scale attack on Government army and naval bases near Pooneryn to the west of Elephant Pass on 11 November. At the time of writing, Government losses were estimated at over 300 with a further 450 unaccounted for, while LTTE losses have been put at about 450.

(2) Details of civilian casualties from the latest battle are not yet known but very few, if any, civilians were believed to be in the vicinity of the bases when the attack took place. The Sri Lankan Air Force subsequently undertook a series of bombing raids on LTTE targets in the Jaffna area. Inaccurate bombing during these raids is reported to have resulted in an as yet unconfirmed number of civilian deaths and injuries.

Excluding the battle at Pooneryn, total civilian casualties in the north during 1993 are estimated at approximately 250, comprising 120 killed during Government shelling and bombing, and 130 killed or missing while attempting to cross the Jaffna lagoon. No information is available on casualties which might have been occasioned by LTTE operations in the area, although LTTE attacks on Sinhalese and Muslim villagers have lessened following adverse local and international reaction to their terror campaign in 1992 during which hundreds of civilians were killed. Further civilian casualties can be expected from continued LTTE activities.

(3) Apart from providing support during major military operations, Government forces resort infrequently to the use of artillery or aerial bombardments. Attempts are made to hit designated targets from the air, but it is apparent that some Government forces lack the expertise and equipment to achieve their objective precisely. It is the usual practice of the Sri Lankan forces to undertake an aerial leaflet drop prior to the launching of a major operation. The leaflets advise civilians to take cover in designated places. However, the latest inaccurate sorties by the Sri Lankan Air Force in the Jaffna area indicate that designated civilian sanctuaries do not necessarily provide guaranteed safety to civilians.

(4) The Australian High Commission in Colombo has made frequent representations to the Government of Sri Lanka, urging it to exercise restraint in its activities against the LTTE and to resume negotiations on a settlement of the communal problems in Sri Lanka. This activity includes representations to senior officers of the Armed Forces, senior Ministers, Parliamentarians and senior bureaucrats. The High Commission also participates in periodic group consultations with key military and civilian decision-makers. Direct contact with the LTTE is more difficult because it is in armed conflict with the Government and because of the geographic isolation of the LTTE leadership. The LTTE would be aware though of the Australian Government's statements deploring the continued violence in Sri Lanka and calling for both the Sri Lankan Government and the LTTE to strive for a negotiated settlement to the conflict. The Australian Government also maintains an open and constructive dialogue with a number of groups in Australia of Sri Lankan origin, including a number of Tamil organisations.

(5) I raised the prospect of Australia seeking to facilitate a role for the Commonwealth in promoting a negotiated settlement to the conflict with senior Sri Lankan Government officials during my visit to Sri Lanka in August 1990. Subsequent to my visit then Prime Minister Hawke wrote to the Sri Lankan President, the late Ranasinghe Premadasa, reiterating Australia's willingness to assist. While welcoming Australia's offer, the Sri Lankan President indicated a preference to continue attempts at direct negotiations between the Sri Lankan Government and the LTTE. A number of subsequent similar offers of assistance have been received by the Sri Lankan Government from international groups, church-based organisations and individuals. The Sri Lankan Government's response has continued to be that the conflict is a matter for internal resolution.

The Sri Lankan Government has stated publicly that it is willing to engage the LTTE in negotiations and has on a number of occasions invited the LTTE to participate in a Joint Parliamentary Committee which has been examining ways and means of resolving the conflict. However, little or no progress towards peace has been achieved since the series of meetings between the Government and the LTTE, which were held in Colombo in 1990, were abandoned by the LTTE. Since then LTTE actions, such as reneging on agreements to exchange its prisoners for supplies, have not assisted calls for dialogue to resolve the conflict. Despite the assassination of President Premadasa in Colombo on 1 May 1993, which the Sri Lankan Government attributes most firmly to the LTTE, President Wijetunga renewed the Government's offer to negotiate with the LTTE.

The Australian Government hopes that the recent fierce battle in the Pooneryn area, and the attendant tragic loss of so many lives, will not result in further attacks seeking retribution but will serve to focus both sides' attention on the essentiality of striving for a negotiated settlement.

Against the background of the Sri Lankan Government's view that the conflict is an internal matter, there seems little that the United Nations, the Commonwealth or the Australian Government can contribute, apart from continuing to urge both sides to resume negotiations and to avoid further tragic loss of life, particularly among the civilian population. But the Government stands ready to help facilitate any steps towards a negotiated settlement of the conflict.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 20 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS) which causes at least 6 500 people to be bedridden and forced to apply to the Commonwealth for invalid pensions and other sickness benefits and is estimated to cost the community about $60 million a year:
(1) Why has there been virtually no Commonwealth research funding directed towards finding a cause and a cure for CFS.
(2) Has funding been allocated for research into CFS; if so, what amount has been allocated.
(3) Will the funding allocated for CFS be increased.
(4) What was the cost to the Commonwealth of providing invalid pensions and other sickness benefits to those suffering with CFS.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) is the Commonwealth Government's main funding body for health and medical research, including research into Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS). The Government does not direct research into specific fields of research but rather allows expert NHMRC assessors to recommend funding to projects on the basis of merit.

(2) In 1993, the NHMRC is providing support totalling $70,685 for a research project into CFS being undertaken by Dr I. Hickie and his colleagues at the University of New South Wales. The project will run for three years in total, with $64,389 being allocated in 1994 and again in 1995.

(3) The level of funding into any medical condition, including CFS, is dependent upon applications submitted to the NHMRC for funding being of sufficient merit to warrant support. Competition for funds is intense and there is never an excess of funds. No new applications for funding into CFS were received for 1994.
(4) Issues pertaining to invalid pensions and sickness allowances fall within the portfolio responsibility of the Minister for Social Security. I have been advised as follows:

"At June 1993, the annual liability or disability support and sickness allowances for people identified as suffering from chronic fatigue syndrome or post viral infection totalled approximately $12 million.

However, medical conditions for Social Security recipients have only been recorded on the computer system since November 1991 and it is not possible to identify the cause of disability for people granted pension before that date.
Earlier research on medical conditions of invalid pensioners did not identify chronic fatigue syndrome separately as it had not at that time been recognised as a separate condition."

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 27 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) When did synthetic human insulins replace animal-based insulins for the vast majority of diabetics in Australia.
(2) Are any figures available for the percentage of diabetics in Australia who use synthetic human insulins instead of animal-based insulins; if so, what are these figures.
(3) Why was this percentage of diabetics in Australia converted to the use of synthetic human insulins.
(4) What studies or research was this decision based upon.
(5) Can it be confirmed that approximately 15-20 per cent of the diabetic population experience undetectable attacks of hypoglycaemia when using synthetic human insulin.
(6) What if anything has been done to overcome this problem.
(7) Has the United Kingdom recently reverted to using animal-based insulins due to problems detecting hypoglycaemia.
(8) Can the accuracy of reports which suggest that, in using animal-based insulins, many diabetics have recently lost all symptoms of an impending hypoglycaemic attack be confirmed.
(9) Has the formulation of animal-based insulins changed in any way recently; if so, how, when and why was this done.
(10) Is the issue of the shadow of undetectable hypoglycaemia now considered to be the issue of the greatest concern for any diabetic.
(11) What research is the department carrying out in this area.
(12) To what quality standards is insulin produced in this country and are copies of these standards available to the general public; if so, where can they be obtained.
(13) What independent testing procedures are in place to ensure that these standards are followed and adhered to at all times.
(14) In the light of the problems being experienced by diabetics, what assurances have been given that these quality standards are rigid enough to maintain effective control.
(15) Do studies take place in which different compositions of the same insulin are clinically tested.

(16) If a different formulation of the same insulin is found to benefit a higher percentage of people, do pharmaceutical companies change the compositions of their insulins without notice; if so, what confidence can the general public have that any insulin they use today is the same as it was 12 months ago.

(17) If various compositions of the same insulin do benefit different percentages of people, then is it possible for pharmaceutical companies to produce two or more formulations of the same insulin in an attempt to cater for all diabetics.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The first human insulins were approved for marketing in Australia in 1984.
Porcine insulins were withdrawn from the market in December 1989 following a commercial decision by the pharmaceutical companies which sponsored them. Bovine insulins remain on the market.

Data from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) indicate that the proportion of insulin prescriptions that were specifically for human insulin rose above fifty per cent for the first time in the 1989/90 financial year.
(2) In the 1992/93 financial year, 90.6 per cent of insulin prescriptions under the PBS were for human insulins and 9.4 per cent were for bovine insulins.

Information from a company which supplies porcine insulins suggests that a small number of diabetics (less than 150) continue to use these products under the Special Access Scheme (SAS) for unregistered drugs. As porcine insulins are not registered on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods they are not subsidised under the PBS.

(3) Decisions regarding transfer from animal to human insulins would have been made by prescribing physicians and their patients. The particular reasons for a transfer would vary from patient to patient. Factors influencing such decisions may have included:
the non-availability of porcine insulins after December 1989;
the increasing popularity of insulin pen injectors which are only available with human insulin;
perceptions by prescribers that human insulins held some advantage over animal insulins.

(4) The department has not been involved in the decision-making processes of the physicians who prescribe human insulins, or those of the pharmaceutical companies which decided to remove porcine insulins from the market. It is therefore not possible to provide details of the rationale for their decisions.

(5) No. Some studies have reported an increased incidence of hypoglycaemia and hypoglycaemic unawareness in patients transferring from animal to human insulins. Other studies have shown no difference between the two types of insulin. Recent research published in the New England Journal of Medicine (16 September 1993) suggests that these apparent effects are not related to the type of insulin but to the degree of control of diabetes itself.

(6) The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) has permitted sponsor companies to supply porcine insulins under the Special Access Scheme (SAS) for unapproved drugs to those patients who have had difficulties with human insulin.
(7) No. The TGA understands that in the United Kingdom porcine insulins were never removed from the market. While some patients may have returned to using them, human insulins are still widely used.

(8) Hypoglycaemic unawareness occurs with both human and animal-based insulins. (10) Persons with diabetes are at risk of developing a number of serious complications. These include hypoglycaemia, hypoglycaemic unawareness, blindness, vascular disease and neurological conditions. Additionally, manufacturers are required to demonstrate compliance with the principles of Good Manufacturing Practice as a condition of supply in Australia. The outcome of inspections conducted by the regulatory authorities in the country of manufacture to ensure this compliance are monitored by the TGA through Australia's membership of the Pharmaceutical Inspection Convention and bilateral arrangements with the United States' Food and Drug Administration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 16 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the statement by the Federal Government that it is committed to achieving 50 per cent female representation on government boards, councils and committees by the year 2000, is this 50 per cent goal a global figure whereby 50 per cent female representation overall is expected to be achieved or does the Government intend achieving 50 per cent female representation on each

QUESTION.PARA: and every government board, council and committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Government's target is to achieve 50 per cent representation of women on government boards, councils and committees by the year 2000. Performance against this target is measured on a global basis however every effort is made to ensure reasonable representation of both women and men on individual boards, councils and committees. Appointments to government boards, councils and committees continue to be based on merit.
